sec.title: Covariance matrix, eigenspectrum, and sampling procedures
sec.p: To begin, we multiplied the inferred firing rate of each neuron (see Methods) by a constant such that in the resulting activity trace ai\begin{document}$ a_{i}$\end{document}, the mean of ai(t)\begin{document}$ a_{i}(t)$\end{document} over the nonzero time frames equaled one (Meshulam et al., 2019). Consistent with the literature (Meshulam et al., 2019), this step aimed to eliminate possible confounding factors in the raw activity traces, such as the heterogeneous expression level of the fluorescence protein within neurons and the nonlinear conversion of the electrical signal to Ca2+ concentration. Note that after this scaling, neurons could still have different activity levels characterized by the variance of ai(t)\begin{document}$ a_{i}(t)$\end{document} over time, due to differences in the sparsity of activity (proportion of nonzero frames) and the distribution of nonzero ai(t)\begin{document}$ a_{i}(t)$\end{document} values. Without normalization, the covariance matrix becomes nearly diagonal, causing significant underestimation of the covariance structures.

The three models of covariance in Figure 2G–I were constructed as follows. For model in Figure 2G, the entries of matrix G\begin{document}$ G$\end{document} (with dimensions N×T\begin{document}$ N\times T$\end{document}) were sampled from an i.i.d. Gaussian distribution with zero mean and standard deviation σ=1\begin{document}$ \sigma=1$\end{document}. In Figure 2H, we constructed the composite covariance matrix for fish 1 achieved by maintaining the eigenvalues from the fish 1 data covariance matrix and replacing the eigenvectors U\begin{document}$ U$\end{document} with a set of random orthonormal basis. Lastly, the covariance matrix in Figure 2I was generated from a randomly connected recurrent network of linear rate neurons. The entries in the synaptic weight matrix are normally distributed with Jij∼N(0,g2/N)\begin{document}$ J_{ij}\sim\mathcal{N}(0,g^{2}/N)$\end{document}, with a coupling strength g=0.95\begin{document}$ g=0.95$\end{document} (Hu and Sompolinsky, 2022; Morales et al., 2023). For consistency, we used the same number of time frames T=7200\begin{document}$T=7200 $\end{document} when comparing CI across all the datasets (Figures 4B, C, 5D, E, Figure 4—figure supplement 2C). For other cases, we analyzed the full length of the data (number of time frames: fish 1 – 7495, fish 2 – 9774, fish 3 – 13,904, fish 4 – 7318, fish 5 – 7200, and fish 6 – 9388). Next, the covariance matrix was calculated as Cij=1T−1∑t=1T(ai(t)−a¯i)(aj(t)−a¯j)\begin{document}$ C_{ij}=\frac{1}{T-1}\sum_{t=1}^{T}\left(a_{i}(t)-\bar{a}_{i}\right)\left(a_{j} (t)-\bar{a}_{j}\right)$\end{document}, where a¯i\begin{document}$ \bar{a}_{i}$\end{document} is the mean of ai(t)\begin{document}$ a_{i}(t)$\end{document} over time. Finally, to visualize covariance matrices on a common scale, we multiplied matrix C by a constant such that the average of its diagonal entries equaled one, that is, Tr⁡(C)/N=1\begin{document}$ \operatorname{Tr}(C)/N=1$\end{document}. This scaling did not alter the shape of covariance eigenvalue distribution, but set the mean at 1 (see also Equation 8).

To maintain consistency across datasets, we fixed the same initial number of neurons at N0=1,024\begin{document}$ N_{0}=1,024$\end{document}. These N0\begin{document}$ N_{0}$\end{document} neurons were randomly chosen once for each zebrafish dataset and then used throughout the subsequent analyses. We adopted this setting for all analyses except in two particular instances: (1) for comparisons among the three sampling methods (RSap, ASap, and FSap), we specifically chose 1024 neurons centered along the anterior–posterior axis, mainly from the midbrain to the anterior hindbrain regions (Figure 5DE, Figure 5—figure supplement 6). (2) When investigating the impact of hunting behavior on scale invariance, we included the entire neuronal population (Appendix 1).

We used an iterative procedure to sample the covariance matrix C\begin{document}$ C$\end{document} (calculated from data or as simulated ERMs). For RSap, in the first iteration, we randomly selected half of the neurons. The covariance matrix for these selected neurons was a N/2×N/2\begin{document}$ N/2\times N/2$\end{document} diagonal block of C\begin{document}$ C$\end{document}. Similarly, the covariance matrix of the unselected neurons was another diagonal block of the same size. In the next iteration, we similarly created two new sampled blocks with half the number of neurons for each of the blocks we had. Repeating this process for n\begin{document}$ n$\end{document} iterations resulted in 2n blocks, each containing N:=N0/2n\begin{document}$ N:=N_{0}/2^{n}$\end{document} neurons. At each iteration, the eigenvalues of each block were calculated and averaged across the blocks after being sorted in descending order. Finally, the averaged eigenvalues were plotted against rank/N\begin{document}$ N$\end{document} on a log–log scale.

In the case of ASap and FSap, the process of selecting neurons was different, although the remaining procedures followed the RSap protocol. In ASap, the selection of neurons was based on a spatial criterion: neurons close to the anterior end on the anterior–posterior axis were grouped to create a diagonal block of size N2×N2\begin{document}$ \frac{N}{2}\times\frac{N}{2}$\end{document}, with the remaining neurons forming a separate block. FSap, on the other hand, used the RG framework (Meshulam et al., 2019) to define the blocks (details in Appendix 1). In each iteration, the cluster of neurons within a block that showed the highest average correlation (Ei≠j(Cij2)\begin{document}$ \mathrm{E}_{i\neq j}(C_{ij}^{2})$\end{document}) was identified and labeled as the most correlated cluster (refer to Figure 5D, Figure 5—figure supplement 6, and Figure 5—figure supplement 7).

In the ERM model, as part of implementing ASap, we generated anatomical and functional coordinates for neurons with a specified CCA properties as described in Methods. Mirroring the approach taken with our data, ASap segmented neurons into groups based on the first dimension of their anatomical coordinates, akin to the anterier–posterior axis. FSap employed the same RG procedures outlined earlier (Appendix 1).

To determine the overall power-law coefficient of the eigenspectra, α, throughout sampling, we fitted a straight line in the log–log rank plot to the large eigenvalues that combined the original and three iterations of sampled covariance matrices (selecting the top 10% eigenvalues for each matrix and excluding the first four largest ones for each matrix). We averaged the estimated α over 10 repetitions of the entire sampling procedure. R2\begin{document}$ R^{2}$\end{document} of the power-law fit was computed in a similar way. To visualize the statistical structures of the original and sampled covariance matrices, the orders of the neurons (i.e., columns and rows) are determined by the following algorithm. We first construct a symmetric Toeplitz matrix T\begin{document}$ \mathcal{T}$\end{document}, with entries Ti,j=ti−j\begin{document}$ \mathcal{T}_{i,j}=t_{i-j}$\end{document} and ti−j≡tj−i\begin{document}$ t_{i-j}\equiv t_{j-i}$\end{document}. The vector t→=[t0,t1,…,tN−1]\begin{document}$\vec{t}=[t_{0},t_{1},\ldots,t_{N-1}]$\end{document} is equal to the mean covariance vector of each neuron calculated below. Let ci→\begin{document}$ \vec{c_{i}}$\end{document} be a row vector of the data covariance matrix; we identify t→=1N∑i=1ND(ci→)\begin{document}$ \vec{t}=\frac{1}{N}\sum_{i=1}^{N}D(\vec{c_{i}})$\end{document}, where D(⋅)\begin{document}$ D(\cdot)$\end{document} denotes a numerical ordering operator, namely rearranging the elements in a vector c→\begin{document}$ \vec{c}$\end{document} such that c0≥c1≥…≥cN−1\begin{document}$ c_{0}\geq c_{1}\geq\ldots\geq c_{N-1}$\end{document}. The second step is to find a permutation matrix P such that ‖T−PCPT‖F\begin{document}$ \|\mathcal{T}-PCP^{T}\|_{F}$\end{document} is minimized, where ‖ ‖F\begin{document}$ \|\ \|_{F}$\end{document} denotes the Frobenius norm. This quadratic assignment problem is solved by simulated annealing. Note that after sampling, the smaller matrix will appear different from the larger one. We need to perform the above reordering algorithm for every sampled matrix so that matrices of different sizes become similar in Figure 2E.

The composite covariance matrix with substituted eigenvectors in Figure 2H was created as described in the following steps. First, we generated a random orthogonal matrix Ur\begin{document}$ U_{r}$\end{document} (based on the Haar measure) for the new eigenvectors. This was achieved by QR decomposition A=UrR\begin{document}$ A=U_{r}R$\end{document} of a random matrix A\begin{document}$ A$\end{document} with i.i.d. entries Aij∼N(0,1/N)\begin{document}$ A_{ij}\sim\mathcal{N}(0,1/N)$\end{document}. The composite covariance matrix Cr\begin{document}$ C_{r}$\end{document} was then defined as Cr:=UrΛUrT\begin{document}$ C_{r}:=U_{r}\Lambda U_{r}^{T}$\end{document}, where Λ\begin{document}$ \Lambda$\end{document} is a diagonal matrix that contains the eigenvalues of C\begin{document}$ C$\end{document}. Note that since all the eigenvalues are real and Ur\begin{document}$ U_{r}$\end{document} is orthogonal, the resulting Cr\begin{document}$ C_{r}$\end{document} is a real and symmetric matrix. By construction, Cr\begin{document}$ C_{r}$\end{document} and C\begin{document}$ C$\end{document} have the same eigenvalues, but their sampled eigenspectra can differ.

sec.title: Dimensionality
sec.p: In this section, we introduce the participation ratio (DPR\begin{document}$ D_{\text{PR}}$\end{document}) as a metric for effective dimensionality of a system, based on Recanatesi et al., 2019; Litwin-Kumar et al., 2017; Gao and Ganguli, 2015; Gao et al., 2017; Clark et al., 2023; Dahmen et al., 2020. DPR\begin{document}$ D_{\text{PR}}$\end{document} is defined as:(5)DPR(C)=(∑iλi)2∑iλi2=(Tr(C))2Tr(C2)=N2E(σ2)2NE(σ4)+N(N−1)Ei≠j(Cij2)\begin{document}$$\displaystyle D_{\text{PR}}(C) = \frac{\left(\sum_i \lambda_i\right)^2}{\sum_i \lambda_i^2} = \frac{\left(\mathrm{Tr}(C)\right)^2}{\mathrm{Tr}(C^2)} = \frac{N^2 \mathrm{E}(\sigma^2)^2}{N \mathrm{E}(\sigma^4) + N(N-1)\mathrm{E}_{i \neq j}(C_{ij}^2)}$$\end{document}

Here, λi\begin{document}$ \lambda_{i}$\end{document} are the eigenvalues of the covariance matrix C\begin{document}$ C$\end{document}, representing variances of neural activities. Tr(⋅)\begin{document}$ \mathrm{Tr}(\cdot)$\end{document} denotes the trace of the matrix. The term Ei≠j(Cij2)\begin{document}$ \mathrm{E}_{i\neq j}(C_{ij}^{2})$\end{document} denotes the expected value of the squared elements that lie off the main diagonal of C\begin{document}$ C$\end{document}. This represents the average squared covariance between the activities of distinct pairs of neurons.

With these definitions, we explore the asymptotic behavior of DPR\begin{document}$ D_{\text{PR}}$\end{document} as the number of neurons N\begin{document}$ N$\end{document} approaches infinity:limN→∞DPR(C)=E(σ2)2Ei≠j(Cij2)\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \lim_{N\to\infty}D_{\text{PR}}(C)=\frac{\mathrm{E}(\sigma^{2})^{2}}{\mathrm{E}_{i\neq j}(C_{ij}^{2})}$$\end{document}

This limit highlights the relationship between the PR dimension and the average squared covariance among different pairs of neurons. To predict how DPR\begin{document}$ D_{\text{PR}}$\end{document} scales with the number of neurons (Figure 2D), we first estimated these statistical quantities (Ei≠j(Cij2)\begin{document}$ \mathrm{E}_{i\neq j}(C_{ij}^{2})$\end{document}, E(σ2)\begin{document}$ \mathrm{E}(\sigma^{2})$\end{document}, and E(σ4)\begin{document}$ \mathrm{E}(\sigma^{4})$\end{document}) using all available neurons, then applied Equation 5 for different values of N\begin{document}$N$\end{document}. It is worth mentioning that a similar theoretical finding is established by Dahmen et al., 2020. The transition from increasing DPR\begin{document}$ D_{\text{PR}}$\end{document} with N\begin{document}$ N$\end{document} to approaching the saturation point occurs when N\begin{document}$ N$\end{document} is significantly larger than DPR\begin{document}$ D_{\text{PR}}$\end{document}.

sec.title: ERM model
sec.p: We consider the eigenvalue distribution or spectrum of the matrix C\begin{document}$ C$\end{document} at the limit of N≫1\begin{document}$ N\gg 1$\end{document} and L≫1\begin{document}$ L\gg 1$\end{document}. This spectrum can be analytically calculated in both high- and intermediate-density scenarios using the replica method (Mézard et al., 1999). The following sketch shows our approach, and detailed derivations can be found in Appendix 2. To calculate the probability density function of the eigenvalues (or eigendensity), we first compute the resolvent or Stieltjes transform g(z)=−2N∂z⟨ln⁡ det(zI−C)−1/2⟩\begin{document}$ g(z)=-\frac{2}{N}\partial_{z}\left\langle\ln\ \det(zI-C)^{-1/2}\right\rangle$\end{document}, z∈C\begin{document}$ z\in\mathbb{C}$\end{document}. Here, ⟨…⟩\begin{document}$ \left\langle\dots\right\rangle$\end{document} is the average across the realizations of C\begin{document}$ C$\end{document} (i.e., random x→i\begin{document}$ \vec{x}_{i}$\end{document}’ s and σi2\begin{document}$ \sigma_{i}^{2}$\end{document}’ s). The relationship between the resolvent and the eigendensity is given by the Sokhotski–Plemelj formula:(6)p(λ)=−1πlimη→0+Img(λ+iη),\begin{document}$$\displaystyle p(\lambda) = -\frac{1}{\pi}\lim\limits_{\eta \to 0^+}\mathbf{Im} \; g(\lambda+i\eta),$$\end{document}
where Im\begin{document}$ \mathbf{Im}$\end{document} means imaginary part.

Here we follow the field-theoretic approach (Mézard et al., 1999), which turns the problem of calculating the resolvent to a calculation of the partition function in statistical physics by using the replica method. In the limit N→∞\begin{document}$ N\to\infty$\end{document}, Ld→∞\begin{document}$ L^{d}\to\infty$\end{document}, ρ being finite, by performing a leading order expansion of the canonical partition function at large z\begin{document}$ z$\end{document} (Appendix 2), we find the resolvent is given by(7)g(z)=1ρ∫ddk→(2π)d1z−ρE(σ2)f~(k→)\begin{document}$$\displaystyle g(z) =\frac{1}{\rho}\int\frac{\mathrm{d}^d \vec{k}}{(2\pi)^d}\frac{1}{z-\rho \mathrm{E}(\sigma^2)\tilde f(\vec{k})}$$\end{document}

In the high-density regime, the probability density function (pdf) of the covariance eigenvalues can be approximated and expressed from Equations 6 and 7 using the Fourier transform of the kernel function f~(k→)\begin{document}$ \tilde{f}(\vec{k})$\end{document}:(8)p(λ)=1ρE(σ2)∫Rdddk→(2π)dδ(λE(σ2)−ρf~(k→)),\begin{document}$$\displaystyle p(\lambda) = \frac{1}{\rho \mathrm{E}(\sigma^2)}\int_{\mathbb{R}^d} \frac{\mathrm{d}^d\vec{k}}{(2\pi)^d}\delta\left(\frac{\lambda}{\mathrm{E}(\sigma^2)}-\rho \tilde f(\vec{k})\right),$$\end{document}

where δ(x)\begin{document}$ \delta(x)$\end{document} is the Dirac delta function and E(σ2)\begin{document}$ \mathrm{E}(\sigma^{2})$\end{document} is the expected value of the variances of neural activity. Intuitively, Equation 8 means that λ/ρ\begin{document}$ \lambda/\rho$\end{document} are distributed with a density proportional to the area of f~(k→)\begin{document}$ \tilde{f}(\vec{k})$\end{document}’ level sets (i.e., isosurfaces).

In Results, we found that the covariance matrix consistently shows greater scale invariance compared to the correlation matrix across all datasets. This suggests that the variability in neuronal activity significantly influences the eigenspectrum. This finding, however, cannot be explained by the high-density theory, which predicts that the eigenspectrum of the covariance matrix is simply a rescaling of the correlation eigenspectrum by E(σi2)\begin{document}$\mathrm{E}(\sigma_{i}^{2})$\end{document}, the expected value of the variances of neural activity. Without loss of generality, we can always standardize the fluctuation level of neural activity by setting E(σ2)=1\begin{document}$ \mathrm{E}(\sigma^{2})=1$\end{document}. This is equivalent to multiplying the covariance matrix C\begin{document}$ C$\end{document} by a constant such that Tr⁡(C)/N=1\begin{document}$ \operatorname{Tr}(C)/N=1$\end{document}, which in turn scales all the eigenvalues of C\begin{document}$ C$\end{document} by the same factor. Consequently, the heterogeneity of σi2\begin{document}$ \sigma_{i}^{2}$\end{document} has no effect on the scale invariance of the eigenspectrum (see Equation 8). This theoretical prediction is indeed correct and is confirmed by direct numerical simulations and quantifying the scale invariance using the CI (Figure 4—figure supplement 2A).

Fortunately, the inconsistency between theory and experimental results can be resolved by focusing the ERM within the intermediate density regime ρϵd≪1\begin{document}$ \rho\epsilon^{d}\ll 1$\end{document}, where neurons are positioned at a moderate distance from each other. As mentioned above, we set E(σ2)=1\begin{document}$ \mathrm{E}(\sigma^{2})=1$\end{document} in our model and vary the diversity of activity fluctuations among neurons represented by E(σ4)\begin{document}$ \mathrm{E}(\sigma^{4})$\end{document}. Consistent with the experimental observations, we find that the CI decreases with E(σ4)\begin{document}$\mathrm{E}(\sigma^{4})$\end{document} (see Figure 4—figure supplement 2B). This agreement indicates that the neural data are better explained by the ERM in the intermediate density regime.

To gain a deeper understanding of this behavior, we use the Gaussian variational method (Mézard et al., 1999) to calculate the eigenspectrum. Unlike the high-density theory where the eigendensity has an explicit expression, in the intermediate density the resolvent g(z)\begin{document}$ g(z)$\end{document} no longer has an explicit expression and is given by the following equation:(9)g(z)=⟨1z−σ2∫Dk→G~(k→,z)⟩σ,\begin{document}$$\displaystyle g(z) = \left\langle \frac{1}{z-\sigma^2 \int \mathrm{D} \vec{k} \; \tilde G(\vec{k},z)}\right\rangle_{\sigma}, $$\end{document}

where ⟨…⟩σ\begin{document}$ \langle\dots\rangle_{\sigma}$\end{document} computes the expectation value of the term within the bracket with respect to σ, namely ⟨…⟩σ≡∫…p(σ)dσ\begin{document}$ \langle\dots\rangle_{\sigma}\equiv\int\dots p(\sigma)\mathrm{d}\sigma$\end{document}. Here and in the following, we denote ∫Dk→≡∫ddk→(2π)d\begin{document}$ \int\mathrm{D}\vec{k}\equiv\int\frac{\mathrm{d}^{d}\vec{k}}{(2\pi)^{d}}$\end{document}. The function G(k→,z)\begin{document}$ G(\vec{k},z)$\end{document} is determined by a self-consistent equation,(10)1f~(k→)=1G~(k→,z)+⟨ρσ2z−σ2∫Dk→G~(k→,z)⟩σ\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \frac{1}{\tilde f(\vec{k})} = \frac{1}{\tilde G(\vec{k},z)} + \left\langle \frac{\rho \sigma^2}{z-\sigma^2\int \mathrm{D} \vec{k} \; \tilde G(\vec{k},z)} \right\rangle_{\sigma} $$\end{document}

We can solve ∫Dk→G(k→,z)\begin{document}$ \int\mathrm{D}\vec{k}\;G(\vec{k},z)$\end{document} from Equation 10 numerically and below is an outline, and the details are explained in Appendix 2. Let us define the integral G≡∫Dk→G~(k→,z)\begin{document}$ \mathcal{G}\equiv\int\mathrm{D}\vec{k}\;\tilde{G}(\vec{k},z)$\end{document}. First, we substitute z≡λ+iη\begin{document}$ z\equiv\lambda+i\eta$\end{document} into Equation 10 and write G=ReG+iImG\begin{document}$ \mathcal{G}=\mathbf{Re}\mathcal{G}+i\mathbf{Im}\mathcal{G}$\end{document}. Equation 10 can thus be decomposed into its real part and imaginary part, and a set of nonlinear and integral equations, each of which involves both ReG\begin{document}$ \mathbf{Re}\mathcal{G}$\end{document} and ImG\begin{document}$ \mathbf{Im}\mathcal{G}$\end{document}. We solve these equations at the limit η→0\begin{document}$ \eta\to 0$\end{document} using a fixed-point iteration that alternates between updating ReG\begin{document}$ \mathbf{Re}\mathcal{G}$\end{document} and ImG\begin{document}$ \mathbf{Im}\mathcal{G}$\end{document} until convergence.

We find that the variational approximations exhibit excellent agreement with the numerical simulation for both large and intermediate ρ where the high-density theory starts to deviate significantly (for ρ=256\begin{document}$ \rho=256$\end{document} and ρ=10.24\begin{document}$ \rho=10.24$\end{document}, ϵ=0.03125\begin{document}$ \epsilon=0.03125$\end{document}, Figure 4—figure supplement 1). Note that the departure of the leading eigenvalues in these plots is expected, since the power-law kernel function we use is not integrable (see Methods).

To elucidate the connection between the two different methods, we estimate the condition when the result of the high-density theory (Equation 8) matches that of the variational method (Equations 9 and 10; Appendix 2). The transition between these two density regimes can also be understood (see Equation 22 and Appendix 2).

Importantly, the scale invariance of the spectrum at μ/d→0\begin{document}$ \mu/d\rightarrow 0$\end{document} previously derived using the high-density result (Equation 3) can be extended to the intermediate-density regime by proving the ρ-independence using the variational method (Appendix 2).

Finally, using the variational method and the integration limit estimated by simulation (see Methods), we show that the heterogeneity of the variance of neural activity, quantified by E(σ4)\begin{document}$ \mathrm{E}(\sigma^{4})$\end{document}, indeed improves the collapse of the eigenspectra for intermediate ρ (Appendix 2). Our theoretical results agree excellently with the ERM simulation (Figure 4—figure supplement 2A, B).

sec.title: Kernel function
sec.p: Throughout the paper, we have mainly considered a particular approximate power-law kernel function inspired by the Student’s t distribution(11)f(x→)=ϵμ(ϵ2+‖x→‖2)−μ/2.\begin{document}$$\displaystyle f(\vec{x}) = \epsilon^\mu(\epsilon^2+\Vert \vec{x}\Vert^2)^{-\mu/2}.$$\end{document}

To understand how to choose ϵ\begin{document}$\epsilon$\end{document} and μ\begin{document}$\mu$\end{document}, see Methods. Variations of Equation 11 near x=0\begin{document}$ x=0$\end{document} have also been explored; see a summary in Table 3.

caption.title: Modifications of the shape of f(x→)\begin{document}$ f(\vec{x})$\end{document} near ‖x→‖=0\begin{document}$ \|\vec{x}\|=0$\end{document} used in Appendix 1—figures 1–3.
caption.p: Flat: when ‖x→‖<ϵ\begin{document}$ \|\vec{x}\| \lt \epsilon$\end{document}, f(x→)=1\begin{document}$ f(\vec{x})=1$\end{document}. Tangent: when ‖x→‖<cϵ\begin{document}$\|\vec{x}\| \lt c\epsilon$\end{document}, f(x→)\begin{document}$f(\vec{x})$\end{document} follows a tangent line of the exact power law (b‖x→‖+1\begin{document}$ b\|\vec{x}\|+1$\end{document} and ϵμ‖x→‖μ\begin{document}$ \frac{\epsilon^{\mu}}{\|\vec{x}\|^{\mu}}$\end{document} have a same first-order derivative when ‖x→‖=cϵ\begin{document}$ \|\vec{x}\|=c\epsilon$\end{document}). b and c are constants. Tent: when ‖x→‖<cϵ\begin{document}$ \|\vec{x}\| \lt c\epsilon$\end{document}, f(x→)\begin{document}$ f(\vec{x})$\end{document} follows a straight line while the slope is not the same as the tangent case. Parabola: when ‖x→‖<cϵ\begin{document}$ \|\vec{x}\| \lt c\epsilon$\end{document}, f(x→)\begin{document}$ f(\vec{x})$\end{document} follows a quadratic function (ax2+1\begin{document}$ ax^{2}+1$\end{document} and ϵμ‖x→‖μ\begin{document}$ \frac{\epsilon^{\mu}}{\|\vec{x}\|^{\mu}}$\end{document} have same first-order derivative). t pdf: mimic the smoothing treatment like the t distribution. All the constant parameters are set such that f(0)=1\begin{document}$ f(0)=1$\end{document}.

Tangent
