t pdf

sec.p: It is worth mentioning that a power law is not the only slow-decaying function that can produce a scale-invariant covariance spectrum (Figure 3—figure supplement 2). We choose it for its analytical tractability in calculating the eigenspectrum. Importantly, we find numerically that the two contributing factors to scale invariance – namely, slow spatial decay and higher functional space – can be generalized to other nonpower-law functions. An example is the stretched exponential function f(x→)=e−‖x→‖η\begin{document}$ f(\vec{x})=e^{-\|\vec{x}\|^{\eta}}$\end{document} with 0<η<1\begin{document}$ 0 \lt \eta \lt 1$\end{document}. When η\begin{document}$ \eta$\end{document} is small and d\begin{document}$ d$\end{document} is large, the covariance eigenspectra also display a similar collapse upon random sampling (Figure 3—figure supplement 2).

This approximate power-law f(x→)\begin{document}$ f(\vec{x})$\end{document} has the advantage of having an analytical expression for its Fourier transform, which is crucial for the high-density theory (Equation 8),(12)f(k→)=2d−μ+22πd2kμ−d2ϵμ+d2K(d−μ)/2(kϵ)Γ(μ/2),k=‖k→‖\begin{document}$$\displaystyle f(\vec{k}) = \frac{2^{\frac{d-\mu+2}{2}}\pi^{\frac{d}{2}} k^{\frac{\mu-d}{2}}\epsilon^{\frac{\mu+d}{2}}K_{(d-\mu)/2}(k\epsilon)}{\Gamma(\mu/2)},\;\; k = \|\vec k\|$$\end{document}

Here, Kα(x)\begin{document}$ K_{\alpha}(x)$\end{document} is the modified Bessel function of the second kind, and Γ(x)\begin{document}$ \Gamma(x)$\end{document} is the Gamma function. We calculated the above formulas analytically for d=1,2,3\begin{document}$ d=1,2,3$\end{document} with the assistance of Mathematica and conjectured the case for general dimension d\begin{document}$ d$\end{document}, which we confirmed numerically for d≤10\begin{document}$ d\leq 10$\end{document}.

We want to explain two technical points relevant to the interpretation of our numerical results and the choice of f(x→)\begin{document}$ f(\vec{x})$\end{document}. Unlike the case in the usual ERM, here we allow f(x→)\begin{document}$ f(\vec{x})$\end{document} to be non-integrable (over Rd\begin{document}$ \mathbb{R}^{d}$\end{document}), which is crucial to allow power law f(x→)\begin{document}$ f(\vec{x})$\end{document}. The nonintegrability violates a condition in the classical convergence results of the ERM spectrum (Bordenave, 2008) as N→∞\begin{document}$ N\rightarrow\infty$\end{document}. We believe that this is exactly the reason for the departure of the first few eigenvalues from our theoretical spectrum (e.g., in Figure 3). Our hypothesis is also supported by ERM simulations with integrable f(x→)\begin{document}$ f(\vec{x})$\end{document} (Figure 3—figure supplement 1), where the numerical eigenspectrum matches closely with our theoretical one, including the leading eigenvalues. For ERM to be a legitimate model for covariance matrices, we need to ensure that the resulting matrix C\begin{document}$ C$\end{document} is positive semidefinite. According to the Bochner theorem (Rudin, 1990), this is equivalent to the Fourier transform (FT) of the kernel function f~(k→)\begin{document}$ \tilde{f}(\vec{k})$\end{document} being nonnegative for all frequencies. For example, in 1D, a rectangle function rect⁡(x)={1,if|x|≤120,otherwise\begin{document}$\operatorname{rect}(x)=\begin{cases}1,&\text{if}\,|x|\leq\frac{1}{2}\\ 0,&\text{otherwise}\end{cases}$\end{document} does not meet the condition (its FT is sinc(x)=sin⁡(x)x\begin{document}$ \mathrm{sinc}(x)=\frac{\sin(x)}{x}$\end{document}), but a tent function tent⁡(x)={1−|x|, if |x|≤10,otherwise\begin{document}$ \operatorname{tent}(x)=\begin{cases}1-|x|,&\text{ if }|x|\leq 1\\ 0,&\text{otherwise}\end{cases}$\end{document} does (its FT is sinc2(x)\begin{document}$ \mathrm{sinc}^{2}(x)$\end{document}). For the particular kernel function f(x→)\begin{document}$ f(\vec{x})$\end{document} in Equation 11, this condition can be easily verified using the analytical expressions of its Fourier transform (Equation 12). The integral expression for Kα(x)\begin{document}$ K_{\alpha}(x)$\end{document}, given as Kα(x)=∫0∞e−xcosh⁡tcosh⁡(αt)dt\begin{document}$ K_{\alpha}(x)=\int_{0}^{\infty}e^{-x\cosh t}\cosh(\alpha t)dt$\end{document}, shows that Kα(x)\begin{document}$ K_{\alpha}(x)$\end{document} is positive for all x>0\begin{document}$ x \gt 0$\end{document}. Likewise, the Gamma function Γ(x)>0\begin{document}$ \Gamma(x) \gt 0$\end{document}. Therefore, the Fourier transform of Equation 11 is positive and the resulting matrix C\begin{document}$ C$\end{document} (of any size and values of x→i\begin{document}$ \vec{x}_{i}$\end{document}) is guaranteed to be positive definite.

Building upon the theory outlined above, numerical simulations further validated the empirical robustness of our ERM model, as showcased in Figures 3B–D–4A. In Figure 3B–D, the ERM was characterized by the parameters N=1024\begin{document}$ N=1024$\end{document}, d=2\begin{document}$ d=2$\end{document}, L=10\begin{document}$ L=10$\end{document}, ρ=10.24\begin{document}$ \rho=10.24$\end{document}, and μ=0.5\begin{document}$ \mu=0.5$\end{document} and ϵ=0.03125\begin{document}$ \epsilon=0.03125$\end{document} for f(x→)\begin{document}$ f(\vec{x})$\end{document}. To numerically compute the eigenvalue probability density function, we generated the ERM 100 times, each sampled using the method described in Methods. The pdf was computed by calculating the pdf of each ERM realization and averaging these across the instances. The curves in Figure 3D showed the average of over 100 ERM simulations. The shaded area (most of which is smaller than the marker size) represented the SEM. For Figure 4A, the columns from left to right were corresponded to μ=0.5,0.9,1.3\begin{document}$ \mu=0.5,0.9,1.3$\end{document}, and the rows from top to bottom were corresponded to d=1,2,3\begin{document}$ d=1,2,3$\end{document}. Other ERM simulation parameters: N=4096\begin{document}$ N=4096$\end{document}, ρ=256\begin{document}$ \rho=256$\end{document}, L=(N/ρ)1/d\begin{document}$L=(N/\rho)^{1/d}$\end{document}, ϵ=0.03125\begin{document}$ \epsilon=0.03125$\end{document}, and σi2=1\begin{document}$ \sigma_{i}^{2}=1$\end{document}. It should be noted that for Figure 4A, the presented data pertain to a single ERM realization.

sec.title: Collapse index
sec.p: We quantify the extent of scale invariance using CI defined as the area between two spectrum curves (Figure 4A, upper right), providing an intuitive measure of the shift of the eigenspectrum when varying the number of sampled neurons. We chose the CI over other measures of distance between distributions for several reasons. First, it directly quantifies the shift of the eigenspectrum, providing a clear and interpretable measure of scale invariance. Second, unlike methods that rely on estimating the full distribution, the CI avoids potential inaccuracies in estimating the probability of the top leading eigenvalues. Finally, the use of CI is motivated by theoretical considerations, namely the ERM in the high-density regime, which provides an analytical expression for the covariance spectrum (Equation 3) valid for large eigenvalues.(13)CI:=1log⁡(q0/q1)∫log⁡q1log⁡q0|∂log⁡λ(q)∂log⁡ρ|dlog⁡q,\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \mathrm{CI} := \frac{1}{\log (q_0/q_1)} \int_{\log q_1}^{\log q_0} \left| \frac{\partial \log \lambda(q)}{\partial\log \rho}\right| \mathrm{d} \log q, $$\end{document}

we set q1\begin{document}$ q_{1}$\end{document} such that λ(q1)=1\begin{document}$\lambda(q_{1})=1$\end{document}, which is the mean of the eigenvalues of a normalized covariance matrix. The other integration limit q0\begin{document}$ q_{0}$\end{document} is set to 0.01 such that λ(q0)\begin{document}$ \lambda(q_{0})$\end{document} is the 1% largest eigenvalue.
Here, we provide numerical details on calculating CI for the ERM simulations and experimental data.

sec.title: A calculation of CI for experimental datasets/ERM model
sec.p: To calculate CI for a covariance matrix C\begin{document}$ C$\end{document} of size N0\begin{document}$ N_{0}$\end{document}, we first computed its eigenvalues λi0\begin{document}$\lambda_{i}^{0}$\end{document} and those of the sampled block Cs\begin{document}$ C_{s}$\end{document} of size Ns=N0/2\begin{document}$ N_{s}=N_{0}/2$\end{document}, denoted as λis\begin{document}$\lambda_{i}^{s}$\end{document} (averaged over 20 times for the ERM simulation and 2000 times in experimental data). Next, we estimated log⁡λ(q)\begin{document}$ \log\lambda(q)$\end{document} using the eigenvalues of C0\begin{document}$ C_{0}$\end{document} and Cs\begin{document}$ C_{s}$\end{document} at q=i/Ns\begin{document}$ q=i/N_{s}$\end{document}, i=1,2,…,Ns\begin{document}$ i=1,2,\ldots,N_{s}$\end{document}. For the sampled Cs\begin{document}$ C_{s}$\end{document}, we simply had log⁡λ(q=i/Ns)=log⁡λis\begin{document}$ \log\lambda(q=i/N_{s})=\log\lambda^{s}_{i}$\end{document}, its ith largest eigenvalue. For the original C0\begin{document}$ C_{0}$\end{document}, log⁡λ(q=i/Ns)\begin{document}$ \log\lambda(q=i/N_{s})$\end{document} was estimated by a linear interpolation, on the log⁡λ−log⁡q\begin{document}$\log \lambda - \log q $\end{document} scale, using the value of log⁡λ(q)\begin{document}$ \log\lambda(q)$\end{document} in the nearest neighboring q=i/N0\begin{document}$ q=i/N_{0}$\end{document}’s (which again are simply log⁡λi0\begin{document}$ \log\lambda_{i}^{0}$\end{document}). Finally, the integral (Equation 13) was computed using the trapezoidal rule, discretized at q=i/Ns\begin{document}$ q=i/N_{s}$\end{document}’s, using the finite difference ∂log⁡λ(q)∂log⁡ρ≈1log⁡(N0/Ns)|Δlog⁡λ(q)|\begin{document}$ \frac{\partial\log\lambda(q)}{\partial\log\rho}\approx\frac{1}{\log(N_{0}/N_{s })}\left|\Delta\log\lambda(q)\right|$\end{document}, where Δ\begin{document}$\Delta$\end{document} denotes the difference between the original eigenvalues of C0\begin{document}$ C_{0}$\end{document} and those of sampled Cs\begin{document}$ C_{s}$\end{document}.

sec.title: Estimating CI using the variational method
sec.p: In the definition of CI (Equation 13), calculating λ(q)\begin{document}$\lambda(q)$\end{document} and ∂log⁡λ(q)∂log⁡ρ\begin{document}$ \frac{\partial\log\lambda(q)}{\partial\log\rho}$\end{document} directly using the variational method is difficult, but we can make use of an implicit differentiation(14)∂log⁡λ(q,ρ)∂log⁡ρ=ρλ∂λ(q,ρ)∂ρ=−ρλ∂q(ρ,λ)∂ρ∂q(ρ,λ)∂λ,\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \frac{\partial \log \lambda(q, \rho)}{\partial\log \rho} = \frac{\rho}{\lambda} \frac{\partial \lambda(q, \rho)}{\partial \rho} = - \frac{\rho}{\lambda} \frac{\frac{\partial q(\rho,\lambda)}{\partial \rho} }{\frac{\partial q(\rho,\lambda)}{\partial \lambda}},$$\end{document}

where q(λ):=∫λ∞p(λ)dλ\begin{document}$ q(\lambda):=\int_{\lambda}^{\infty}p(\lambda)\mathrm{d}\lambda$\end{document} is the complementary cdf (the inverse function of λ(q)\begin{document}$ \lambda(q)$\end{document} in Methods). Using this, the integral in CI (Equation 13) can be rewritten as(15)∫log⁡q1log⁡q0|∂log⁡λ(q,ρ)∂log⁡ρ|dlog⁡q=∫q1q0|−ρqλ∂q∂ρ∂q∂λ|dq=∫λ(q1)λ(q0)|−ρqλ∂q∂ρy∂q∂λ|∂q∂λdλ=∫λ(q0)λ(q1)|1λ∂log⁡q∂log⁡ρ|dλ.\begin{document}$$\begin{aligned} & \displaystyle \int_{\log q_1}^{\log q_0} \left| \frac{\partial \log \lambda(q,\rho)}{\partial\log \rho}\right| \mathrm{d} \log q = \int_{q_1}^{q_0} \left| - \frac{\rho}{q \lambda} \frac{\frac{\partial q}{\partial \rho} }{\frac{\partial q}{\partial \lambda}} \right| \mathrm{d} q \\ =& \, \displaystyle \int_{\lambda(q_1)}^{\lambda(q_0)} \left| - \frac{\rho}{q \lambda} \frac{\frac{\partial q}{\partial \rho} y}{\frac{\partial q}{\partial \lambda}} \right |\frac{\partial q}{\partial \lambda} \mathrm{d} \lambda = \int_{\lambda(q_0)}^{\lambda(q_1)} \left| \frac{1}{ \lambda} \frac{\partial \log q}{\partial \log \rho} \right| \mathrm{d} \lambda.\end{aligned}$$\end{document}
Since ∂q∂λ=−p(λ)<0\begin{document}$ \frac{\partial q}{\partial\lambda}=-p(\lambda) \lt 0$\end{document}, we switch the order of the integration interval in the final expression of Equation 15.

First, we explain how to compute the complementary cdf q(λ)\begin{document}$ q(\lambda)$\end{document} numerically using the variational method. The key is to integrate the probability density function p(λ)\begin{document}$ p(\lambda)$\end{document} from λ to a finite λ(qs)\begin{document}$ \lambda(q_{s})$\end{document} rather than to infinity,(16)q(λ)=∫λ∞p(λ)dλ=∫λ(qs)∞p(λ)dλ+∫λλ(qs)p(λ)dλ=qs+∫λλ(qs)p(λ)dλ.\begin{document}$$\displaystyle q(\lambda) = \int_{\lambda}^{\infty} p(\lambda) \mathrm{d} \lambda = \int_{\lambda(q_s)}^{\infty} p(\lambda) \mathrm{d} \lambda + \int_{\lambda}^{\lambda(q_s)} p(\lambda) \mathrm{d} \lambda = q_s + \int_{\lambda}^{\lambda(q_s)} p(\lambda) \mathrm{d} \lambda.$$\end{document}

The integration limit λ(qs)\begin{document}$\lambda(q_{s})$\end{document} cannot be calculated directly using the variational method. We thus used the value of λs(qs≈q0)\begin{document}$ \lambda^{s}(q_{s}\approx q_{0})$\end{document} (Methods) from simulations of the ERM with a large N=1024\begin{document}$ N=1024$\end{document} as an approximation. Furthermore, we employed a smoothing technique to reduce bias in the estimation of λs(qs)\begin{document}$ \lambda^{s}(q_{s})$\end{document} due to the leading zigzag eigenvalues (i.e., the largest eigenvalues) of the eigenspectrum. Specifically, we determined the nearest rank j<Nq0\begin{document}$ j \lt Nq_{0}$\end{document} and then smoothed the eigenvalue log⁡λs(qs)\begin{document}$ \log\lambda^{s}(q_{s})$\end{document} on the log–log scale using the formula log⁡λs(qs)=13∑i=02log⁡λs(j+iN)\begin{document}$ \log\lambda^{s}(q_{s})=\frac{1}{3}\sum\limits_{i=0}^{2}\log\lambda^{s}(\frac{j +i}{N})$\end{document} and log⁡qs=13∑i=02log⁡j+iN\begin{document}$ \log q_{s}=\frac{1}{3}\sum\limits_{i=0}^{2}\log\frac{j+i}{N}$\end{document}, averaging over 100 ERM simulations.

Note that we can alternatively use the high-density theory (Appendix 2) to compute the integration limit λ(qs=1/N)\begin{document}$ \lambda(q_{s}=1/N)$\end{document} instead of resorting to simulations. However, since the true value deviates from the λh(qs=1/N)\begin{document}$ \lambda^{h}(q_{s}=1/N)$\end{document} derived from high-density theory, this approach introduces a constant bias (Figure 4—figure supplement 2) when computing the integral in Equation 16. Therefore we used the simulation value λs(qs≈q0)\begin{document}$ \lambda^{s}(q_{s}\approx q_{0})$\end{document} when producing Figure 4—figure supplement 2AB.

Next, we describe how each term within the integral of Equation 15 was numerically estimated. First, we calculated ∂log⁡q∂log⁡ρ\begin{document}$ \frac{\partial\log q}{\partial\log\rho}$\end{document} with a similar method described in Methods. Briefly, we calculated q0(λ)\begin{document}$q_{0}(\lambda)$\end{document} for density ρ0=N0Ld\begin{document}$\rho_{0}=\frac{N_{0}}{L^{d}}$\end{document} and qs(λ)\begin{document}$ q_{s}(\lambda)$\end{document} for density ρs=NsLd\begin{document}$ \rho_{s}=\frac{N_{s}}{L^{d}}$\end{document}, and then used the finite difference 1log⁡(ρ0/ρs)|Δlog⁡q(λ)|\begin{document}$ \frac{1}{\log(\rho_{0}/\rho_{s})}\left|\Delta\log q(\lambda)\right|$\end{document}. Second, ∂log⁡q(λ)∂log⁡ρ\begin{document}$ \frac{\partial\log q(\lambda)}{\partial\log\rho}$\end{document} was evaluated at λ=λ(q1)+iλ(q0)−λ(q1)k−1\begin{document}$ \lambda=\lambda(q_{1})+i\frac{\lambda(q_{0})-\lambda(q_{1})}{k-1}$\end{document}, where i=0,1,2,…,k−1\begin{document}$ i=0,1,2,\ldots,k-1$\end{document}, and we used k=20\begin{document}$ k=20$\end{document}. Finally, we performed a cubic spline interpolation of the term ∂log⁡q∂log⁡ρ\begin{document}$\frac{\partial\log q}{\partial\log\rho}$\end{document}, and obtained the theoretical CI by an integration of Equation 15. Figure 4—figure supplement 2A, B shows a comparison between theoretical CI and that obtained by numerical simulations of ERM (Methods).

sec.title: Estimating the ERM parameters
sec.p: Our ERM model has four parameters: μ\begin{document}$\mu$\end{document} and ϵ\begin{document}$\epsilon$\end{document} dictate the kernel function f(x→)\begin{document}$ f(\vec{x})$\end{document}, whereas the box size L\begin{document}$ L$\end{document} and the embedding dimension d\begin{document}$ d$\end{document} determine the neuronal density ρ\begin{document}$\rho$\end{document}. In the following, we describe an approximate method to estimate these parameters from pairwise correlations measured experimentally Rij=Cijσiσj\begin{document}$ R_{ij}=\frac{C_{ij}}{\sigma_{i}\sigma_{j}}$\end{document}. We proceed by deriving a relationship between the correlation probability density distribution h(R)\begin{document}$ h(R)$\end{document} and the pairwise distance probability density distribution g(u):=g(‖x→1−x→2‖)\begin{document}$ g(u):=g(\|\vec{x}_{1}-\vec{x}_{2}\|)$\end{document} in the functional space, from which the parameters of the ERM can be estimated.

Consider a distribution of neurons in the functional space with a coordinate distribution p(x→)\begin{document}$ p(\vec{x})$\end{document}. The pairwise distance density function g(u)\begin{document}$ g(u)$\end{document} is related to the spatial point density by the following formula:(17)g(u)=∫[0,L]dp(x→1)p(x→2)δ(‖x→1−x→2‖−u)dx→1dx→2\begin{document}$$\displaystyle g(u) = \int_{[0,L]^d} p(\vec{x}_1)p(\vec{x}_2)\delta(\Vert \vec{x}_1 -\vec{x}_2\Vert - u) \mathrm{d} \vec{x}_1\mathrm{d} \vec{x}_2$$\end{document}

For ease of notation, we subsequently omit the region of integration, which is the same as here. In the case of a uniform distribution, p(x→1)=p(x→2)=1/V=1/Ld\begin{document}$ p(\vec{x}_{1})=p(\vec{x}_{2})=1/V=1/L^{d}$\end{document}. For other spatial distributions, Equation 17 cannot be explicitly evaluated. We therefore make a similar approximation by focusing on a small pairwise distance (i.e., large correlation):(18)p(x→1)≈p(x→2)≈p(x→1+x→22)\begin{document}$$\displaystyle p(\vec{x}_1) \approx p(\vec{x}_2) \approx p(\frac{\vec{x}_1 + \vec{x}_2}{2})$$\end{document}
By a change of variables:X→=x→1+x→22,u→=x→1−x→2,\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \vec{X}=\frac{\vec{x}_{1}+\vec{x}_{2}}{2},\,\,\,\,\vec{u}=\vec{x}_{1}-\vec{x}_{2},$$\end{document}

Equation 17 can be rewritten as(19)g(u)≈∫p2(X→)δ(‖u→‖−u)dX→du→=Sd−1(u)∫p2(X→)dX→\begin{document}$$\displaystyle g(u) \approx \int p^2(\vec{X})\delta(\Vert \vec{u}\Vert - u) \mathrm{d} \vec{X}\mathrm{d} \vec{u}= S_{d-1}(u) \int p^2(\vec{X}) \mathrm{d} \vec{X}$$\end{document}

where Sd−1(u)\begin{document}$ S_{d-1}(u)$\end{document} is the surface area of d−1\begin{document}$ d-1$\end{document} sphere with radius u. Note that the approximation of g(u)\begin{document}$ g(u)$\end{document} is not normalized to 1, as Equation 19 provides an approximation valid only for small pairwise distances (i.e., large correlation). Therefore, we believe this does not pose an issue.

With the approximate power-law kernel function R=f(u)≈(ϵu)μ\begin{document}$ R=f(u)\approx(\frac{\epsilon}{u})^{\mu}$\end{document}, the probability density function of pairwise correlation h(R)\begin{document}$ h(R)$\end{document} is given by:(20)h(R)=g(u)|dudR|=2πd2ϵdΓ(d2)μR(μ+d)/μ∫p2(X→)dX→\begin{document}$$\displaystyle h(R) = g(u) \left\vert \frac{\mathrm{d} u}{\mathrm{d} R} \right\vert=\frac{2\pi^{\frac{d}{2}} \epsilon^d}{\Gamma(\frac{d}{2}) \mu R^{(\mu+d)/\mu}} \int p^2(\vec{X}) \mathrm{d} \vec{X}$$\end{document}

Taking the logarithm on both sides(21)log⁡h(R)=log⁡(ϵd∫p2(X→)dX→)+log⁡2πd2Γ(d2)μ−μ+dμlog⁡R\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \log{h(R)} =\log\left(\epsilon^d \int p^2(\vec{X}) \mathrm{d} \vec{X}\right) +\log{\frac{2\pi^{\frac{d}{2}}}{\Gamma(\frac{d}{2}) \mu}} - \frac{\mu+d}{\mu}\log{R}$$\end{document}

Equation 21 is the key formula for ERM parameters estimation. In the case of a uniform spatial distribution, ϵd∫p2(X→)dX→=ϵd/V=(ϵ/L)d\begin{document}$\epsilon^{d}\int p^{2}(\vec{X})\mathrm{d}\vec{X}=\epsilon^{d}/V=(\epsilon/L)^{d}$\end{document}. For a given dimension d\begin{document}$ d$\end{document}, we can therefore estimate μ\begin{document}$\mu$\end{document} and (ϵ/L)d\begin{document}$ (\epsilon/L)^{d}$\end{document} separately by fitting h(R)\begin{document}$ h(R)$\end{document} on the log–log scale using the linear least squares. Lastly, we fit the distribution of σ2\begin{document}$ \sigma^{2}$\end{document} (the diagonal entries of the covariance matrix C\begin{document}$ C$\end{document}) to a log-normal distribution by estimating the maximum likelihood.

There is a redundancy between the unit of the functional space (using a rescaled ϵδ≡ϵ/δ\begin{document}$\epsilon_{\delta}\equiv\epsilon/\delta$\end{document}) and the unit of f(x→)\begin{document}$ f(\vec{x})$\end{document} (using a rescaled fδ(x→)≡f(x→/δ)\begin{document}$ f_{\delta}(\vec{x})\equiv f(\vec{x}/\delta)$\end{document}), thus ϵ\begin{document}$\epsilon$\end{document} and L\begin{document}$ L$\end{document} are a pair of redundant parameters: once ε is given, L\begin{document}$ L$\end{document} is also determined. We set ϵ=0.03125\begin{document}$ \epsilon=0.03125$\end{document} throughout the article. In summary, for a given dimension d\begin{document}$ d$\end{document} and ϵ\begin{document}$\epsilon$\end{document}, μ\begin{document}$\mu$\end{document} of f(x→)\begin{document}$ f(\vec{x})$\end{document} (Equation 11), the distribution of σ2\begin{document}$ \sigma^{2}$\end{document} and ρ\begin{document}$\rho$\end{document} (or equivalently L\begin{document}$ L$\end{document}) can be fitted by comparing the distribution of pairwise correlations in experimental data and ERM. Furthermore, knowing (ϵ/L)d\begin{document}$ (\epsilon/L)^{d}$\end{document} enables us to determine a fundamental dimensionless parameter(22)ρϵd:=N(ϵ/L)d,\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \rho \epsilon^d := N(\epsilon/L)^d,$$\end{document}

which tells us whether the experimental data are better described by the high-density theory or the Gaussian variational method (Appendix 2). Indeed, the fitted ρϵd∼10−3−100\begin{document}$ \rho\epsilon^{d}\sim 10^{-3}-10^{0}$\end{document} is much smaller than 1, consistent with our earlier conclusion that neural data are better described by an ERM model in the intermediate-density regime.

Notably, we found that a smaller embedding dimension d≤5\begin{document}$ d\leq 5$\end{document} gave a better fit to the overall pairwise correlation distribution. The following is an empirical explanation. As d\begin{document}$ d$\end{document} grows, to best fit the slope of log⁡h(R)−log⁡R\begin{document}$ \log h(R)-\log R$\end{document}, μ\begin{document}$\mu$\end{document} will also grow. However, for very high dimensions d\begin{document}$ d$\end{document}, the y-intercept would become very negative, or equivalently, the fitted correlation would become extremely small. This can be verified by examining the leading order log⁡R\begin{document}$ \log R$\end{document} independent term in Equation 21, which can be approximated as dlog⁡ϵL+d2(log⁡π+1−log⁡d2)\begin{document}$ d\log\frac{\epsilon}{L}+\frac{d}{2}\left(\log\pi+1-\log\frac{d}{2}\right)$\end{document}. It becomes very negative for large d\begin{document}$ d$\end{document} since ϵ≪L\begin{document}$ \epsilon\ll L$\end{document} by construction. Throughout this article, we use d=2\begin{document}$ d=2$\end{document} when fitting the experimental data with our ERM model.

The above calculation can be extended to the cases where the coordinate distribution p(x→)\begin{document}$ p(\vec{x})$\end{document} becomes dependent on other parameters. To estimate the parameters in coordinate distributions that can generate ERMs with a similar pairwise correlation distribution (Appendix 1—figure 1), we fixed the integral value ∫p2(x→)dx→\begin{document}$ \int p^{2}(\vec{x})\mathrm{d}\vec{x}$\end{document}. Consider, for example, a transformation of the uniform coordinate distribution to the normal distribution N(μp=0,σp2I)\begin{document}$ \mathcal{N}(\mu_{p}=0,\sigma^{2}_{p}\mathbf{I})$\end{document} in R2\begin{document}$ \mathbb{R}^{2}$\end{document}. We imposed ∫p2(x→)dx→=1/(4πσp2)=1/L2\begin{document}$ \int p^{2}(\vec{x})\mathrm{d}\vec{x}=1/(4\pi\sigma^{2}_{p})=1/L^{2}$\end{document}. For the log-normal distribution, a similar calculation led to Lexp⁡(σp2/4−μp)=2πσp\begin{document}$L\exp(\sigma_{p}^{2}/4-\mu_{p})=2\sqrt{\pi}\sigma_{p}$\end{document}. The numerical values for these parameters are shown in Appendix 1. However, note that due to the approximation we used (Equation 18), our estimate of the ERM parameters becomes less accurate if the density function p(x→)\begin{document}$ p(\vec{x})$\end{document} changes rapidly over a short distance in the functional space. More sophisticated methods, such as grid search, may be needed to tackle such a scenario.

After determining the parameters of the ERM, we first examine the spectrum of the ERM with uniformly distributed random functional coordinates x→i∈[0,L]d\begin{document}$\vec{x}_{i}\in[0,L]^{d}$\end{document} (Figure 5—figure supplement 1M–R). Second, we use f(x→)\begin{document}$ f(\vec{x})$\end{document} to translate experimental pairwise correlations into pairwise distances for all neurons in the functional space (Figure 5—figure supplement 2, Figure 5—figure supplement 1G–L). The embedding coordinates x→i\begin{document}$ \vec{x}_{i}$\end{document} in the functional space can then be solved through multidimensional scaling (MDS) by minimizing the Sammon error (Methods). The similarity between the spectra of the uniformly distributed coordinates (Figure 5—figure supplement 1M–R) and those of the embedding coordinates (Figure 5—figure supplement 1G–L) is also consistent with the notion that specific coordinate distributions in the functional space have little impact on the shape of the eigenspectrum (Appendix 1—figure 1).

sec.title: Nonnegativity of data covariance
sec.p: To use ERM to model the covariance matrix, the pairwise correlation is given by a non-negative kernel function f(x→)\begin{document}$ f(\vec{x})$\end{document} that monotonically decreases with the distance between neurons in the functional space. This nonnegativeness brings about a potential issue when applied to experimental data, where, in fact, a small fraction of pairwise correlations/covariances are negative. We have verified that the spectrum of the data covariance matrix (Figure 2—figure supplement 3) remains virtually unchanged when replacing these negative covariances with zero (Figure 2—figure supplement 3). This confirms that the ERM remains a good model when the neural dynamics is in a regime where pairwise covariances are mostly positive Dahmen et al., 2019 (see also Figure 2—figure supplement 2B, Figure 2—figure supplement 2B–D).

sec.title: Multidimensional scaling
sec.p: With the estimated ERM parameters (μ\begin{document}$\mu$\end{document} in f(x→)\begin{document}$ f(\vec{x})$\end{document} and the box size L\begin{document}$ L$\end{document} for given ϵ\begin{document}$\epsilon$\end{document} and d\begin{document}$ d$\end{document}, see Methods), we performed MDS to infer neuronal coordinates x→i\begin{document}$ \vec{x}_{i}$\end{document} in functional space. First, we computed a pairwise correlation Rij=Cijσiσj\begin{document}$ R_{ij}=\frac{C_{ij}}{\sigma_{i}\sigma_{j}}$\end{document} from the data covariances. Next, we calculated the pairwise distance, denoted by uij∗\begin{document}$ u^{*}_{ij}$\end{document}, by computing the inverse function of f(x→)\begin{document}$ f(\vec{x})$\end{document} with respect to the absolute value of Rij\begin{document}$ R_{ij}$\end{document}, uij∗=f−1(|Rij|)\begin{document}$ u^{*}_{ij}=f^{-1}(|R_{ij}|)$\end{document}. We used the absolute value |Rij|\begin{document}$ |R_{ij}|$\end{document} instead of Rij\begin{document}$ R_{ij}$\end{document} as a small percentage of Rij\begin{document}$ R_{ij}$\end{document} are negative (Figure 2—figure supplement 2A–D) where the distance is undefined. This substitution by the absolute value serves as a simple workaround for the issue and is only used here in the analysis to infer the neuronal coordinates by MDS. Finally, we estimated the embedding coordinates x→i\begin{document}$ \vec{x}_{i}$\end{document} for each neuron by the SMACOF algorithm (Scaling by MAjorizing a COmplicated Function), which minimizes the Sammon error(23)E=1∑i<juij∗∑i<j(uij∗−uij)2uij∗\begin{document}$$\displaystyle E = \frac{1}{\sum\limits_{i \lt j} u^*_{ij}} \sum\limits_{i \lt j} \frac{(u^*_{ij} - u_{ij})^2}{u^*_{ij}} $$\end{document}

where uij=‖x→i−x→j‖\begin{document}$ u_{ij}=\|\vec{x}_{i}-\vec{x}_{j}\|$\end{document} is the pairwise distance in the embedding space calculated above. To reduce errors at large distances (i.e., small correlations with Rij<f(L)\begin{document}$ R_{ij} \lt f(L)$\end{document}, where L\begin{document}$ L$\end{document} is the estimated box size), we performed a soft cut-off at a large distance:(24)uij∗=f−1(|Rij|),Rij≥f(L)uij∗=Llog⁡(f−1(|Rij|)/L)+L,Rij<f(L)\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \begin{array}{ll} \displaystyle u^*_{ij} = f^{-1}(|R_{ij}|), & R_{ij} \ge f(L) \\ \displaystyle u^*_{ij} = L \log(f^{-1}(|R_{ij}|)/L) + L, & R_{ij} \lt f(L)\end{array}$$\end{document}

During the optimization process, we started at the embedding coordinates estimated by the classical MDS (Cox and Cox, 2000), with an initial sum of squares distance error that can be calculated directly, and ended with an error or its gradient smaller than 10−4.

The fitted ERM with the embedding coordinates x→i\begin{document}$\vec{x}_{i}$\end{document} reproduced the experimental covariance matrix including the cluster structures (Figure 5—figure supplement 2) and its sampling eigenspectra (Figure 5—figure supplement 1).

sec.title: Canonical correlation analysis
sec.p: Here we briefly explain the CCA method (Knapp, 1978) for completeness. The basis vectors v→func\begin{document}$ \vec{v}_{\text{func}}$\end{document} and v→anat\begin{document}$ \vec{v}_{\text{anat}}$\end{document}, in functional and anatomical space, respectively, were found by maximizing the correlation RCCA=corr({v→func⋅x→i},{v→anat⋅y→i})\begin{document}$ R_{\text{CCA}}=corr(\{\vec{v}_{\text{func}}\cdot\vec{x}_{i}\},\{\vec{v}_{\text {anat}}\cdot\vec{y}_{i}\})$\end{document}. These basis vectors satisfy the condition that the projections of the neuron coordinates along them, {x→i⋅v→func}\begin{document}$ \{\vec{x}_{i}\cdot\vec{v}_{\text{func}}\}$\end{document} and {y→i⋅v→anat}\begin{document}$ \{\vec{y}_{i}\cdot\vec{v}_{\text{anat}}\}$\end{document}, are maximally correlated among all possible choices of v→func\begin{document}$ \vec{v}_{\text{func}}$\end{document} and v→anat\begin{document}$ \vec{v}_{\text{anat}}$\end{document}. Here, {x→i}\begin{document}$ \{\vec{x}_{i}\}$\end{document}, {y→i}\begin{document}$ \{\vec{y}_{i}\}$\end{document} represent the coordinates in functional and anatomical spaces, respectively. The resulting maximum correlation is RCCA\begin{document}$ R_{\text{CCA}}$\end{document}. To check the significance of the canonical correlation, we shuffled the functional space coordinates {x→i}\begin{document}$ \{\vec{x}_{i}\}$\end{document} across neurons’ identity and re-calculated the canonical correlation with the anatomical coordinates, as shown in Figure 5—figure supplement 4.

To study the effect of functional–anatomical relation described by RCCA\begin{document}$ R_{\text{CCA}}$\end{document} in the ERM model, we generated three-dimensional anatomical coordinates {y→i}\begin{document}$ \{\vec{y}_{i}\}$\end{document} and two-dimensional functional coordinates {x→i}\begin{document}$ \{\vec{x}_{i}\}$\end{document} for each neuron which are jointly five-dimensional zero-mean multivariate Gaussian random variables. The coordinates are independent among each other, except for the first dimension {x→i1}\begin{document}$\{\vec{x}^{1}_{i}\}$\end{document} of the functional coordinates and the first dimension {y→i1}\begin{document}$\{\vec{y}^{1}_{i}\}$\end{document}, which are assigned to have a correlation coefficient equals to RCCA\begin{document}$ R_{\text{CCA}}$\end{document}. The variances of the coordinates are σy12=1,σy22=1,σy32=1\begin{document}$ \sigma^{2}_{y1}=1,\sigma^{2}_{y2}=1,\sigma^{2}_{y3}=1$\end{document}, and σx12=2,σx22=1\begin{document}$ \sigma^{2}_{x1}=2,\sigma^{2}_{x2}=1$\end{document} for the numerics in Figure 5—figure supplement 7. Under this construction, the first canonical correlation between the anatomical and functional coordinates equals RCCA\begin{document}$ R_{\text{CCA}}$\end{document}, and the first canonical direction v→anat\begin{document}$ \vec{v}_{\text{anat}}$\end{document} in the anatomical space is (1,0,0)T\begin{document}$ (1,0,0)^{T}$\end{document} and the first canonical direction v→func\begin{document}$ \vec{v}_{\text{func}}$\end{document} in the functional space is (1,0)T\begin{document}$ (1,0)^{T}$\end{document}.

sec.title: Spectrum of three types of sampling procedures in ERM model
sec.p: In Result, we have considered three types of sampling procedures: random sampling (RSap), spatial sampling in the anatomical space (ASap, e.g., recording neurons in a brain region), and spatial sampling in the functional space (FSap), namely spatial sampling in functional space by subdividing the space into smaller regions, is equivalent to the previously reported RG inspired process (Bradde and Bialek, 2017). Here, we consider the relationship between the spectrum of three types of sampling procedures.

We assume a uniform random distribution of neurons in a d\begin{document}$ d$\end{document}-dimensional functional space, [0,L]d\begin{document}$ [0,L]^{d}$\end{document}. For RSap procedures, the resulting neuronal density ρR\begin{document}$ \rho_{R}$\end{document} is reduced to ρR=kρ0\begin{document}$ \rho_{R}=k\rho_{0}$\end{document}, with k\begin{document}$ k$\end{document} representing the sampling ratio (k=N/N0\begin{document}$ k=N/N_{0}$\end{document}) and ρ0\begin{document}$ \rho_{0}$\end{document} being the initial density. In contrast, FSap maintains the original density, ρF=ρ0\begin{document}$ \rho_{F}=\rho_{0}$\end{document}. This constancy in neuronal density under FSap ensures that the covariance eigenspectrum remains invariant across scales for any spatial correlation functions f(x→)\begin{document}$ f(\vec{x})$\end{document}, such as power law and exponential, as shown in Appendix 1—figure 5A, B, D, E. In contrast, RSap reduces ρ, thus demanding more rigorous conditions to achieve a scale-invariant covariance spectrum (e.g., compare Appendix 1—figure 5A, C).

Under ASap, sampled neurons are not spread out evenly in functional space, whereas our theoretical framework assumes a uniform distribution. To reconcile this discrepancy, we employ a uniform approximation of the neural distribution. This approach involves introducing an effective density, ρ′\begin{document}$\rho^{\prime}$\end{document}, defined as the spatial average of the density function ρ(x→)\begin{document}$ \rho(\vec{x})$\end{document}. This adjustment allows our theoretical model to accommodate non-uniform distributions encountered in anatomically spatial sampling.(25)ρ′≡⟨ρ(x→)⟩=∫p(x→)ρ(x→)dx→=kN0∫p2(x→)dx→,\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \rho' \equiv \langle \rho(\vec{x}) \rangle = \int p(\vec{x})\rho(\vec{x}) \mathrm{d} \vec{x} = kN_0\int p^2(\vec{x}) \mathrm{d} \vec{x},$$\end{document}
where p(x→)\begin{document}$ p(\vec{x})$\end{document} is the normalized density distribution (see Methods).

Using the Cauchy–Schwarz inequality, we have(26)∫p2(x→)dx→∫dx→≥(∫p(x→)dx→)2\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \int p^2(\vec{x}) \mathrm{d} \vec{x} \int \mathrm{d} \vec{x} \geq (\int p(\vec{x}) \mathrm{d} \vec{x})^2$$\end{document}
thus ρ′≥kρ0\begin{document}$ \rho^{\prime}\geq k\rho_{0}$\end{document}.

According to the condition p(x→)<1kV\begin{document}$ p(\vec{x}) \lt \frac{1}{kV}$\end{document}, we have ρ′≤ρ0\begin{document}$ \rho^{\prime}\leq\rho_{0}$\end{document}, intuitively, sampling within a uniformly distributed neuron population does not increase the density.

So we have ρ0≥ρA′≥kρ0\begin{document}$ \rho_{0}\geq\rho^{\prime}_{A}\geq k\rho_{0}$\end{document}, that is, ρF≥ρA′≥ρR\begin{document}$ \rho_{F}\geq\rho^{\prime}_{A}\geq\rho_{R}$\end{document}. Thus, the spectrum ASap should be between FSap and RSap.

sec.title: Dimensions of three types of sampling procedures in ERM model
Scaling of dimensions through random sampling
sec.p: Let us revisit the definition of the participation ratio (PR) dimension as defined in Equation 5:(27)DPR(C)=(∑iλi)2∑iλi2=(Tr(C))2Tr(C2)=N2E(σ2)2NE(σ4)+N(N−1)Ei≠j(Cij2)\begin{document}$$\displaystyle D_{\text{PR}}(C) = \frac{\left(\sum_i \lambda_i\right)^2}{\sum_i \lambda_i^2} = \frac{\left(\mathrm{Tr}(C)\right)^2}{\mathrm{Tr}(C^2)} = \frac{N^2\mathrm{E}(\sigma^2)^2}{N \mathrm{E}(\sigma^4) + N(N-1)\mathrm{E}_{i \neq j}(C_{ij}^2)}$$\end{document}

During the random sampling process, the expected values E(σ2)\begin{document}$ E(\sigma^{2})$\end{document}, E(σ4)\begin{document}$ E(\sigma^{4})$\end{document}, and Ei≠j(Cij2)\begin{document}$ \mathrm{E}_{i\neq j}(C_{ij}^{2})$\end{document} remain constant. These constants allow for the estimation of the PR dimension across various scales using:(28)DPRRSap=kN0E(σ2)2E(σ4)+(kN0−1)Ei≠j(Cij2)\begin{document}$$\displaystyle D_{\text{PR}}^{\text{RSap}} = \frac{kN_0 \mathrm{E}(\sigma^2)^2}{\mathrm{E}(\sigma^4) + (kN_0-1)\mathrm{E}_{i \neq j}(C_{ij}^2)}$$\end{document}

Here, k=N/N0\begin{document}$ k=N/N_{0}$\end{document} represents a scaling factor (fraction) associated with sampling. The key question is to understand how the dimensionality changes with k\begin{document}$ k$\end{document}. Under random sampling, as k\begin{document}$ k$\end{document} increases, the dimensionality will quickly approaches a saturating point defined by Equation 1.

sec.title: Scaling of dimensions through functional sampling
sec.p:
In this section, we leverage the uniform ERM model to estimate dimensions within the context of functional sampling, specifically focusing on the estimation of squared pairwise covariance Ei≠j(Cij2) egin{document}$\mathrm{E}_{i
eq j}(C_{ij}^{2})$\end{document} and dimensionality. Adopting an approximation for a power-law kernel function f(x)≈ϵμ‖x‖−μ egin{document}$ f(x)\approx\epsilon^{\mu}\|x\|^{-\mu}$\end{document} allows us to express the expected value of the squared covariance Ei≠j(Cij2) egin{document}$ \mathrm{E}_{i
eq j}(C_{ij}^{2})$\end{document} as follows:(29)Ei≠j(Cij2)=∫[0,L]dp(x→1)p(x→2)f2(‖x→1−x→2‖)dx→1dx→2≈∫[0,L]dp(x→1)p(x→2)ϵ2μ‖x→1−x→2‖−2μdx→1dx→2. egin{document}$$ egin{aligned}\mathrm{E}_{i 
eq j}(C_{ij}^2) &= \displaystyle \int_{[0,L]^d} p(\vec{x}_1)p(\vec{x}_2) f^2 (\|\vec{x}_1-\vec{x}_2\|) \mathrm{d} \vec{x}_1\mathrm{d} \vec{x}_2 \ & \displaystyle \approx \int_{[0,L]^d} p(\vec{x}_1)p(\vec{x}_2) \epsilon^{2\mu} \|\vec{x}_1-\vec{x}_2\|^{-2\mu} \mathrm{d} \vec{x}_1\mathrm{d} \vec{x}_2.\end{aligned}$$\end{document}

For a set subjected to functional sampling with a sampling fraction k egin{document}$ k$\end{document}, this procedure adjusts the size of the functional space in the ERM model by a factor of k−1/d egin{document}$ k^{-1/d}$\end{document}. Consequently, the Ei≠jk(Cij2) egin{document}$ \mathrm{E}_{i
eq j}^{k}(C_{ij}^{2})$\end{document} for the sampled fraction k egin{document}$ k$\end{document} is given by:(30)Ei≠jk(Cij2)=∫[0,k1/dL]dp(x→1)p(x→2)f2(‖x→1−x→2‖)dx→1dx→2=∫[0,L]dp(x→1)p(x→2)f2(k1/d‖x→1−x→2‖)dx→1dx→2≈∫[0,L]dp(x→1)p(x→2)ϵ2μk−2μ/d‖x→1−x→2‖−2μdx→1dx→2≈k−2μ/dEi≠j(Cij2), egin{document}$$ egin{aligned} \mathrm{E}_{i
eq j}^k(C_{ij}^2) &= \displaystyle \int_{[0,k^{1/d}L]^d} p(\vec{x}_1)p(\vec{x}_2) f^2(\|\vec{x}_1-\vec{x}_2\|) \mathrm{d} \vec{x}_1\mathrm{d} \vec{x}_2 \&= \displaystyle \int_{[0,L]^d} p(\vec{x}_1)p(\vec{x}_2) f^2(k^{1/d}\|\vec{x}_1-\vec{x}_2\|) \mathrm{d} \vec{x}_1\mathrm{d} \vec{x}_2 \& \displaystyle \approx \int_{[0,L]^d} p(\vec{x}_1)p(\vec{x}_2) \epsilon^{2\mu}k^{-2\mu/d} \|\vec{x}_1-\vec{x}_2\|^{-2\mu} \mathrm{d} \vec{x}_1\mathrm{d} \vec{x}_2 \& \displaystyle \approx k^{-2\mu/d} \mathrm{E}_{i 
eq j}(C_{ij}^2),\end{aligned}$$\end{document}

Here, we assume that E[σ2]\begin{document}$ E[\sigma^{2}]$\end{document} and E[σ4]\begin{document}$ E[\sigma^{4}]$\end{document} are constant across the sampling process. This model enables the estimation of the ratio μ/d\begin{document}$ \mu/d$\end{document} as detailed in the Methods.(31)DPRFSap≈kN0E(σ2)2E(σ4)+(kN0−1)k−2μ/dEi≠j(Cij2)\begin{document}$$\displaystyle D_{\text{PR}}^{\text{FSap}} \approx \frac{kN_0 \mathrm{E}(\sigma^2)^2}{\mathrm{E}(\sigma^4) + (kN_0-1)k^{-2\mu/d}\mathrm{E}_{i \neq j}(C_{ij}^2)}$$\end{document}

In the large N\begin{document}$ N$\end{document} limit, we observe distinct behaviors in the evolution of dimensionality in both theory and data: it saturates in RSap (dashed line in Figure 5D), namely DPRRSap≈DPR\begin{document}$ D_{\text{PR}}^{\text{RSap}}\approx D_{\text{PR}}$\end{document} defined in Equation 1, whereas it follows a different scaling relationship DPRFSap≈k2μ/dDPR\begin{document}$ D_{\text{PR}}^{\text{FSap}}\approx k^{2\mu/d}D_{\text{PR}}$\end{document} in FSap (solid line in Figure 5D).

sec.title: Comparative analysis of PR dimension across sampling techniques
sec.p: This section examines the behavior of the PR dimension under three sampling techniques: anatomical sampling, random sampling, and functional sampling. We show that the average PR dimension following anatomical sampling occupies a middle ground between the extremes presented by random and functional sampling.

The PR dimension, denoted DPR\begin{document}$ D_{\text{PR}}$\end{document}, reflects the sampling impact and depends on the distribution p(X→)\begin{document}$ p(\vec{X})$\end{document} of the functional coordinates X→\begin{document}$ \vec{X}$\end{document}. Defining the sampling fraction as k=1/q\begin{document}$ k=1/q$\end{document}, the mean DPR\begin{document}$ D_{\text{PR}}$\end{document} is represented as:(32)mean(DPR)=1q∑i=1qDPRi=1q∑i=1qJ(pi(X→)),\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \text{mean}(D_{\text{PR}}) = \frac{1}{q}\sum_{i=1}^{q}D^i_{\text{PR}} = \frac{1}{q}\sum_{i=1}^{q}J(p_i(\vec{X})),$$\end{document}

where the neuron set 1,2,...,N\begin{document}$ 1,2,...,N$\end{document} is segmented into q\begin{document}$ q$\end{document} clusters {X→1,X→2,...,X→q}\begin{document}$ \{\vec{X}_{1},\vec{X}_{2},...,\vec{X}_{q}\}$\end{document}, each comprising Nq\begin{document}$ \frac{N}{q}$\end{document} neurons. The probability distribution pi(X→)\begin{document}$p_{i}(\vec{X})$\end{document} corresponds to each cluster {X→i}\begin{document}$ \{\vec{X}_{i}\}$\end{document}. The probability distribution for each cluster, pi(X→)\begin{document}$ p_{i}(\vec{X})$\end{document}, emerges naturally from the sampling process.

The equivalence of the mean probability density function across the sampled clusters to the original set’s probability density function leads us to the condition:(33)1q∑i=1qpi(X→)=p(X→),\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \frac{1}{q}\sum_{i=1}^{q}p_i(\vec{X}) = p(\vec{X}),$$\end{document}
This condition is a direct consequence of the sampling process, ensuring that the aggregated probability density function of all sampled sets mirrors the overall density distribution of the neurons.

Applying the Lagrange multiplier method to optimize the mean DPR\begin{document}$ D_{\text{PR}}$\end{document}:(34)L(p,λ)=1q∑i=1qJ(pi(X→))+∫DddX→λ(X→)(1q∑i=1qpi(X→)−p(X→)),\begin{document}$$\displaystyle L(p,\lambda) = \frac{1}{q}\sum_{i=1}^{q}J(p_i(\vec{X})) + \int_{D}\mathrm{d}^d\vec{X}\lambda(\vec{X})\left(\frac{1}{q}\sum_{i=1}^{q}p_i(\vec{X}) - p(\vec{X})\right),$$\end{document}

Here, L(p,λ)\begin{document}$ L(p,\lambda)$\end{document} is the Lagrangian, λ(X→)\begin{document}$ \lambda(\vec{X})$\end{document} is the Lagrange multiplier, we derive the optimal condition:(35)∂L(p,λ)∂pi=0,\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \frac{\partial L(p,\lambda)}{\partial p_i} = 0,$$\end{document}
yielding:(36)1q∂J∂pi(X→)+λ(X→)q=0.\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \frac{1}{q}\frac{\partial J}{\partial p_i(\vec{X})} + \frac{\lambda(\vec{X})}{q} = 0.$$\end{document}

At the optimal mean DPR\begin{document}$ D_{\text{PR}}$\end{document}, each p(X→i)\begin{document}$ p(\vec{X}_{i})$\end{document} is equivalent, leading to p(X→i)=p(X→j)=p(X→)\begin{document}$ p(\vec{X}_{i})=p(\vec{X}_{j})=p(\vec{X})$\end{document} (representative of random sampling). Hence, the mean DPR\begin{document}$ D_{\text{PR}}$\end{document} post-random sampling sets the upper limit for the mean DPR\begin{document}$ D_{\text{PR}}$\end{document} after anatomical sampling.

Let us investigate the lower bound of the mean PR dimension with the ERM model. For the minimization of mean (DPR)\begin{document}$ (D_{\text{PR}})$\end{document}, a key requirement is the functional spatial proximity of neurons within the same cluster, in other words, the neuron set should be distinctly separated in functional space. Consequently, achieving the minimum mean PR dimension necessitates a functional sampling strategy.

sec.title: Derive upper bound of dimension from spectrum
sec.p: To deduce DPR\begin{document}$ D_{PR}$\end{document} from the spectrum, for simplicity, we focus on the high-density region, where we have an analytical expression for λ that is valid for large eigenvalues:(37)λr=γ(rN)−1+μd⋅ρμd=γr−1+μdL−μNforr≤β(N),\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \lambda_r = \gamma \left(\frac{r}{N} \right)^{-1 + \frac{\mu}{d}} \cdot \rho^{\frac{\mu}{d}} = \gamma r^{-1 + \frac{\mu}{d}} L^{-\mu}N \quad \text{for} \quad r \leq \beta (N), $$\end{document}

where L\begin{document}$ L$\end{document} is the size of the functional space, γ\begin{document}$\gamma$\end{document} is the coefficient in Equation 3, which depends on d\begin{document}$ d$\end{document}, μ\begin{document}$\mu$\end{document}, and E(σ2)\begin{document}$ \mathrm{E}(\sigma^{2})$\end{document}. Note that the eigenvalue λr\begin{document}$ \lambda_{r}$\end{document} decays rapidly after the threshold r=β(N)\begin{document}$ r=\beta(N)$\end{document}. Since we did not discuss small eigenvalues in this article, we represent them here as an unknown function η(r,N,L)\begin{document}$ \eta(r,N,L)$\end{document}:(38)λr=η(r,N,L)forr>β(N)\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \lambda_r = \eta(r, N, L) \quad \text{for} \quad r \gt \beta (N) $$\end{document}

As discussed in Methods, without changing the properties of the spectrum, we can always impose E(σ2)=1\begin{document}$ \mathrm{E}(\sigma^{2})=1$\end{document} such that(39)∑r=1Nλr=Tr⁡(C)=N\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \sum_{r=1}^N \lambda_r = \operatorname{Tr}(C) = N$$\end{document}

We emphasize that this constraint requires that large and small eigenvalues behave differently because otherwise ∑r=1Nr−α\begin{document}$ \sum_{r=1}^{N}r^{-\alpha}$\end{document} with α<1\begin{document}$ \alpha \lt 1$\end{document} would scale as N1−α\begin{document}$ N^{1-\alpha}$\end{document}, and ∑r=1Nλr\begin{document}$ \sum_{r=1}^{N}\lambda_{r}$\end{document} is not proportional to N\begin{document}$ N$\end{document}.

Using the Cauchy–Schwarz inequality, we have an upper bound of ∑r=1Nλr2\begin{document}$ \sum_{r=1}^{N}\lambda_{r}^{2}$\end{document}:(40)∑r=1Nλr2≤(∑rλr)2=N2\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \sum_{r=1}^N \lambda_r^2 \leq \left(\sum_r \lambda_r \right)^2 = N^2$$\end{document}

On the other hand, λ12\begin{document}$ \lambda_{1}^{2}$\end{document} is a lower bound of ∑r=1Nλr2\begin{document}$ \sum_{r=1}^{N}\lambda_{r}^{2}$\end{document}:(41)∑r=1Nλr2>λ12=L−2μN2γ2\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \sum_{r=1}^N \lambda_r^2 \gt \lambda_1^2 = L^{-2\mu}N^2 \gamma^2$$\end{document}
As a result, the dimensionalityDPR=(∑r=1Nλr)2∑r=1Nλr2,\begin{document}$$\displaystyle D_{\rm PR}=\frac{\left(\sum_{r=1}^{N}\lambda_{r}\right)^{2}}{\sum_{r=1}^{N}\lambda_{r}^{2}},$$\end{document}
is bounded as(42)1≤DPR<L2μγ−2\begin{document}$$\displaystyle 1 \le D_{\rm PR} \lt L^{2\mu} \gamma^{-2}$$\end{document}

Under random sampling, L\begin{document}$ L$\end{document} remains fixed. Thus, we must have a bounded dimensionality that is independent of N\begin{document}$ N$\end{document} for our ERM model. A tighter lower bound of ∑r=1Nλr2\begin{document}$\sum_{r=1}^{N}\lambda_{r}^{2}$\end{document} is(43)∑r=1Nλr2>γ2L−2μN2∑r=1β(N)(r−2+2μ/d)\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \sum_{r=1}^N \lambda_r^2 \gt \gamma^2 L^{-2\mu} N^{2} \sum_{r=1}^{\beta (N)} \left(r^{-2 + 2\mu/d} \right)$$\end{document}

A tighter upper bound of participation ratio DPR\begin{document}$ D_{\rm PR}$\end{document} can be written as:(44)DPR=(∑r=1Nλr)2∑r=1Nλr2<L2μγ−2∑r=1β(N)(r−2+2μ/d)<L2μγ−2\begin{document}$$\displaystyle D_{\rm PR} = \frac{\left(\sum_{r=1}^N \lambda_r \right)^2}{\sum_{r=1}^N \lambda_r^2} \lt \frac{L^{2\mu} \gamma^{-2}}{\sum_{r=1}^{\beta (N)} \left(r^{-2 + 2\mu/d} \right)} \lt L^{2\mu} \gamma^{-2}$$\end{document}

However, in functional sampling, enlarging the region size with constant density ρ results in L∼N1/d\begin{document}$ L\sim N^{1/d}$\end{document}. Thus, the upper bound of DPR\begin{document}$ D_{\rm PR}$\end{document} should grow as N2μ/d\begin{document}$ N^{2\mu/d}$\end{document}, consistent with the previously derived result (Equation 31) in Methods.

sec.title: Simulating CCA and anatomical sampling
sec.p: In this section, we estimate the dimensions of the anatomically sampled neuron set. For simplicity, we assume that the functional coordinates of neurons, Xi\begin{document}$ X_{i}$\end{document}, and the anatomical coordinates of neurons, Yi\begin{document}$Y_{i}$\end{document}, both follow a multivariate Gaussian distribution. We define anatomical sampling, which involves sampling on Yi\begin{document}$ Y_{i}$\end{document}, along a direction chosen arbitrarily and denote this direction as YA\begin{document}$ Y^{A}$\end{document}. Subsequently, we perform sampling on Xi\begin{document}$ X_{i}$\end{document} in the direction denoted by XA\begin{document}$ X^{A}$\end{document}, which is determined to have the highest correlation with YA\begin{document}$ Y^{A}$\end{document} according to CCA. This process effectively mimics the scenario of functional sampling.

The key to calculating the PR dimension involves computing the expected value Ei≠j(Cij2)\begin{document}$ \mathrm{E}_{i\neq j}(C_{ij}^{2})$\end{document}. In the ERM model, the distribution of Cij\begin{document}$ C_{ij}$\end{document} can be estimated by the distribution of points in the functional space. This allows for the calculation of the PR dimension across anatomical sampling by comparing the distribution of Xi\begin{document}$ X_{i}$\end{document} after anatomical sampling with that after functional sampling. We can model the distribution of XA\begin{document}$ X^{A}$\end{document} and YA\begin{document}$ Y^{A}$\end{document} as follows:(45)RASap=corr(XA,YA),CASap=corr(XA,YA)σxσy,[XAYA]∼N([00],[σx2CASapCASapσy2]),\begin{document}$$\begin{aligned} R_{\text{ASap}}& = \displaystyle \text{corr}(X^A,Y^A), \\C_{\text{ASap}} &= \displaystyle \text{corr}(X^A,Y^A) \sigma_x \sigma_y, \\\begin{bmatrix}X^A \\Y^A\end{bmatrix} &\sim \displaystyle \mathcal{N}\left(\begin{bmatrix}0 \\0\end{bmatrix}, \begin{bmatrix}\sigma_x^2 & C_{\text{ASap}} \\C_{\text{ASap}} & \sigma_y^2\end{bmatrix} \right), \end{aligned}$$\end{document}

Here, we consider only the projection of the functional coordinate onto the direction XA\begin{document}$ X^{A}$\end{document}, which exhibits the highest correlation, denoted by RASap\begin{document}$ R_{\text{ASap}}$\end{document}, with YA\begin{document}$ Y^{A}$\end{document}. Specifically, when selecting the anatomical direction as the first CCA direction, the correlation between XA\begin{document}$ X^{A}$\end{document} and YA\begin{document}$ Y^{A}$\end{document} reaches its maximum, such that RASap=RCCA\begin{document}$ R_{\text{ASap}}=R_{\text{CCA}}$\end{document}. In this case, anatomical sampling results in the minimization of the dimensionality.

Now, let us perform anatomical sampling on the neurons. The X→i\begin{document}$ \vec{X}_{i}$\end{document} and Y→i\begin{document}$ \vec{Y}_{i}$\end{document} denote the functional and anatomical coordinates of the ith\begin{document}$ i^{\text{th}}$\end{document} neuron cluster after anatomical sampling, respectively.

To approximate, we need to calculate the functional coordinate probability distribution p(X→i)=p(X→|qiky<YA<q(i+1)ky)\begin{document}$ p(\vec{X}_{i})=p(\vec{X}|q^{y}_{ik} \lt Y^{A} \lt q^{y}_{(i+1)k})$\end{document}, which is the distribution of the ith\begin{document}$ i^{\text{th}}$\end{document} neuron cluster after anatomical sampling. YA\begin{document}$ Y^{A}$\end{document} represents the selected direction in anatomical space, and qiky\begin{document}$ q^{y}_{ik}$\end{document} denotes the ikth\begin{document}$ ik^{\text{th}}$\end{document} quantile of YA\begin{document}$ Y^{A}$\end{document}, where k\begin{document}$ k$\end{document} is the sampled fraction. Note the following relationships and distributions:(46)p(XA|YA=y)=p(XA,YA=y)p(YA=y),p(XA|YA=y)∼N(yσxσyRASap,σx2(1−RASap2)).\begin{document}$$\begin{aligned}&p(X^A|Y^A = y) = \displaystyle \frac{p(X^A,Y^A = y)}{p(Y^A = y)}, \\ &p(X^A|Y^A = \displaystyle y) \sim \mathcal{N}\left(y\frac{\sigma_x}{\sigma_y}R_{\text{ASap}}, \sigma_x^2(1-R_{\text{ASap}}^2)\right).\end{aligned}$$\end{document}(47)p(XiA)=p(XA|qiky<YA<q(i+1)ky)=1k∫qikyq(i+1)kyp(XA|YA=y)dy\begin{document}$$\displaystyle p(X^A_i) = p(X^A|q^y_{ik} \lt Y^{A} \lt q^y_{(i+1)k}) =\frac{1}{k} \int^{q^y_{(i+1)k}}_{q^y_{ik}} p(X^A|Y^A = y) dy$$\end{document}

The conditional probability distribution P(XA|qiky<YA<q(i+1)ky)\begin{document}$P(X^{A}|q^{y}_{ik} \lt Y^{A} \lt q^{y}_{(i+1)k})$\end{document} is equivalent to the distribution of the sum of YiAσxσyRASap\begin{document}$ Y_{i}^{A}\frac{\sigma_{x}}{\sigma_{y}}R_{\text{ASap}}$\end{document} and X0\begin{document}$ X_{0}$\end{document}, where X0∼N(0,σx2(1−RASap2))\begin{document}$ X_{0}\sim\mathcal{N}(0,\sigma_{x}^{2}(1-R_{\text{ASap}}^{2}))$\end{document}:(48)XiA=YiAσxσyRASap+X0,\begin{document}$$\displaystyle X^A_i = Y^A_i\frac{\sigma_x}{\sigma_y}R_{\text{ASap}} + X_0,$$\end{document}(49)p(YiA=y)={1k2πσyexp⁡(−y22σy2)for qiky<y<q(i+1)ky,0otherwise.\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \begin{array}{ll}p(Y_i^A = y) &= \begin{cases}\frac{1}{k\sqrt{2\pi}\sigma_y}\exp\left(-\frac{y^2}{2\sigma^2_y}\right) & \text{for } q^y_{ik} \lt y \lt q^y_{(i+1)k}, \\0 & \text{otherwise}.\end{cases}\end{array}$$\end{document}

The computation of XiA\begin{document}$ X^{A}_{i}$\end{document} involves two technical challenges: (1) The distribution of YiA\begin{document}$ Y^{A}_{i}$\end{document} is represented by a non-elementary function (Equation 49), which complicates the direct calculation of XiA\begin{document}$ X^{A}_{i}$\end{document}, which is the sum of YiARASapσx/σy\begin{document}$ Y^{A}_{i}R_{\text{ASap}}\sigma_{x}/\sigma_{y}$\end{document} and X0\begin{document}$ X_{0}$\end{document}. To facilitate approximation, we model YiA\begin{document}$ Y^{A}_{i}$\end{document} using a normal distribution with equivalent variance. (2) Calculating the variance of YiA\begin{document}$ Y^{A}_{i}$\end{document} presents direct challenges, and the variance of YiA\begin{document}$ Y^{A}_{i}$\end{document} differs across different neuron clusters i. Using a uniform distribution for Y\begin{document}$ Y$\end{document} simplifies this task (this assumption is only used to calculate the variance of YiA\begin{document}$ Y^{A}_{i}$\end{document}). Under this assumption, the variance of YiA\begin{document}$ Y^{A}_{i}$\end{document} can be straightforwardly calculated as Var(YiA)=k2σy2\begin{document}$ \mathrm{Var}(Y^{A}_{i})=k^{2}\sigma^{2}_{y}$\end{document}. Consequently, we approximate YiA\begin{document}$Y^{A}_{i}$\end{document} and XiA\begin{document}$ X^{A}_{i}$\end{document} as follows:(50)YiA∼N(qiky+q(i+1)ky2,k2σy2),\begin{document}$$\displaystyle Y_i^A \sim \mathcal{N}\left(\frac{q^y_{ik} + q^y_{(i+1)k}}{2}, k^2\sigma^2_y\right),$$\end{document}(51)XiA∼N(qiky+q(i+1)ky2σxσyRASap,σx2(1−RASap2+k2RASap2)).\begin{document}$$\displaystyle X_i^A \sim \mathcal{N}\left(\frac{q^y_{ik} + q^y_{(i+1)k}}{2}\frac{\sigma_x}{\sigma_y}R_{\text{ASap}}, \sigma_x^2(1-R_{\text{ASap}}^2+k^2 R_{\text{ASap}}^2)\right).$$\end{document}

Calculating the PR dimension directly from the distribution of XiA\begin{document}$ X^{A}_{i}$\end{document} is difficult; thus, we approximate anatomical sampling with fraction k\begin{document}$ k$\end{document} as functional sampling with fraction kf\begin{document}$ k_{f}$\end{document}, leading to:(52)kf=1+k2RASap2−RASap2.\begin{document}$$\displaystyle k_f = \sqrt{1+k^2 R_{\text{ASap}}^2-R_{\text{ASap}}^2}.$$\end{document}

Using the equation for functional sampling Ei≠jk(Cij2)≈k−2μ/dEi≠j(Cij2) egin{document}$ \mathrm{E}_{i
eq j}^{k}(C_{ij}^{2})\approx k^{-2\mu/d}\mathrm{E}_{i
eq j}(C_ {ij}^{2})$\end{document} (Equation 30):(53)Ei≠jk(Cij2)≈(1+k2RASap2−RASap2)−μ/dEi≠j(Cij2). egin{document}$$\displaystyle \mathrm{E}_{i
eq j}^k(C_{ij}^2) \approx (1+k^2 R_{	ext{ASap}}^2-R_{	ext{ASap}}^2)^{-\mu/d} \mathrm{E}_{i 
eq j}(C_{ij}^2).$$\end{document}(54)DPRASap≈kN0E(σ2)2E(σ4)+(kN0−1)(1+k2RASap2−RASap2)−μ/dEi≠j(Cij2) egin{document}$$\displaystyle D_{	ext{PR}}^{	ext{ASap}} \approx  rac{kN_0 \mathrm{E}(\sigma^2)^2}{\mathrm{E}(\sigma^4) + (kN_0-1)(1+k^2 R_{	ext{ASap}}^2-R_{	ext{ASap}}^2)^{-\mu/d}\mathrm{E}_{i 
eq j}(C_{ij}^2)}$$\end{document}

sec.title: Extensions of ERM and factors not affecting the scale invariance
sec.p: In Appendix 1—figure 1, we considered five additional types of spatial density distributions (coordinate distributions) in functional space and two additional functional space geometries. We examined the points distributed according to the uniform distribution (x→∼1/Ld\begin{document}$ \vec{x}\sim 1/L^{d}$\end{document}), the normal distribution (x→∼N(μp,σp2I)\begin{document}$ \vec{x}\sim\mathcal{N}(\mu_{p},\sigma_{p}^{2}\mathbf{I})$\end{document}), and the log-normal distribution (log⁡x→∼N(μp,σp2I)\begin{document}$ \log\vec{x}\sim\mathcal{N}(\mu_{p},\sigma_{p}^{2}\mathbf{I})$\end{document}). We used the method described in Methods to adjust the parameters of the coordinate distributions based on the uniform distribution case, so that they all generate similar pairwise correlation distributions. The relationships between these parameters are described in Methods. In Appendix 1—figure 1B, we used the following parameters: d=2\begin{document}$ d=2$\end{document} for the uniform distribution; μp=0\begin{document}$ \mu_{p}=0$\end{document}, σp=2.82\begin{document}$ \sigma_{p}=2.82$\end{document} for the normal distribution; and μp=2\begin{document}$ \mu_{p}=2$\end{document}, σp=0.39\begin{document}$\sigma_{p}=0.39$\end{document} for the log-normal distribution.

Second, we introduced multiple clusters of neurons in the functional space, with each cluster uniformly distributed in a box. We considered three arrangements: (1) two closely situated clusters (with a box size of L=52\begin{document}$ L=5\sqrt{2}$\end{document}, the distance between two cluster centers being Lc=L\begin{document}$ L_{c}=L$\end{document}), and (2) two distantly situated clusters (with a box size of L=52\begin{document}$ L=5\sqrt{2}$\end{document} and the distance between clusters Lc=4L\begin{document}$ L_{c}=4L$\end{document}), and three clusters arranged symmetrically in an equilateral triangle (with a box size of L=10/3\begin{document}$ L=10/\sqrt{3}$\end{document} and the distance between clusters Lc=L\begin{document}$ L_{c}=L$\end{document}).

Finally, we examined the scenario in which the points were uniformly distributed on the surface of a sphere (4πl2=L2\begin{document}$ 4\pi l^{2}=L^{2}$\end{document}, l\begin{document}$ l$\end{document} being the radius of the sphere) or a hemisphere (2πl2=L2\begin{document}$ 2\pi l^{2}=L^{2}$\end{document}) embedded in R3\begin{document}$\mathbb{R}^{3}$\end{document} (the pairwise distance is that in R3\begin{document}$ \mathbb{R}^{3}$\end{document}). It should be noted that both cases have the same surface area as the 2D box.

caption.title: Factors that do not affect the scale invariance.
caption.p: (A) Rank plot of the covariance eigenspectrum for ERMs with different f(x→)\begin{document}$f(\vec{x})$\end{document} (see Table 3). Diagrams show different slow-decaying kernel functions f(x→)\begin{document}$ f(\vec{x})$\end{document} along a 1D slice. (B) Same as A but for different coordinate distributions in the functional space (see text). The diagrams on the right illustrate uniform and clustered coordinate distributions. (C) Same as A but for different geometries of the functional space (see text). Diagrams illustrate spherical and hemispherical surfaces. (D) CI of the different ERMs considered in (A–C). The range on the y-axis is identical to Figure 4C. On the x-axis, 1: uniform distribution, 2: normal distribution, 3: log-normal distribution, 4: uniform two nearby clusters, 5: uniform two faraway clusters, 6: uniform 3-cluster, 7: spherical surface in R3\begin{document}$ \mathbb{R}^{3}$\end{document}, 8: hemispherical surface in R3\begin{document}$ \mathbb{R}^{3}$\end{document}. All ERM models in (B, C) are adjusted to have a similar distribution of pairwise correlations (Appendix 1).

caption.p: Rank plot (upper row) and pdf (lower row) of the covariance eigenspectrum for ERMs with different f(x→)\begin{document}$ f(\vec{x})$\end{document}. (A) ϵ=0.06\begin{document}$ \epsilon=0.06$\end{document}. (B) ϵ=0.12\begin{document}$ \epsilon=0.12$\end{document}. (C) ϵ=0.3\begin{document}$ \epsilon=0.3$\end{document}. (D) ϵ=0.6\begin{document}$ \epsilon=0.6$\end{document}. Other ERM simulation parameters: N=4096\begin{document}$ N=4096$\end{document}, ρ=100\begin{document}$ \rho=100$\end{document}, μ=0.5\begin{document}$ \mu=0.5$\end{document}, d=2\begin{document}$ d=2$\end{document}, L=6.4\begin{document}$ L=6.4$\end{document}, σi2=1\begin{document}$ \sigma_{i}^{2}=1$\end{document}. The formulas for different f(x→)\begin{document}$ f(\vec{x})$\end{document}’s are listed in Table 3 in Methods.

caption.p: The upper row illustrates the slow-decaying kernel function f(x→)\begin{document}$ f(\vec{x})$\end{document} (blue solid line) and its power-law asymptote (red dashed line) along a 1D slice at various f(x→)\begin{document}$ f(\vec{x})$\end{document}. The lower row is similar to A, but on the log–log scale. The formulas for different f(x→)\begin{document}$ f(\vec{x})$\end{document}’s are listed in Table 3 in Methods.

sec.title: RG approach
sec.p: Here we briefly summarize the RG approach used in Meshulam et al., 2019 and elucidate the adjustments required when applying the RG approach to ERM. The method consists of two stages: (i) iterative agglomerate clustering of neurons, and (ii) computing the spectrum of a block of the original covariance matrix corresponding to a cluster of the desired size based on the previous clustering result.

sec.title: Stage (i): iterative clustering
sec.p: We begin with N0\begin{document}$ N_{0}$\end{document} neurons, where N0\begin{document}$ N_{0}$\end{document} is assumed to be a power of 2. In the first iteration, we compute Pearson’s correlation coefficients for all neuron pairs. We then search greedily for the most correlated pairs and group the half pairs with the highest correlation into the first cluster; the remaining neurons form the second cluster. For each pair (a,b)\begin{document}$(a,b)$\end{document}, we define a coarse-grained variable according to:(S1)xik=Zabk−1(xak−1+xbk−1),\begin{document}$$\displaystyle x^{k}_i = Z^{k-1}_{ab} (x^{k-1}_a + x^{k-1}_{b}),$$\end{document}

where Zabk−1\begin{document}$ Z^{k-1}_{ab}$\end{document} normalizes the average to ensure unit nonzero activity. This process reduces the number of neurons to N1=N0/2\begin{document}$ N_{1}=N_{0}/2$\end{document}. In subsequent iterations, we continue grouping the most correlated pairs of the coarse-grained neurons, iteratively reducing the number of neurons by half at each step. This process continues until the desired level of coarse-graining is achieved.

When applying the RG approach to ERM, instead of combining neural activity, we merge correlation matrices to traverse different scales. During the kth iteration, we compute the coarse-grained covariance as:(S2)cijk=cabk−1+cack−1+cbck−1+cbdk−1\begin{document}$$\displaystyle c_{ij}^k = c_{ab}^{k-1} + c_{ac}^{k-1} + c_{bc}^{k-1} + c_{bd}^{k-1}$$\end{document}
and the variance as:(S3)ciik=caak−1+cbbk−1+2cabk−1\begin{document}$$\displaystyle c_{ii}^k = c_{aa}^{k-1} + c_{bb}^{k-1} + 2c_{ab}^{k-1}$$\end{document}

Following these calculations, we normalize the coarse-grained covariance matrix to ensure that all variances are equal to one. Note that these coarse-grained covariances are only used in stage (i) and not used to calculate the spectrum.

sec.title: Stage (ii): eigenspectrum calculation
sec.p: The calculation of eigenspectra at different scales proceeds through three sequential steps. First, for each cluster identified in stage (i), we compute the covariance matrix using the original firing rates of neurons within that cluster (not the coarse-grained activities). Second, we calculate the eigenspectrum for each cluster. Finally, we average these eigenspectra across all clusters at a given iteration level to obtain the representative eigenspectrum for that scale.

In stage (ii), we calculate the eigenspectra of the sub-covariance matrices across different cluster sizes as described in Meshulam et al., 2019. Let N0=2n\begin{document}$ N_{0}=2^{n}$\end{document} be the original number of neurons. To reduce it to size N=N0/2k=2n−k\begin{document}$ N=N_{0}/2^{k}=2^{n-k}$\end{document}, where k\begin{document}$ k$\end{document} is the kth reduction step, consider the coarse-grained neurons in step n−k\begin{document}$ n-k$\end{document} in stage (i). Each coarse-grained neuron is a cluster of 2n−k\begin{document}$ 2^{n-k}$\end{document} neurons. We then calculate spectrum of the block of the original covariance matrix corresponding to neurons of each cluster (there are 2k\begin{document}$ 2^{k}$\end{document} such blocks). Lastly, an average of these 2k\begin{document}$ 2^{k}$\end{document} spectra is computed.

For example, when reducing from N0=23=8\begin{document}$ N_{0}=2^{3}=8$\end{document} to N=23−1=4\begin{document}$ N=2^{3-1}=4$\end{document} neurons (k=1\begin{document}$ k=1$\end{document}), we would have two clusters of four neurons each. We calculate the eigenspectrum for each 4 × 4 block of the original covariance matrix, then average these two spectra together. To better understand this process through a concrete example, consider a hypothetical scenario where a set of eight neurons, labeled 1,2,3,...,7,8, are subjected to a two-step clustering procedure. In the first step, neurons are grouped based on their maximum correlation pairs, for example, resulting in the formation of four pairs: {1,2},{3,4},{5,6}\begin{document}$ \{1,2\},\{3,4\},\{5,6\}$\end{document}, and {7,8}\begin{document}$\{7,8\}$\end{document} (see Appendix 1—figure 4). Subsequently, the neurons are further grouped into two clusters based on the results of the RG step mentioned above. Specifically, if the correlation between the coarse-grained variables of the pair {1,2}\begin{document}$ \{1,2\}$\end{document} and the pair {3,4}\begin{document}$ \{3,4\}$\end{document} is found to be the largest among all other pairs of coarse-grained variables, the first group consists of neurons {1,2,3,4}\begin{document}$ \{1,2,3,4\}$\end{document}, while the second group contains neurons {5,6,7,8}\begin{document}$ \{5,6,7,8\}$\end{document}. Next, take the size of the cluster N=4\begin{document}$ N=4$\end{document} for example. The eigenspectra of the covariance matrices of the four neurons within each cluster are computed. This results in two eigenspectra, one for each cluster. The correlation matrices used to compute the eigenspectra of different sizes do not involve coarse-grained neurons. It is the real neurons 1,2,3,...,7,8, but with expanding cluster sizes. Finally, the average of the eigenspectra of the two clusters is calculated.

caption.title: Example of renormalization group (RG) approach for a set of eight neurons.
caption.p: The figure is adapted from Meshulam et al., 2019. The diagram illustrates the iterative clustering process for eight neurons. In each iteration, neurons are paired based on maximum correlation, with their activities combined through summation and normalized to maintain unit mean for nonzero values. Each neuron can only be paired once per iteration, ensuring all neurons are grouped by the iteration’s end.

caption.title: Eigenspectra of renormalization group (RG)-inspired clustering, direct functional region sampling (FSap), and random sampling (RSap) in ERM.
caption.p: (A, D) RG clustered eigenspectra of ERM. The size of the cluster is denoted by N\begin{document}$ N$\end{document}, which is the number of neurons in each cluster. We adopt the RG approach (Meshulam et al., 2018; Meshulam et al., 2019), but with a specific modification (Appendix 1). (B, E) Direct spatial sampling in the functional space (FSap) and the corresponding ERM eigenspectra. We began our analysis with a set of N0\begin{document}$ N_{0}$\end{document} neurons distributed in the functional space. Initially, we chose N=N0/2\begin{document}$ N=N_{0}/2$\end{document} neurons that were located exclusively on one side of the x-axis of this space. We then proceeded to select N=N0/4\begin{document}$ N=N_{0}/4$\end{document} neurons from 4 quadrants. This sampling process was repeated iteratively, generating successively smaller subsets of neurons. (C, F) Random sampled (RSap) eigenspectra of ERM. ERM parameters: (A–C) Exponential function f(x→)=e−‖x→‖/b\begin{document}$ f(\vec{x})=e^{-\|\vec{x}\|/b}$\end{document} where b=1\begin{document}$ b=1$\end{document}, ρ=10.24\begin{document}$ \rho=10.24$\end{document} and dimension d=2\begin{document}$ d=2$\end{document}. (D–F) Approximate power law Equation 11 with μ=0.5\begin{document}$ \mu=0.5$\end{document}, ρ=10.24\begin{document}$ \rho=10.24$\end{document} and dimension d=2\begin{document}$ d=2$\end{document}. Other parameters are the same as Figure 3. The standard error of the mean (SEM) across the clusters is represented by the shaded area of each line.

caption.title: Morrell et al.’s latent variable model.
caption.p: (A–D) Functional sampled (FSap) eigenspectra of the Morrell et al. model. (E–H) Random sampled (RSap) eigenspectra of the same model. Briefly, in Morrell et al.’s latent variable model (Morrell et al., 2024; Morrell et al., 2021), neural activity is driven by Nf\begin{document}$ N_{f}$\end{document} latent fields and a place field. The latent fields are modeled as Ornstein–Uhlenbeck processes with a time constant τ. The parameters ε and η control the mean and variance of individual neurons’ firing rates, respectively. The following are the parameter values used. (A, E) Using the same parameters as in Morrell et al., 2021: Nf=10\begin{document}$ N_{f}=10$\end{document}, ϵ=−2.67\begin{document}$ \epsilon=-2.67$\end{document}, η=6\begin{document}$ \eta=6$\end{document}, τ=0.1\begin{document}$ \tau=0.1$\end{document}. Half of the cells are also coupled to the place field. (B–D, F–H) Using parameters from Morrell et al., 2024: Nf=5\begin{document}$ N_{f}=5$\end{document}, ϵ=−3\begin{document}$ \epsilon=-3$\end{document}, η=4\begin{document}$ \eta=4$\end{document}. There is no place field. The time constant τ=0.1,1,10\begin{document}$\tau=0.1,1,10$\end{document} for (B, F, C, G) and (D, H), respectively.

sec.title: Analyzing the effects of removing neural activity data during hunting
sec.p: To identify and remove the time frames corresponding to putative hunting behaviors, the following procedure was used. The hunting interval was defined as 10 frames (1 s) preceding the onset of an eye convergence (see Methods) to 10 frames after the offset of this eye convergence. These frames were then excluded from the data before recalculating the covariance matrix (see Methods) and subsequently the sampled eigenspectra (Appendix 1—figure 7B, Appendix 1—figure 8B, D, F, H). As a control to the removal of the hunting frame, an equal number of time frames that are not within those hunting intervals were randomly selected and then removed and analyzed (Appendix 1—figure 7C, Appendix 1—figure 8A, C, E, G). The number of hunting interval frames and total recording frames for five fish exhibiting hunting behaviors are as follows: fish 1 – 268/7495, fish 2 – 565/9774, fish 3 – 2734/13,904, fish 4 – 843/7318, and fish 5 – 1066/7200. Fish 6 (number of time frames: 9388) was not exposed to a prey stimulus and, therefore, was excluded from the analysis.

To assess the impact of hunting removal on CI, we calculated the CI of the covariance matrix using all neurons recorded in each fish (without sampling to 1024 neurons). For the control case, we repeated the removal of the nonhunting frame 10 times to generate 10 covariance matrices and computed their CIs. We used a one-sample t-test to determine the level of statistical significance between the control CIs and the CI obtained after removal of the hunting frame.

Using fitted ERM parameters by full data, we performed a MDS on the control data and hunting-removed data to infer the functional coordinates. Note that the functional coordinates inferred by MDS are not unique: rotations and translations give equivalent solutions. For visualization purposes (not needed for analysis), we first used the Umeyama algorithm to optimally align the functional coordinates of control and hunting-removed data.

To identify distinct clusters within the functional coordinates, we fit Gaussian Mixture Models (GMMs) using the ‘GaussianMixtures’ package in Julia. We chose the number of clusters K\begin{document}$ K$\end{document} based on giving the smallest Bayesian information criterion score. After fitting the GMMs, a list of probabilities pik\begin{document}$ p_{ik}$\end{document}, k=1,2,…,K\begin{document}$ k=1,2,\ldots,K$\end{document} was given for each neuron i specifying the probability of the neuron belonging to the cluster k\begin{document}$ k$\end{document}. The mean and covariance parameters were estimated for each Gaussian distributed cluster. For visualization (but not for analysis), a neuron was colored according to cluster k∗\begin{document}$ k^{*}$\end{document} where k∗=arg⁡max1≤k≤Kpik\begin{document}$k^{*}=\arg\max_{1\leq k\leq K}p_{ik}$\end{document}.

We used the following method to measure the size of the cluster and its fold change. For a 2D (recall d=2\begin{document}$ d=2$\end{document} in our ERM) Gaussian distributed cluster, let us consider an ellipse centered on its mean, and its axes are aligned with the eigenvectors of its covariance matrix C2×2\begin{document}$ C_{2\times 2}$\end{document}. Let the eigenvalues of C\begin{document}$ C$\end{document} be λ1,λ2\begin{document}$ \lambda_{1},\lambda_{2}$\end{document}. Then we set the length of the half-axis of the ellipse to be cλi\begin{document}$ c\sqrt{\lambda_{i}}$\end{document}, respectively. Here, c>0\begin{document}$ c \gt 0$\end{document} is a constant determined below. Note that the ellipse axes correspond to linear combinations of 2D Gaussian random variables that are independent and λi\begin{document}$ \lambda_{i}$\end{document}’s are the variance of these linear combinations. From this fact, it is straightforward to show that the probability that a sample from the Gaussian cluster lies in the above ellipse depends only on c\begin{document}$ c$\end{document}, that is, 1−e−c22\begin{document}$ 1-e^{-\frac{c^{2}}{2}}$\end{document}, and not on the shape of the cluster. So, the ellipse represents a region that covers a fixed proportion of neurons for any cluster, and its area can be used as a measure for the size of the Gaussian cluster. Note that the area of the ellipse is πc2λ1λ2=πc2det(C)\begin{document}$ \pi c^{2}\sqrt{\lambda_{1}\lambda_{2}}=\pi c^{2}\sqrt{\det(C)}$\end{document}. In Appendix 1—figure 9, we plot the ellipses to help visualize the clusters and their changes. We choose c\begin{document}$ c$\end{document} such that the ellipse covers 95% of the probability (i.e., the fraction of neurons belonging to the cluster).

In the control functional map where we fit the GMMs, we directly calculated the size measure πc2det(C)\begin{document}$ \pi c^{2}\sqrt{\det(C)}$\end{document} from the estimated covariance C\begin{document}$ C$\end{document} for each Gaussian cluster. In the hunting-removed functional map, we needed to estimate the covariance C′\begin{document}$ C^{\prime}$\end{document} for neurons belonging to a cluster k\begin{document}$ k$\end{document} under the new coordinates (we assume that the new distribution can still be approximated by a Gaussian distribution). We performed this estimation in a probabilistic manner to avoid issues of highly overlapping clusters where the cluster membership could be ambiguous for some neurons. First, we estimated the center/mean of the new Gaussian distribution by(x¯,y¯):=(∑i=1Npikxi∑i=1Npik,∑i=1Npikyi∑i=1Npik).\begin{document}$$\displaystyle (\bar{x},\bar{y}):=\left(\frac{\sum_{i=1}^{N}p_{ik}x_{i}}{\sum_{i=1}^{N}p_{ik}},\frac{\sum_{i=1}^{N}p_{ik}y_{i}}{\sum_{i=1}^{N}p_{ik}}\right).$$\end{document}

Here, the summation goes over all the N\begin{document}$ N$\end{document} neurons in the functional space and pik\begin{document}$p_{ik}$\end{document} is the membership probability defined above, and (xi,yi)\begin{document}$ \left(x_{i},y_{i}\right)$\end{document} is the coordinate of neuron i\begin{document}$ i$\end{document} in the hunting-removed map. Similarly, we can use a weighted average to estimate the entries in the covariance matrix C′=[Cxx′Cxy′Cyx′Cyy′]\begin{document}$ C^{\prime}=\begin{bmatrix}C^{\prime}_{xx}&C^{\prime}_{xy}\\ C^{\prime}_{yx}&C^{\prime}_{yy}\end{bmatrix}$\end{document}. For example,C^xy′:=∑i=1Npik(xi−x¯)(yi−y¯)∑i=1Npik.\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \hat{C}_{xy}^{\prime}:=\frac{\sum_{i=1}^{N}p_{ik}\left(x_{i}-\bar{x}\right)\left(y_{i}-\bar{y}\right)}{\sum_{i=1}^{N}p_{ik}}.$$\end{document}

Then we calculated the size of the cluster on the new map as πc2det(C^′)\begin{document}$ \pi c^{2}\sqrt{\det(\hat{C}^{\prime})}$\end{document}. Finally, we computed the fold change in size as det(C^′)det(C)\begin{document}$ \sqrt{\frac{\det\left(\hat{C}^{\prime}\right)}{\det(C)}}$\end{document}.

caption.title: The effects of hunting behavior on scale invariance and functional space organization.
caption.p: Sampled covariance eigenspectra of the data from fish 1 calculated from control (A) and hunting removed (B) data . Ctrl: We randomly remove the same number of non-hunting frames. This process is repeated 10 times, and the mean ± SD of the CI is shown in the plot. Hunting removed: The time frames corresponding to the eye-converged intervals (putative hunting state) are removed when calculating the covariance (Appendix 1). The CI for the hunting-removed data appears to be statistically smaller than in the control case (p-value = 1.5 × 10−9). (C) Functional space organization of control data. The neurons are clustered using the Gaussian Mixture Models (GMMs) and their cluster memberships are shown by the color. The color bar represents the proportion of neurons that belong to each cluster. (D) Similar to (C) but the functional coordinates are inferred from the hunting-removed data. The color code of each neuron is the same as that of the control data (C), which allows for a comparison of the changes to the clusters under the hunting-removed condition. See also the Movie S1.
