(E) Fold change in size/area (Appendix 1) for each cluster (top; the gray dashed line represents a fold change of 1, i.e., no change in size) and the anatomical distribution of the most dispersed cluster (bottom).

caption.title: Removing the time segment of hunting behavior does not obliterate the scale-invariant eigenspectra.
caption.p: Rows correspond to four light-field zebrafish data: fish 2 to fish 5 (results for fish 1 have been shown in Appendix 1—figure 7). (A, C, E, G) Ctrl: we randomly remove the same number of time frames that are not the putative hunting frames. We repeat this process 10 times to generate 10 control covariance matrices and the CI is represented by mean ± SD. (B, D, F, H) Hunting removed: data obtained by removing hunting frames from the full data (Appendix 1). The CI for the hunting removed data appears to be significantly smaller than that of the control case (one-sample t-test p=2.2×10−10\begin{document}$ p=2.2\times 10^{-10}$\end{document} in fish 2, p=4.6×10−9\begin{document}$ p=4.6\times 10^{-9}$\end{document} in fish 3, p=1.7×10−9\begin{document}$ p=1.7\times 10^{-9}$\end{document} in fish 4, and p=3.4×10−17\begin{document}$ p=3.4\times 10^{-17}$\end{document} in fish 5).

caption.title: Hunting behavior reorganizes neurons in the functional space (continued on next page).
caption.p: Rows correspond to five light-field recordings of zebrafish engaged in hunting behavior: fish 1 to fish 5. (A, D, G, J, M) (top) Functional space organization of the control data inferred by fitting the ERM and MDS (Result). Neurons are clustered using the Gaussian Mixture Models (GMMs) and their cluster memberships are shown by the color. The colorbar represents the proportion of neurons belonging to each cluster. (A, D, G, J, M) (bottom) The coordinate distribution of the cluster in control data which is most dispersed (i.e., largest fold change in size, see below) after hunting-removal. The transparency of the dots (colorbar) is proportional to the probability of the neurons belonging to this cluster (Appendix 1). The cyan ellipse serves as a visual aid for the cluster size: it encloses 95% of the neurons belonging to that cluster (Appendix 1). (B, E, H, K, N) (top) Similar to (A, D, G, J, M) (top) but the functional coordinates are inferred from the hunting-removed data. The color code of each neuron is the same as that in the control data, which allows for a comparison of the changes to the clusters under the hunting-removed condition. (B, E, H, K, N) (bottom) Similar to (A, D, G, J, M) (bottom) but the functional coordinates are inferred from the hunting-removed data. The transparency of each neuron is the same as in (A, D, G, J, M). (bottom), and it represents the probability pik\begin{document}$ p_{ik}$\end{document} (Appendix 1) of neurons belonging to the most dispersed cluster k\begin{document}$ k$\end{document} in the control data. Likewise, the cyan ellipse encloses 95% of the neurons belonging to that cluster (Appendix 1). (C, F, I, L, O) Top, size/area fold change (Appendix 1) for each cluster (the gray dashed line represents a fold change of 1, i.e., no change in size); bottom, the anatomical distribution of the neurons in the most dispersed cluster.

caption.title: Neural activity patterns in anatomical and functional space during hunting (click here).
caption.p: Single-trial examples of fish 1 and fish 3. (A) Inferred firing rate activity in anatomical space. Scale bar, 100 µm. (B) Inferred firing rate activity in functional space. Functional space organization of the control data inferred by fitting the ERM and MDS in Result. The cyan ellipse serves as a visual aid for the cluster size: it encloses 95% of the neurons belonging to that cluster (Appendix 1). The inset illustrates the functional space organization, similar to that shown in Appendix 1—figure 7C. The colorbars in panels A and B depict the inferred activity magnitude of individual neurons. (C) Simultaneous behavior recording alongside the neural activity. Time, seconds.

app.title: Appendix 2
app.p: In this appendix, we elaborate upon the sketch introduced in the Methods, and present a full derivation of the covariance eigenspectrum of our ERM model. This section is organized as follows. First, we will briefly introduce the relationship between the eigenvalue probability density distribution and the resolvent. Second, we will turn the problem of calculating the resolvent to a calculation of the partition function using a field-theoretic representation and proceed to manipulate the partition function using the replica method. Third, we will introduce two approximate methods for calculating the partition function, leading to the high-density theory and the Gaussian variational method. We will discuss the implications and predictions of each method. Finally, we will discuss the relationship between the two methods and identify the parameter regime where the high-density theory agrees with the numerical simulation. Notation table: Appendix 2—table 1.

sec.title: Resolvent
sec.p: The eigenvalues λn\begin{document}$ \lambda_{n}$\end{document} of a Hermitian matrix C\begin{document}$ C$\end{document} are real. Their probability density function or eigendensity is formally given by(S4)p(λ)=1N⟨∑n=1Nδ(λ−λn)⟩,\begin{document}$$\displaystyle p(\lambda) = \frac{1}{N} \left \langle \sum\limits_{n=1}^{N}{\delta(\lambda-\lambda_n)} \right \rangle,$$\end{document}

where ⟨…⟩\begin{document}$ \langle\dots\rangle$\end{document} represents an average across different realizations of C\begin{document}$ C$\end{document}. The eigendensity is connected with the resolvent (Mézard et al., 1999; Goetschy and Skipetrov, 2013),(S5)g(z)=1N⟨Tr1z−C⟩=1N⟨∑n=1N1z−λn⟩,\begin{document}$$\displaystyle g(z) = \frac{1}{N}\left \langle \mathrm{Tr}\frac{1}{z-C} \right \rangle=\frac{1}{N}\left \langle \sum\limits_{n=1}^{N} \frac{1}{z-\lambda_n} \right \rangle,$$\end{document}

we therefore compute the eigendensity using the standard inverse formula of Stieltjes tranform:(S6)p(λ)=−1πlimη→0+Im g(λ+iη)\begin{document}$$\displaystyle p(\lambda) = -\frac{1}{\pi}\lim\limits_{\eta \to 0^+}\mathbf{Im} \ g(\lambda+i\eta)$$\end{document}

sec.title: Field representation
sec.p: In this section, we discuss a field-theoretical representation of the resolvent g(z)\begin{document}$g(z)$\end{document}. First, we rewrite Equation S5 as(S7)g(z)=−2N∂z⟨ln⁡[(det(z−C))−1/2]⟩\begin{document}$$\displaystyle g(z) = -\frac{2}{N}\partial_z\left \langle \ln\left[\left(\det(z-C)\right)^{-1/2}\right] \right \rangle$$\end{document}

The determinant (det(z−C))−1/2\begin{document}$ \left(\det(z-C)\right)^{-1/2}$\end{document} can be represented as a Gaussian integral(S8)Ξ(z)=(det(z−C))−1/2=i−N/2∫−∞+∞dϕ12π...dϕN2πexp⁡[−i2ΦT(z−C)Φ],\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \Xi(z) = \left(\det(z-C)\right)^{-1/2} = i^{-N/2}\int^{ +\infty}_{-\infty}\frac{\mathrm{d}\phi_1}{\sqrt{2\pi}}...\frac{\mathrm{d}\phi_N}{\sqrt{2\pi}}\exp\left[-\frac{i}{2}\Phi^T(z-C)\Phi\right],$$\end{document}

where Φ=[ϕ1,…,ϕN]T\begin{document}$ \Phi=[\phi_{1},\ldots,\phi_{N}]^{T}$\end{document}, and i≡−1\begin{document}$ i\equiv\sqrt{-1}$\end{document}.(S9)ln⁡Ξ(z)=ln⁡∫−∞+∞dϕ12π...dϕN2πexp⁡[−i2ΦT(z−C)Φ]−iπN4\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \ln\Xi(z) = \ln\int^{ +\infty}_{-\infty}\frac{\mathrm{d}\phi_1}{\sqrt{2\pi}}...\frac{\mathrm{d}\phi_N}{\sqrt{2\pi}}\exp\left[-\frac{i}{2}\Phi^T(z-C)\Phi\right]-\frac{i\pi N}{4}$$\end{document}

We thus establish a relationship between the resolvent and Ξ\begin{document}$ \Xi$\end{document}(S10)g(z)=−2N∂z⟨ln⁡Ξ(z)⟩\begin{document}$$\displaystyle g(z) = -\frac{2}{N}\partial_z\left \langle \ln\Xi(z) \right \rangle$$\end{document}

Note that the constant term in Equation S9 can be killed by ∂z\begin{document}$\partial_{z}$\end{document} and we will ignore it in the sequel. Equation S10 is the central formula in this note. Ξ(z)\begin{document}$ \Xi(z)$\end{document} is also called the partition function in statistical physics. We endeavor to find a way to compute the average of ln⁡Ξ(z)\begin{document}$ \ln\Xi(z)$\end{document}.

Recall that in our ERM model (Result Equation S2 and Figure 3A), the covariance between neuron i and neuron j is determined by the distance kernel function and their neural activity variances:(S11)Cij=f(x→i−x→j)σiσj,\begin{document}$$\displaystyle C_{ij} = f(\vec{x}_i-\vec{x}_j)\sigma_i \sigma_j,$$\end{document}

where x→i\begin{document}$ \vec{x}_{i}$\end{document} are sampled from a uniform coordinate distribution p(x→i)=1/V;σi\begin{document}$ p(\vec{x}_{i})=1/V;\sigma _i$\end{document} are i.i.d. chosen from a probability density distribution p(σ)\begin{document}$ p(\sigma)$\end{document} and are independent of the neuron coordinates x→i\begin{document}$\vec{x}_{i}$\end{document}. The ⟨…⟩\begin{document}$ \langle\dots\rangle$\end{document} in Equation S10 is therefore an average over all possible x→i\begin{document}$ \vec{x}_{i}$\end{document} and σi\begin{document}$ \sigma_{i}$\end{document}. In order to compute ⟨ln⁡Ξ(z)⟩\begin{document}$ \left\langle\ln\Xi(z)\right\rangle$\end{document}, we apply the replica method based on a smart use of the identityln⁡x=limn→0xn−1n\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \ln x=\lim_{n\rightarrow 0}\frac{x^n-1}{n} $$\end{document}

Equation S10 now becomes(S12)g(z)=−2N∂z[limn→01n⟨Ξn(z)−1⟩]=−2N∂z[limn→01nln⁡⟨Ξn(z)⟩]\begin{document}$$\displaystyle g(z) = -\frac{2}{N}\partial_z \left[\lim\limits_{n \to 0}\frac{1}{n}\left \langle \Xi^n(z)-1 \right \rangle\right] = -\frac{2}{N}\partial_z \left[\lim\limits_{n \to 0}\frac{1}{n} \ln \left \langle \Xi^n(z) \right \rangle\right]$$\end{document}
The idea is to compute the right-hand side for finite and integer n\begin{document}$ n$\end{document} and then perform the analytic continuation to n→0\begin{document}$ n\to 0$\end{document}.

Now we seek to determine the value of ⟨Ξn(z)⟩\begin{document}$ \left\langle\Xi^{n}(z)\right\rangle$\end{document}. It contains n\begin{document}$ n$\end{document} copies (replicas) of the original system(S13)⟨Ξn(z)⟩=(12π)Nn2∫−∞+∞(dϕ11...dϕ1n)...(dϕN1...dϕNn)⟨exp⁡[−i2∑α=1nΦαT(z−C)Φα]⟩.\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \left \langle \Xi^n(z) \right \rangle = (\frac{1}{2\pi})^{\frac{Nn}{2}}\int^{ +\infty}_{ -\infty}(\mathrm{d}\phi_1^1...\mathrm{d}\phi_1^n)...(\mathrm{d}\phi_N^1...\mathrm{d}\phi_N^n)\left \langle \exp\left[-\frac{i}{2}\sum\limits_{\alpha=1}^{n}\Phi^{\alpha T}(z-C)\Phi^{\alpha}\right]\right \rangle. $$\end{document}

Writing it down explicitly, we have(S14)⟨Ξn(z)⟩=(12π)Nn2∫−∞+∞(dϕ11...dϕ1n)...(dϕN1...dϕNn)∫−LLddx→1V...ddx→NV∫p(σ1)dσ1...p(σN)dσNexp⁡[−zi2∑α=1n∑j=1N(ϕjα)2+i2∑α=1n∑j,k=1Nϕjαϕkαf(x→j−x→k)σjσk]\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \begin{array}{rl}\\\left \langle \Xi^n(z) \right \rangle = (\frac{1}{2\pi})^{\frac{Nn}{2}}\int^{ +\infty}_{ -\infty}(\mathrm{d}\phi_1^1...\mathrm{d}\phi_1^n)...(\mathrm{d}\phi_N^1...\mathrm{d}\phi_N^n)\int^{L}_{-L}\frac{\mathrm{d}^d\vec{x}_1}{V}...\frac{\mathrm{d}^d\vec{x}_N}{V}\int p(\sigma_1)\mathrm{d}\sigma_1...p(\sigma_N)\mathrm{d}\sigma_N \\ \exp\left[-\frac{zi}{2}\sum\limits_{\alpha=1}^{n}\sum\limits_{j=1}^{N}(\phi_j^{\alpha})^2+\frac{i}{2}\sum\limits_{\alpha=1}^{n}\sum\limits_{j,k=1}^{N}\phi^{\alpha}_j\phi^{\alpha}_k f(\vec{x}_j-\vec{x}_k)\sigma_j \sigma_k\right]\end{array}$$\end{document}

In order to proceed further, we introduce the following auxiliary fields:(S15)ψα(x→)=∑j=1Nϕjαδ(x→−x→j)\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \psi^{\alpha}(\vec{x}) = \sum\limits_{j=1}^N\phi^{\alpha}_j\delta(\vec{x}-\vec{x}_j)$$\end{document}

Equation S15 can be represented as a following functional integral(S16)1=∫−∞+∞∏α=1nD[ψα]δF[ψα(x→)−∑j=1Nϕjαδ(x→−x→j)]\begin{document}$$\displaystyle 1 = \int^{ +\infty}_{ -\infty}\prod_{\alpha = 1}^n D[\psi^{\alpha}]\delta_F[\psi^{\alpha}(\vec{x})-\sum\limits_{j=1}^N\phi^{\alpha}_j\delta(\vec{x}-\vec{x}_j)] $$\end{document}(S17)δF[ψ]=∫−∞+∞D[ψ^]exp⁡[i∫−∞+∞ddx→ψ(x→)ψ^(x→)]\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \delta_F[\psi] = \int^{ +\infty}_{ -\infty}D[\hat\psi]\exp[i\int_{-\infty}^{+\infty}\mathrm{d}^d \vec{x} \psi(\vec{x})\hat\psi(\vec{x})]$$\end{document}

or we can combine Equations S16 and S17 as(S18)1=∫−∞+∞∫−∞+∞∏α=1nD[ψ^α]D[ψα]exp⁡[i∫−∞+∞ddx→[ψα(x→)−∑j=1Nϕjαδ(x→−x→j)]ψ^α(x→)]\begin{document}$$\displaystyle 1 = \int^{ +\infty}_{ -\infty}\int^{ +\infty}_{ -\infty}\prod_{\alpha = 1}^n D[\hat\psi^{\alpha}]D[\psi^{\alpha}]\exp\left[i\int_{-\infty}^{+\infty}\mathrm{d}^d \vec{x} [\psi^{\alpha}(\vec{x})-\sum\limits_{j=1}^N\phi^{\alpha}_j\delta(\vec{x}-\vec{x}_j)]\hat\psi^{\alpha}(\vec{x})\right]$$\end{document}

Using Equation S15, we can write the term 12∑j,k=1Nϕjαϕkαf(x→j−x→k)\begin{document}$ \frac{1}{2}\sum\limits_{j,k=1}^{N}\phi^{\alpha}_{j}\phi^{\alpha}_{k}f(\vec{x}_ {j}-\vec{x}_{k})$\end{document} in Equation S14 as(S19)12∑j,k=1Nϕjαϕkαf(x→j−x→k)=12∫−∞+∞dx→dx→′f(x→−x→′)ψα(x→)ψα(x→′)\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \frac{1}{2}\sum\limits_{j,k=1}^{N}\phi^{\alpha}_j\phi^{\alpha}_k f(\vec{x}_j-\vec{x}_k) = \frac{1}{2}\int^{ +\infty}_{ -\infty}\mathrm{d}\vec{x}\mathrm{d}\vec{x}' f(\vec{x}-\vec{x}')\psi^{\alpha}(\vec{x})\psi^{\alpha}(\vec{x}')$$\end{document}

We insert the relation Equations S18 and S19 into Equation S14,(S20)⟨Ξn(z)⟩=(12π)Nn2∫−∞+∞(dϕ11...dϕ1n)...(dϕN1...dϕNn)∫−LLddx→1V...ddx→NV∫p(σ1)dσ1...p(σN)dσNexp⁡[−zi2∑α=1n∑j=1N(ϕjα)2+i2∑α=1n∑j,k=1Nϕjαϕkαf(x→j−x→k)σjσk]∫−∞+∞∫−∞+∞∏α=1nD[ψα]D[ψ^α]exp⁡[i∫−∞+∞ddx→(ψα(x→)−∑j=1Nϕjαδ(x→−x→j)σj)ψ^α(x→)]=(12π)Nn2∫−∞+∞∏α=1nD[ψα]D[ψ^α]∫−∞+∞(dϕ11...dϕ1n)...(dϕN1...dϕNn)∫−LLddx→1V...ddx→NV∫p(σ1)dσ1...p(σN)dσNexp⁡[−zi2∑α=1n∑j=1N(ϕjα)2+i2∑α=1n∑j,k=1Nϕjαϕkαf(x→j−x→k)σjσk]exp⁡[i∑α=1n∫−∞+∞ddx→(ψα(x→)−∑j=1Nϕjαδ(x→−x→j)σj)ψ^α(x→)]=(12π)Nn2∫−∞+∞∏α=1nD[ψα]D[ψ^α]exp⁡[i2∑α=1n∫−∞+∞dx→dx→′f(x→−x→′)ψα(x→)ψα(x→′)]∫−∞+∞(dϕ11...dϕ1n)...(dϕN1...dϕNn)∫−LLddx→1V...ddx→NV∫p(σ1)dσ1...p(σN)dσNexp⁡[−zi2∑α=1n∑j=1N(ϕjα)2+i∑α=1n∫−∞+∞ddx→(ψα(x→)−∑j=1Nϕjαδ(x→−x→j)σj)ψ^α(x→)]=(12π)Nn2∫−∞+∞∏α=1nD[ψα]D[ψ^α]exp⁡[i2∑α=1n∫−∞+∞dx→dx→′f(x→−x→′)ψα(x→)ψα(x→′)]exp⁡[i∑α=1n∫−∞+∞ddx→ψα(x→)ψ^α(x→)]∫−∞+∞(dϕ11...dϕ1n)...(dϕN1...dϕNn)∫−LLddx→1V...ddx→NV∫p(σ1)dσ1...p(σN)dσNexp⁡[−zi2∑α=1n∑j=1N(ϕjα)2−i∑α=1n∫−∞+∞ddx→∑j=1Nϕjαδ(x→−x→j)σjψ^α(x→)]\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \begin{aligned} \left \langle \Xi^n(z) \right \rangle = & \, \displaystyle(\frac{1}{2\pi})^{\frac{Nn}{2}}\int^{ +\infty}_{ -\infty}(\mathrm{d}\phi_1^1...\mathrm{d}\phi_1^n)...(\mathrm{d}\phi_N^1...\mathrm{d}\phi_N^n)\int^{L}_{-L}\frac{\mathrm{d}^d\vec{x}_1}{V}...\frac{\mathrm{d}^d\vec{x}_N}{V} \int p(\sigma_1)\mathrm{d}\sigma_1...p(\sigma_N)\mathrm{d}\sigma_N \\ & \displaystyle \exp\left[-\frac{zi}{2}\sum\limits_{\alpha=1}^{n}\sum\limits_{j=1}^{N}(\phi_j^{\alpha})^2+\frac{i}{2}\sum\limits_{\alpha=1}^{n}\sum\limits_{j,k=1}^{N}\phi^{\alpha}_j\phi^{\alpha}_k f(\vec{x}_j-\vec{x}_k)\sigma_j\sigma_k\right] \\ & \displaystyle \int^{ +\infty}_{ -\infty}\int^{ +\infty}_{ -\infty}\prod_{\alpha = 1}^n D[\psi^{\alpha}] D[\hat{\psi}^{\alpha}]\exp\left[i\int^{ +\infty}_{ -\infty}\mathrm{d}^d\vec{x}(\psi^{\alpha}(\vec{x})-\sum\limits_{j=1}^N\phi^{\alpha}_j\delta(\vec{x}-\vec{x}_j)\sigma_j)\hat{\psi}^{\alpha}(\vec{x})\right] \\ = & \, \displaystyle (\frac{1}{2\pi})^{\frac{Nn}{2}}\int^{ +\infty}_{ -\infty}\prod_{\alpha = 1}^n D[\psi^{\alpha}]D[\hat{\psi}^{\alpha}]\int^{ +\infty}_{ -\infty}(\mathrm{d}\phi_1^1...\mathrm{d}\phi_1^n)...(\mathrm{d}\phi_N^1...\mathrm{d}\phi_N^n)\\ & \displaystyle \int^{L}_{-L}\frac{\mathrm{d}^d\vec{x}_1}{V}...\frac{\mathrm{d}^d\vec{x}_N}{V}\int p(\sigma_1)\mathrm{d}\sigma_1...p(\sigma_N)\mathrm{d}\sigma_N \\ & \displaystyle \exp\left[-\frac{zi}{2}\sum\limits_{\alpha=1}^{n}\sum\limits_{j=1}^{N}(\phi_j^{\alpha})^2+\frac{i}{2}\sum\limits_{\alpha=1}^{n}\sum\limits_{j,k=1}^{N}\phi^{\alpha}_j\phi^{\alpha}_k f(\vec{x}_j-\vec{x}_k)\sigma_j \sigma_k\right]\\ & \displaystyle \exp\left[i\sum\limits_{\alpha=1}^{n}\int^{ +\infty}_{ -\infty}\mathrm{d}^d\vec{x}(\psi^{\alpha}(\vec{x})-\sum\limits_{j=1}^N\phi^{\alpha}_j\delta(\vec{x}-\vec{x}_j)\sigma_j)\hat{\psi}^{\alpha}(\vec{x})\right]\\ = & \, \displaystyle (\frac{1}{2\pi})^{\frac{Nn}{2}}\int^{ +\infty}_{ -\infty}\prod_{\alpha = 1}^n D[\psi^{\alpha}]D[\hat{\psi}^{\alpha}]\exp\left[\frac{i}{2}\sum\limits_{\alpha=1}^{n}\int^{ +\infty}_{ -\infty}\mathrm{d}\vec{x}\mathrm{d}\vec{x}' f(\vec{x}-\vec{x}')\psi^{\alpha}(\vec{x})\psi^{\alpha}(\vec{x}')\right]\\ & \displaystyle \int^{ +\infty}_{ -\infty}(\mathrm{d}\phi_1^1...\mathrm{d}\phi_1^n)...(\mathrm{d}\phi_N^1...\mathrm{d}\phi_N^n)\int^{L}_{-L}\frac{\mathrm{d}^d\vec{x}_1}{V}...\frac{\mathrm{d}^d\vec{x}_N}{V}\int p(\sigma_1)\mathrm{d}\sigma_1...p(\sigma_N)\mathrm{d}\sigma_N \\ & \displaystyle \exp\left[-\frac{zi}{2}\sum\limits_{\alpha=1}^{n}\sum\limits_{j=1}^{N}(\phi_j^{\alpha})^2+i\sum\limits_{\alpha=1}^{n}\int^{ +\infty}_{ -\infty}\mathrm{d}^d\vec{x}(\psi^{\alpha}(\vec{x})-\sum\limits_{j=1}^N\phi^{\alpha}_j\delta(\vec{x}-\vec{x}_j)\sigma_j)\hat{\psi}^{\alpha}(\vec{x})\right]\\ = & \, \displaystyle (\frac{1}{2\pi})^{\frac{Nn}{2}}\int^{ +\infty}_{ -\infty}\prod_{\alpha = 1}^n D[\psi^{\alpha}]D[\hat{\psi}^{\alpha}]\exp\left[\frac{i}{2}\sum\limits_{\alpha=1}^{n}\int^{ +\infty}_{ -\infty}\mathrm{d}\vec{x}\mathrm{d}\vec{x}' f(\vec{x}-\vec{x}')\psi^{\alpha}(\vec{x})\psi^{\alpha}(\vec{x}')\right] \\ & \displaystyle \exp\left[i\sum\limits_{\alpha=1}^{n}\int^{ +\infty}_{-\infty}\mathrm{d}^d\vec{x}\psi^{\alpha}(\vec{x})\hat{\psi}^{\alpha}(\vec{x})\right] \\ & \displaystyle \int^{ +\infty}_{ -\infty}(\mathrm{d}\phi_1^1...\mathrm{d}\phi_1^n)...(\mathrm{d}\phi_N^1...\mathrm{d}\phi_N^n)\int^{L}_{-L}\frac{\mathrm{d}^d\vec{x}_1}{V}...\frac{\mathrm{d}^d\vec{x}_N}{V}\int p(\sigma_1)\mathrm{d}\sigma_1...p(\sigma_N)\mathrm{d}\sigma_N \\ & \displaystyle \exp\left[-\frac{zi}{2}\sum\limits_{\alpha=1}^{n}\sum\limits_{j=1}^{N}(\phi_j^{\alpha})^2-i\sum\limits_{\alpha=1}^{n}\int^{ +\infty}_{ -\infty}\mathrm{d}^d\vec{x}\sum\limits_{j=1}^N\phi^{\alpha}_j\delta(\vec{x}-\vec{x}_j)\sigma_j\hat{\psi}^{\alpha}(\vec{x})\right]\end{aligned}$$\end{document}

Integrating the last term in Equation S20(S21)∫−∞+∞dϕi1...dϕin∫−LLddriV∫dσip(σi)exp⁡[−zi2∑α=1n(ϕiα)2−i∑α=1n∫−∞+∞ddrϕiαδ(r−ri)σiψ^α(r)]=∫−LLddriV∫−∞+∞dϕi1...dϕin∫dσip(σi)exp⁡[−zi2∑α=1n(ϕiα)2−i∑α=1nϕiασiψ^α(ri)]=(2πzi)n2∫−LLddriV∫dσip(σi)exp⁡[i2z∑α=1nψ^α(ri)2σi2]=(2πzi)n2∫−LLddrV∫dσp(σ)exp⁡[i2z∑α=1nψ^α(r)2σ2]\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \begin{aligned} \displaystyle \int^{ +\infty}_{ -\infty}\mathrm{d}\phi_i^{1}...& \mathrm{d}\phi_i^{n} \displaystyle \int^{L}_{-L}\frac{\mathrm{d}^dr_i}{V}\int \mathrm{d}\sigma_i p(\sigma_i)\exp\left[-\frac{zi}{2}\sum\limits_{\alpha=1}^{n}(\phi_i^{\alpha})^2-i\sum\limits_{\alpha=1}^{n}\int^{ +\infty}_{ -\infty}\mathrm{d}^dr\phi^{\alpha}_i\delta(r-r_i)\sigma_i\hat{\psi}^{\alpha}(r)\right]\\&= \displaystyle \int^{L}_{-L}\frac{\mathrm{d}^dr_i}{V}\int^{ +\infty}_{ -\infty}\mathrm{d}\phi_i^{1}...\mathrm{d}\phi_i^{n}\int \mathrm{d}\sigma_i p(\sigma_i)\exp\left[-\frac{zi}{2}\sum\limits_{\alpha=1}^{n}(\phi_i^{\alpha})^2-i\sum\limits_{\alpha=1}^{n}\phi^{\alpha}_i\sigma_i\hat{\psi}^{\alpha}(r_i)\right]\\&= \displaystyle (\frac{2\pi}{zi})^{\frac{n}{2}}\int^{L}_{-L}\frac{\mathrm{d}^dr_i}{V}\int \mathrm{d}\sigma_i p(\sigma_i)\exp\left[\frac{i}{2z}\sum\limits_{\alpha=1}^{n}\hat{\psi}^{\alpha}(r_i)^2\sigma_i^2\right]\\&= \displaystyle (\frac{2\pi}{zi})^{\frac{n}{2}}\int^{L}_{-L}\frac{\mathrm{d}^dr}{V}\int \mathrm{d}\sigma p(\sigma)\exp\left[\frac{i}{2z}\sum\limits_{\alpha=1}^{n}\hat{\psi}^{\alpha}(r)^2\sigma^2\right]\end{aligned}$$\end{document}

so that ⟨Ξn(z)⟩\begin{document}$ \left\langle\Xi^{n}(z)\right\rangle$\end{document} from Equation S14 can be written as(S22)⟨Ξn(z)⟩=∫−∞+∞∏α=1nD[ψα]D[ψ^α]ANeS0\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \left \langle \Xi^n(z) \right \rangle = \int^{ +\infty}_{ -\infty}\prod_{\alpha = 1}^n D[\psi^{\alpha}]D[\hat{\psi}^{\alpha}]A^Ne^{S_0}$$\end{document}(S23)whereA=∫−LLddx→V(zi)−n2∫dσp(σ)exp⁡[i2z∑α=1nψ^α(x→)2σ2]\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \text{where} \quad A = \int^{L}_{-L}\frac{\mathrm{d}^d\vec{x}}{V}(zi)^{-\frac{n}{2}}\int \mathrm{d}\sigma p(\sigma)\exp\left[\frac{i}{2z}\sum\limits_{\alpha=1}^{n}\hat{\psi}^{\alpha}(\vec{x})^2\sigma^2\right]$$\end{document}(S24)andS0=i2∑α=1n∫−∞+∞dx→dx→′f(x→−x→′)ψα(x→)ψα(x→′)+i∑α=1n∫−∞+∞ddx→ψα(x→)ψ^α(x→)\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \text{and} \quad S_0 = \frac{i}{2}\sum\limits_{\alpha=1}^{n}\int^{ +\infty}_{ -\infty}\mathrm{d}\vec{x}\mathrm{d}\vec{x}' f(\vec{x}-\vec{x}')\psi^{\alpha}(\vec{x})\psi^{\alpha}(\vec{x}')+i\sum\limits_{\alpha=1}^{n}\int^{ +\infty}_{ -\infty}\mathrm{d}^d\vec{x}\psi^{\alpha}(\vec{x})\hat{\psi}^{\alpha}(\vec{x})$$\end{document}

Integrating out the ψα\begin{document}$ \psi^{\alpha}$\end{document} in ⟨Ξn(z)⟩\begin{document}$ \left\langle\Xi^{n}(z)\right\rangle$\end{document} Equations S22 and S24(S25)∫−∞+∞D[ψα]exp⁡[i2∫−∞+∞dx→dx→′f(x→−x→′)ψα(x→)ψα(x→′)+i∫−∞+∞ddx→ψα(x→)ψ^α(x→)]=(2πi)N/2(detf)−1/2exp⁡[−i2∫−∞+∞dx→dx→′f−1(x→−x→′)ψ^α(x→)ψ^α(x→′)]\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \begin{aligned}\int^{ +\infty}_{ -\infty} D[\psi^{\alpha}] & \, \displaystyle \exp\left[\frac{i}{2}\int^{ +\infty}_{ -\infty}\mathrm{d}\vec{x}\mathrm{d}\vec{x}' f(\vec{x}-\vec{x}')\psi^{\alpha}(\vec{x})\psi^{\alpha}(\vec{x}')+i\int^{ +\infty}_{ -\infty}\mathrm{d}^d\vec{x}\psi^{\alpha}(\vec{x})\hat{\psi}^{\alpha}(\vec{x})\right]\\ &= \displaystyle (2\pi i)^{N/2}(\det f)^{-1/2}\exp\left[-\frac{i}{2}\int^{ +\infty}_{ -\infty}\mathrm{d}\vec{x}\mathrm{d}\vec{x}'f^{-1}(\vec{x}-\vec{x}')\hat{\psi}^{\alpha}(\vec{x})\hat{\psi}^{\alpha}(\vec{x}')\right]\end{aligned}$$\end{document}

Here, f−1\begin{document}$ f^{-1}$\end{document} is the inverse kernel satisfying:(S26)∫−∞+∞dx→″f(x→−x→″)f−1(x→″−x→′)=δ(x→−x→′)\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \int^{ +\infty}_{ -\infty}\mathrm{d} \vec{x}'' f(\vec{x}-\vec{x}'')f^{-1}(\vec{x}''-\vec{x}') = \delta(\vec{x}-\vec{x}')$$\end{document}

so that ⟨Ξn(z)⟩\begin{document}$\left\langle\Xi^{n}(z)\right\rangle$\end{document} can be written as(S27)⟨Ξn(z)⟩=(2πi)Nn2(detf)−n/2∫−∞+∞D[ψ^α]eS1\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \begin{aligned}\\\left \langle \Xi^n(z) \right \rangle = (2\pi i)^{\frac{Nn}{2}}(\det f)^{-n/2}\int^{ +\infty}_{ -\infty}D[\hat{\psi}^{\alpha}]e^{S_1}\end{aligned}$$\end{document}(S28)S1=Nln⁡A−i2∑α=1n∫−∞+∞dx→dx→′f−1(x→−x→′)ψ^α(x→)ψ^α(x→′)\begin{document}$$\displaystyle S_1 = N\ln A - \frac{i}{2}\sum\limits_{\alpha=1}^{n}\int^{ +\infty}_{ -\infty}\mathrm{d}\vec{x}\mathrm{d}\vec{x}'f^{-1}(\vec{x}-\vec{x}')\hat{\psi}^{\alpha}(\vec{x})\hat{\psi}^{\alpha}(\vec{x}')$$\end{document}

The constant term (2πi)Nn2\begin{document}$(2\pi i)^{\frac{Nn}{2}}$\end{document} of ⟨Ξn(z)⟩\begin{document}$ \left\langle\Xi^{n}(z)\right\rangle$\end{document} can be ignored because we should compute ∂z⟨ln⁡Ξ(z)⟩\begin{document}$ \partial_{z}\left\langle\ln\Xi(z)\right\rangle$\end{document} Equation S10 in the end.

To ensure the mathematical rigor in Equation S45, we next apply the Wick rotation ψα(x→)→ψα(x→)e−iπ4\begin{document}$ \psi^{\alpha}(\vec{x})\to\psi^{\alpha}(\vec{x})e^{-i\frac{\pi}{4}}$\end{document} (Appendix 2).(S29)⟨Ξn(z)⟩=(detf)−n/2∫−∞+∞D[ψ^α]eS1\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \left \langle \Xi^n(z) \right \rangle = (\det f)^{-n/2}\int^{ +\infty}_{ -\infty}D[\hat{\psi}^{\alpha}]e^{S_1}$$\end{document}(S30)S1=Nln⁡A−12∑α=1n∫−∞+∞dx→dx→′f−1(x→−x→′)ψ^α(x→)ψ^α(x→′)\begin{document}$$\displaystyle S_1 = N\ln A - \frac{1}{2}\sum\limits_{\alpha=1}^{n}\int^{ +\infty}_{ -\infty}\mathrm{d}\vec{x}\mathrm{d}\vec{x}'f^{-1}(\vec{x}-\vec{x}')\hat{\psi}^{\alpha}(\vec{x})\hat{\psi}^{\alpha}(\vec{x}')$$\end{document}(S31)A=∫−LLddx→V(z)−n2∫dσp(σ)exp⁡[12z∑α=1nψ^α(x→)2σ2]\begin{document}$$\displaystyle A = \int^{L}_{-L}\frac{\mathrm{d}^d\vec{x}}{V}(z)^{-\frac{n}{2}}\int \mathrm{d}\sigma p(\sigma)\exp\left[\frac{1}{2z}\sum\limits_{\alpha=1}^{n}\hat{\psi}^{\alpha}(\vec{x})^2\sigma^2\right]$$\end{document}

sec.title: High-density expansion
sec.p: In this section, we directly calculate the canonical partition function ⟨Ξn(z)⟩\begin{document}$ \left\langle\Xi^{n}(z)\right\rangle$\end{document} in the z→∞\begin{document}$ z\to\infty$\end{document} limit by approximating the term Nln⁡A\begin{document}$ N\ln A$\end{document} (Equation S30) to a quadratic action, from which the partition function (Equation S29) would become a Gaussian integral.

Let us first calculate the AN\begin{document}$ A^{N}$\end{document} in z→∞\begin{document}$ z\to\infty$\end{document} limit(S32)limz→∞A≈(z)−n2∫dσp(σ)[1+∫−LLddx→V12z∑α=1nψ^α(x→)2σ2]=(z)−n2[1+∫dσp(σ)σ2∫−LLddx→V12z∑α=1nψ^α(x→)2]=(z)−n2[1+E(σ2)∫−LLddx→V12z∑α=1nψ^α(x→)2]\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \begin{aligned} \lim\limits_{z \to \infty} A & \displaystyle \approx (z)^{-\frac{n}{2}}\int \mathrm{d}\sigma p(\sigma)\left[1+\int^{L}_{-L}\frac{\mathrm{d}^d\vec{x}}{V}\frac{1}{2z}\sum\limits_{\alpha=1}^{n}\hat{\psi}^{\alpha}(\vec{x})^2\sigma^2\right]\\& = \displaystyle (z)^{-\frac{n}{2}}\left[1+\int \mathrm{d}\sigma p(\sigma)\sigma^2\int^{L}_{-L}\frac{\mathrm{d}^d\vec{x}}{V}\frac{1}{2z}\sum\limits_{\alpha=1}^{n}\hat{\psi}^{\alpha}(\vec{x})^2\right]\\& = \displaystyle (z)^{-\frac{n}{2}}\left[1+\mathrm{E}(\sigma^2)\int^{L}_{-L}\frac{\mathrm{d}^d\vec{x}}{V}\frac{1}{2z}\sum\limits_{\alpha=1}^{n}\hat{\psi}^{\alpha}(\vec{x})^2\right]\end{aligned}$$\end{document}(S33)limz→∞AN=limz→∞(z)−Nn2[1+NE(σ2)∫−LLddx→V12z∑α=1nψ^α(x→)2]=limz→∞(z)−Nn2[1+NE(σ2)∑α=1n∫−LLddx→V12zψ^α(x→)2]≈(z)−Nn2exp⁡[E(σ2)∫−LLddx→VN2z∑α=1nψ^α(x→)2]\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \begin{aligned}\lim\limits_{z \to \infty} A^N & = \displaystyle \lim\limits_{z \to \infty}(z)^{-\frac{Nn}{2}}\left[1+N\mathrm{E}(\sigma^2)\int^{L}_{-L}\frac{\mathrm{d}^d\vec{x}}{V}\frac{1}{2z}\sum\limits_{\alpha=1}^{n}\hat{\psi}^{\alpha}(\vec{x})^2\right]\\& = \displaystyle \lim\limits_{z \to \infty}(z)^{-\frac{Nn}{2}}\left[1+N\mathrm{E}(\sigma^2)\sum\limits_{\alpha=1}^{n}\int^{L}_{-L}\frac{\mathrm{d}^d\vec{x}}{V}\frac{1}{2z}\hat{\psi}^{\alpha}(\vec{x})^2\right]\\ & \approx \displaystyle (z)^{-\frac{Nn}{2}}\exp\left[\mathrm{E}(\sigma^2)\int^{L}_{-L}\frac{\mathrm{d}^d\vec{x}}{V}\frac{N}{2z}\sum\limits_{\alpha=1}^{n}\hat{\psi}^{\alpha}(\vec{x})^2\right]\end{aligned}$$\end{document}

Now let us calculate ⟨Ξn(z)⟩\begin{document}$ \left\langle\Xi^{n}(z)\right\rangle$\end{document} (Equation S29–S31) by letting L→∞\begin{document}$ L\to\infty$\end{document}(S34)⟨Ξn(z)⟩=(detf)−n/2(z)−Nn2∫−∞+∞D[ψ^α]eSh\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \left \langle \Xi^n(z) \right \rangle = (\det f)^{-n/2}(z)^{-\frac{Nn}{2}}\int^{ +\infty}_{ -\infty}D[\hat{\psi}^{\alpha}]e^{S_h}$$\end{document}

where the high-density quadratic action(S35)Sh=E(σ2)∫−∞∞ddx→VN2z∑α=1nψ^α(x→)2−12∑α=1n∫−∞+∞dx→dx→′f−1(x→−x→′)ψ^α(x→)ψ^α(x→′)=−12∑α=1n∫−∞+∞dx→dx→′G−1(x→−x→′)ψ^α(x→)ψ^α(x→′)\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \begin{aligned} S_h &=\displaystyle \mathrm{E}(\sigma^2) \int^{\infty}_{-\infty}\frac{\mathrm{d}^d\vec{x}}{V}\frac{N}{2z}\sum\limits_{\alpha=1}^{n}\hat{\psi}^{\alpha}(\vec{x})^2 - \frac{1}{2}\sum\limits_{\alpha=1}^{n}\int^{ +\infty}_{ -\infty}\mathrm{d}\vec{x}\mathrm{d}\vec{x}'f^{-1}(\vec{x}-\vec{x}')\hat{\psi}^{\alpha}(\vec{x})\hat{\psi}^{\alpha}(\vec{x}')\\& = \displaystyle -\frac{1}{2}\sum\limits_{\alpha=1}^{n}\int^{ +\infty}_{ -\infty}\mathrm{d}\vec{x}\mathrm{d}\vec{x}'G^{-1}(\vec{x}-\vec{x}')\hat{\psi}^{\alpha}(\vec{x})\hat{\psi}^{\alpha}(\vec{x}')\end{aligned}$$\end{document}

where G−1(x→−y→)=f−1(x→−y→)−NE(σ2)Vzδ(x→−y→)\begin{document}$ G^{-1}(\vec{x}-\vec{y})=f^{-1}(\vec{x}-\vec{y})-\frac{N\mathrm{E}(\sigma^{2})} {Vz}\delta(\vec{x}-\vec{y})$\end{document}. Next, by integrating out the ψ^\begin{document}$ \hat{\psi}$\end{document} field, we find(S36)⟨Ξn(z)⟩=(detf)−n/2(z)−Nn2∫−∞+∞D[ψ^α]eSh=(zNdetfdet(G−1))−n/2\begin{document}$$\begin{aligned}\left \langle \Xi^n(z) \right \rangle &= \displaystyle (\det f)^{-n/2}(z)^{-\frac{Nn}{2}}\int^{ +\infty}_{ -\infty}D[\hat{\psi}^{\alpha}]e^{S_h}\\&= \displaystyle (z^N \det f\det (G^{-1}))^{-n/2}\end{aligned}$$\end{document}

Using Equation S12 that connects the partition function with the resolvent, we have(S37)g(z)=−2N∂z[limn→01nln⁡((det(zfG−1))−n/2)]=VN∂z∫−∞+∞ddk→(2π)dln⁡(z−NE(σ2)f~(k→)V)=1ρ∫−∞+∞ddk→(2π)d1z−ρE(σ2)f~(k→)\begin{document}$$\begin{aligned} g(z) &= \displaystyle-\frac{2}{N}\partial_z \left[\lim\limits_{n \to 0}\frac{1}{n} \ln\left((\det(zfG^{-1}))^{-n/2}\right)\right]\\&= \displaystyle\frac{V}{N}\partial_z\int^{ +\infty}_{ -\infty}\frac{\mathrm{d}^d\vec{k}}{(2\pi)^d}\ln\left(z-\frac{N\mathrm{E}(\sigma^2)\tilde f(\vec{k})}{V}\right)\\&= \displaystyle\frac{1}{\rho}\int^{ +\infty}_{ -\infty}\frac{\mathrm{d}^d\vec{k}}{(2\pi)^d}\frac{1}{z-\rho \mathrm{E}(\sigma^2)\tilde f(\vec{k})}\end{aligned}$$\end{document}
where f~(k→)\begin{document}$\tilde{f}(\vec{k})$\end{document} is the Fourier transform of f(x→)\begin{document}$ f(\vec{x})$\end{document}.

Finally, the eigendensity p(λ)\begin{document}$ p(\lambda)$\end{document} (Equation S6) is given by(S38)p(λ)=−1πlimη→0+Im(g(λ+iη))=1ρ∫−∞+∞ddk→(2π)dδ(λ−ρE(σ2)f~(k→))=1ρE(σ2)∫−∞+∞ddk→(2π)dδ(λE(σ2)−ρf~(k→))\begin{document}$$\begin{aligned} p(\lambda) &= \displaystyle -\frac{1}{\pi}\lim\limits_{\eta \to 0^+}\mathbf{Im}(g(\lambda+i\eta))\\&= \displaystyle \frac{1}{\rho}\int^{ +\infty}_{ -\infty}\frac{\mathrm{d}^d\vec{k}}{(2\pi)^d}\delta(\lambda-\rho \mathrm{E}(\sigma^2)\tilde f(\vec{k}))\\&= \displaystyle \frac{1}{\rho \mathrm{E}(\sigma^2)}\int^{ +\infty}_{ -\infty}\frac{\mathrm{d}^d\vec{k}}{(2\pi)^d}\delta\left(\frac{\lambda}{\mathrm{E}(\sigma^2)}-\rho \tilde f(\vec{k})\right)\end{aligned}$$\end{document}

sec.title: Derivation of power-law eigenspectrum in high-density limit
sec.p: Here we calculate the eigendensity of our model, with the kernel function f(x→)\begin{document}$ f(\vec{x})$\end{document} (Table 3). The Equation S38 (set E(σ2)=1\begin{document}$ \mathrm{E}(\sigma^{2})=1$\end{document} as in Result) can be written as:(S39)p(λ)=Sd−1(2π)d‖k→0‖d−1ρ2|f~′(k→0)|,‖k→0‖=f~−1(λρ)\begin{document}$$\displaystyle p(\lambda) = \frac{S_{d-1}}{(2\pi)^d}\frac{\Vert \vec{k}_0 \Vert^{d-1}}{\rho^2 \vert \tilde f'(\vec{k}_0)\vert} ,\quad \quad \Vert \vec{k}_0 \Vert = \tilde f^{-1}(\frac{\lambda}{\rho})$$\end{document}

where Sd−1\begin{document}$ S_{d-1}$\end{document} is the surface area of d−1\begin{document}$ d-1$\end{document} dimensional sphere. Here, we consider the approximation f(x→)≈ϵμ‖x→‖−μ\begin{document}$f(\vec{x})\approx\epsilon^{\mu}\|\vec{x}\|^{-\mu}$\end{document}, whose Fourier transform and its derivative are f~(k→)=c0‖k→‖−(d−μ)\begin{document}$ \tilde{f}(\vec{k})=c_{0}\|\vec{k}\|^{-(d-\mu)}$\end{document}, f~′(k→)=c1‖k→‖−(d−μ+1)\begin{document}$ \tilde{f}^{\prime}(\vec{k})=c_{1}\|\vec{k}\|^{-(d-\mu+1)}$\end{document} and ‖k0‖=f~−1(λρ)=(λc0ρ)−1d−μ\begin{document}$\|k_{0}\|=\tilde{f}^{-1}(\frac{\lambda}{\rho})=(\frac{\lambda}{c_{0}\rho})^{- \frac{1}{d-\mu}}$\end{document}. The constants are given by c0=2d−μπd2ϵμΓ(d−μ2)Γ(μ2)=ϵμc2\begin{document}$ c_{0}=2^{d-\mu}\pi^{\frac{d}{2}}\epsilon^{\mu}\frac{\Gamma(\frac{d-\mu}{2})}{ \Gamma(\frac{\mu}{2})}=\epsilon^{\mu}c_{2}$\end{document}, c1=−(d−μ)c0\begin{document}$ c_{1}=-(d-\mu)c_{0}$\end{document}, c2=2d−μπd2Γ(d−μ2)Γ(μ2)\begin{document}$ c_{2}=2^{d-\mu}\pi^{\frac{d}{2}}\frac{\Gamma(\frac{d-\mu}{2})}{\Gamma(\frac{ \mu}{2})}$\end{document}(S40)p(λ)=Sd−1(2π)d‖k→0‖d−1ρ2|f~′(k→0)|=Sd−1(2π)d‖k→0‖2d−μρ2|c1|=Sd−1(2π)dc0dd−μρ2(d−μ)(λρ)−2d−μd−μ=Sd−1(2π)dc2dd−μd−μλ−2d−μd−μ(ρϵd)μd−μ\begin{document}$$\begin{aligned}p(\lambda) &= \displaystyle \frac{S_{d-1}}{(2\pi)^d}\frac{\Vert \vec{k}_0 \Vert^{d-1}}{\rho^2 \vert \tilde f'(\vec{k}_0)\vert}= \displaystyle \frac{S_{d-1}}{(2\pi)^d}\frac{\Vert \vec{k}_0 \Vert^{2d-\mu}}{\rho^2 \vert c_1\vert}\\&= \frac{S_{d-1}}{(2\pi)^d}\frac{c_0^{\frac{d}{d-\mu}}}{\rho^2 (d-\mu)}(\frac{\lambda}{\rho})^{-\frac{2d-\mu}{d-\mu}}= \frac{S_{d-1}}{(2\pi)^d}\frac{c_2^{\frac{d}{d-\mu}}}{d-\mu}\lambda^{-\frac{2d-\mu}{d-\mu}}(\rho\epsilon^{d})^{\frac{\mu}{d-\mu}}\end{aligned}$$\end{document}

sec.title: Derivation of eigenspectrum with exponential kernel function in high-density limit
sec.p: Here we consider the exponential kernel function f(x→)=e−b‖x→‖\begin{document}$ f(\vec{x})=e^{-b\|\vec{x}\|}$\end{document}, whose Fourier transform and its derivative are f~(k→)=c1(b2+‖k→‖2)d+12\begin{document}$ \tilde{f}(\vec{k})=\frac{c_{1}}{(b^{2}+\|\vec{k}\|^{2})^{\frac{d+1}{2}}}$\end{document}, f~′(k→)=−(d+1)k→c1(b2+‖k→‖2)−d+32\begin{document}$ \tilde{f}^{\prime}(\vec{k})=-\frac{(d+1)\vec{k}c_{1}}{(b^{2}+\|\vec{k}\|^{2})^ {-\frac{d+3}{2}}}$\end{document} and ‖k0‖=f~−1(λρ)=(c1ρλ)2d+1−b2\begin{document}$ \|k_{0}\|=\tilde{f}^{-1}(\frac{\lambda}{\rho})=\sqrt{(\frac{c_{1}\rho}{\lambda })^{\frac{2}{d+1}}-b^{2}}$\end{document}, ‖k0‖2+b2=(c1ρλ)2d+1\begin{document}$\|k_{0}\|^{2}+b^{2}=(\frac{c_{1}\rho}{\lambda})^{\frac{2}{d+1}}$\end{document}, where c1=2dπd−12bΓ(d+12)\begin{document}$ c_{1}=2^{d}\pi^{\frac{d-1}{2}}b\Gamma(\frac{d+1}{2})$\end{document}(S41)p(λ)=Sd−1(2π)d‖k→0‖d−1ρ2|f~′(k→0)|=Sd−1(2π)d(b2+‖k→0‖2)−d+32‖k→0‖d−1ρ2|(d+1)k→0c1|=Sd−1(2π)d(c1ρλ)−d+3d+1‖k→0‖d−2(d+1)ρ2|c1|=Sd−1(d+1)(2π)dc12d+1ρ−d+1d+1λ−d+3d+1‖k→0‖d−2=Sd−1(d+1)(2π)d22dd+1πd−1d+1Γ(d+12)2d+1(ρb−d)−d+1d+1λ−d+3d+1((2dπd−12Γ(d+12)ρb−dλ)2d+1−1)d−22\begin{document}$$\begin{aligned} p(\lambda) = & \, \displaystyle \frac{S_{d-1}}{(2 \pi)^d} \frac{\left\|\vec{k}_0\right\|^{d-1}}{\rho^2\left|\tilde{f}^{\prime}\left(\vec{k}_0\right)\right|}=\frac{S_{d-1}}{(2 \pi)^d} \frac{\left(b^2+\left\|\vec{k}_0\right\|^2\right)^{-\frac{d+3}{2}}\left\|\vec{k}_0\right\|^{d-1}}{\rho^2\left|(d+1) \vec{k}_0 c_1\right|} \\ = & \, \displaystyle \frac{S_{d-1}}{(2 \pi)^d} \frac{\left(\frac{c_1 \rho}{\lambda}\right)^{-\frac{d+3}{d+1}}\left\|\vec{k}_0\right\|^{d-2}}{(d+1) \rho^2\left|c_1\right|}=\frac{S_{d-1}}{(d+1)(2 \pi)^d} c_1^{\frac{2}{d+1}} \rho^{\frac{-d+1}{d+1}} \lambda^{-\frac{d+3}{d+1}}\left\|\vec{k}_0\right\|^{d-2} \\ = & \,\displaystyle \frac{S_{d-1}}{(d+1)(2 \pi)^d} 2^{\frac{2 d}{d+1}} \pi^{\frac{d-1}{d+1}} \Gamma\left(\frac{d+1}{2}\right)^{\frac{2}{d+1}}\left(\rho b^{-d}\right)^{\frac{-d+1}{d+1}} \\ &\lambda^{-\frac{d+3}{d+1}}\left(\left(\frac{2^d \pi^{\frac{d-1}{2}} \Gamma\left(\frac{d+1}{2}\right) \rho b^{-d}}{\lambda}\right)^{\frac{2}{d+1}}-1\right)^{\frac{d-2}{2}} \end{aligned}$$\end{document}

It is straightforward to see that this spectrum is not scale invariant. For example, when d=2\begin{document}$ d=2$\end{document}, the above expression reduces to a perfect power-law spectrum p(λ)∼ρ−d+1d+1λ−d+3d+1\begin{document}$ p(\lambda)\sim\rho^{\frac{-d+1}{d+1}}\lambda^{-\frac{d+3}{d+1}}$\end{document}, which changes with scale over sampling.

sec.title: Variational approximation
sec.p: To find a general approximation for the eigenspectrum that goes beyond the high-density limit, we use Gaussian variational approximation in the field representation, namely by looking for the best quadratic action Sv\begin{document}$S_{v}$\end{document},(S42)Sv=−12∑αβn∫−∞+∞dx→dx→′Gαβ−1(x→−x→′)ψ^α(x→)ψ^β(x→′),\begin{document}$$\displaystyle S_v = -\frac{1}{2}\sum\limits_{\alpha\beta}^{n}\int^{ +\infty}_{ -\infty}\mathrm{d}\vec{x}\mathrm{d}\vec{x}'G^{-1}_{\alpha \beta}(\vec{x}-\vec{x}')\hat{\psi}^{\alpha}(\vec{x})\hat{\psi}^{\beta}(\vec{x}'),$$\end{document}

to approximate the action S1\begin{document}$ S_{1}$\end{document} in the partition function (Equations S29–S31). This enables us to represent the partition function by a Gaussian integral, which can be evaluated analytically. We find the best quadratic action Sv\begin{document}$ S_{v}$\end{document} by minimizing the difference between S1\begin{document}$ S_{1}$\end{document} and Sv\begin{document}$ S_{v}$\end{document}, which is defined as KL divergence between two distributions that are proportional to eS1\begin{document}$e^{S_{1}}$\end{document} and eSv\begin{document}$e^{S_{v}}$\end{document}.

In this section, we will proceed by using the grand canonical ensemble formulation, namely the average in Equation S4, instead of using a fixed covariance matrix size N\begin{document}$ N$\end{document}, which is now carried out across all different sizes. If N\begin{document}$ N$\end{document} follows a Poisson distribution, it is easy to show (Appendix 2) that the grand canonical partition function is given by Equation S116:Z=∑N⟨ΞNn(z)⟩aNN!,\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \mathcal{Z}=\sum_{N}\langle\Xi^{n}_{N}(z)\rangle\frac{a^{N}}{N!},$$\end{document}

where a=⟨N⟩\begin{document}$ a=\langle N\rangle$\end{document}. As a result, the new action S1\begin{document}$ S_{1}$\end{document} becomes(S43)S1=NA−12∑α=1n∫−∞+∞dx→dx→′f−1(x→−x→′)ψ^α(x→)ψ^α(x→′).\begin{document}$$\displaystyle S_1 = NA - \frac{1}{2}\sum\limits_{\alpha=1}^{n}\int^{ +\infty}_{ -\infty}\mathrm{d}\vec{x}\mathrm{d}\vec{x}'f^{-1}(\vec{x}-\vec{x}')\hat{\psi}^{\alpha}(\vec{x})\hat{\psi}^{\alpha}(\vec{x}').$$\end{document}

Here and below, N\begin{document}$ N$\end{document} should be viewed as the average matrix size. The resolvent g(z)\begin{document}$ g(z)$\end{document} in Equation S12 can be similarly generalized to Equation S117,g(z)=limn→0−2Nn∂zln⁡Z\begin{document}$$\displaystyle g(z)=\lim\limits_{n\to 0}-\frac{2}{Nn}\partial_{z}\ln\mathcal{Z}$$\end{document}

As in statistical physics, we define the free energy as(S44)F1=−ln⁡Z=−ln⁡∫−∞+∞D[ψ^α]eS1\begin{document}$$\displaystyle F_1 = -\ln \mathcal{Z} = -\ln \int^{ +\infty}_{ -\infty}D[\hat{\psi}^{\alpha}]e^{S_1}$$\end{document}

We shall define the variational free energy Fv\begin{document}$ F_{v}$\end{document} such that it would approximate the true free energy F1\begin{document}$ F_{1}$\end{document} by minimizing DKL(Pv||P1)\begin{document}$ D_{KL}(P_{v}||P_{1})$\end{document},(S45)Fv=DKL(Pv||P1)+F1\begin{document}$$\displaystyle F_v = D_{KL}(P_v || P_1) + F_1$$\end{document}

where(S46)P1=eS1∫−∞+∞D[ψ^α]eS1\begin{document}$$\displaystyle P_1 = \frac{e^{S_1}}{\int^{ +\infty}_{ -\infty}D[\hat{\psi}^{\alpha}]e^{S_1}}$$\end{document}(S47)Pv=eSv∫−∞+∞D[ψ^α]eSv\begin{document}$$\displaystyle P_v = \frac{e^{S_v}}{\int^{ +\infty}_{ -\infty}D[\hat{\psi}^{\alpha}]e^{S_v}}$$\end{document}

The KL divergence DKL(Pv||P1)\begin{document}$D_{KL}(P_{v}||P_{1})$\end{document} is always nonnegative and the free energy F1\begin{document}$ F_{1}$\end{document} is independent of the quadratic action Sv\begin{document}$S_{v}$\end{document}. Therefore, we need to minimize the variational free energy Fv\begin{document}$ F_{v}$\end{document}. Let us now examine the variational free energy Fv\begin{document}$ F_{v}$\end{document}(S48)Fv=DKL(Pv||P1)+F1=1Zv∫−∞+∞D[ψ^α]eSvln⁡PvP1−ln⁡Z=1Zv∫−∞+∞D[ψ^α]eSv(Sv−S1−ln⁡∫−∞+∞D[ψ^α]eSv+ln⁡∫−∞+∞D[ψ^α]eS1)−ln⁡Z=1Zv∫−∞+∞D[ψ^α]eSv(Sv−S1)−ln⁡Zv\begin{document}$$\begin{aligned} F_v =& \displaystyle D_{KL}(P_v || P_1) + F_1\\ =& \displaystyle \frac{1}{Z_v}\int^{ +\infty}_{ -\infty}D[\hat{\psi}^{\alpha}]e^{S_v}\ln \frac{P_v}{P_1}-\ln \mathcal{Z}\\=& \displaystyle \frac{1}{Z_v}\int^{ +\infty}_{ -\infty}D[\hat{\psi}^{\alpha}]e^{S_v}(S_v-S_1-\ln\int^{ +\infty}_{ -\infty}D[\hat{\psi}^{\alpha}]e^{S_v} + \ln\int^{ +\infty}_{ -\infty}D[\hat{\psi}^{\alpha}]e^{S_1})-\ln \mathcal{Z}\\=& \displaystyle \frac{1}{Z_v}\int^{ +\infty}_{ -\infty}D[\hat{\psi}^{\alpha}]e^{S_v}(S_v-S_1)-\ln Z_v\end{aligned}$$\end{document}

Here Zv\begin{document}$ Z_{v}$\end{document} is the normalization factor(S49)Zv=∫−∞+∞D[ψ^α]eSv\begin{document}$$\displaystyle Z_v = \int^{ +\infty}_{ -\infty}D[\hat{\psi}^{\alpha}]e^{S_v}$$\end{document}

Since we want to minimize Fv\begin{document}$F_{v}$\end{document}, the constant term(S50)1Zv∫−∞+∞D[ψ^α]eSvSv=const\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \frac{1}{Z_v}\int^{ +\infty}_{ -\infty}D[\hat{\psi}^{\alpha}]e^{S_v}S_v = \mathrm{const}$$\end{document}

can beignored, and Equation S48 is reduced to(S51)Fv=−1Zv∫−∞+∞D[ψ^α]eSvS1−ln⁡Zv\begin{document}$$\displaystyle F_v =-\frac{1}{Z_v}\int^{ +\infty}_{ -\infty}D[\hat{\psi}^{\alpha}]e^{S_v}S_1 - \ln Z_v$$\end{document}

To simplify the formula, let us introduce S2\begin{document}$ S_{2}$\end{document}(S52)S2=−12∑α=1n∫−∞+∞dx→dx→′f−1(x→−x→′)ψ^α(x→)ψ^α(x→′)\begin{document}$$\displaystyle S_2 = -\frac{1}{2}\sum\limits_{\alpha=1}^{n}\int^{ +\infty}_{-\infty}\mathrm{d}\vec{x}\mathrm{d}\vec{x}'f^{-1}(\vec{x}-\vec{x}')\hat{\psi}^{\alpha}(\vec{x})\hat{\psi}^{\alpha}(\vec{x}')$$\end{document}

and rewrite Equation S51 as(S53)Fv=−1Zv∫−∞+∞D[ψ^α]eSvS2−1Zv∫−∞+∞D[ψ^α]eSvNA−ln⁡Zv\begin{document}$$\displaystyle F_v =-\frac{1}{Z_v}\int^{ +\infty}_{ -\infty}D[\hat{\psi}^{\alpha}]e^{S_v}S_2 -\frac{1}{Z_v}\int^{ +\infty}_{ -\infty}D[\hat{\psi}^{\alpha}]e^{S_v} NA- \ln Z_v$$\end{document}

Next, we will compute each term in the variational free energy Fv\begin{document}$ F_{v}$\end{document} First, we calculate the third term ln⁡Zv\begin{document}$\ln Z_{v}$\end{document} in Equation S53 by Equations S42 and S49(S54)ln⁡Zv=ln⁡(∏α,β(2π)N/2(det(Gαβ−1))−12)=∑α,β12ln⁡det(Gαβ)+n2N2ln⁡(2π)\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \begin{aligned} \ln Z_v &= \displaystyle \ln\left(\prod_{\alpha,\beta} (2\pi)^{N/2}(\det(G^{-1}_{\alpha \beta}))^{-\frac{1}{2}}\right)\\ &= \displaystyle \sum_{\alpha,\beta} \frac{1}{2}\ln\det(G_{\alpha \beta}) + \frac{n^2N}{2}\ln(2\pi)\end{aligned}$$\end{document}

Second, we calculate the first term 1Zv∫−∞+∞D[ψ^α]eSvS2\begin{document}$ \frac{1}{Z_{v}}\int^{+\infty}_{-\infty}D[\hat{\psi}^{\alpha}]e^{S_{v}}S_{2}$\end{document} in Equation S53(S55)1Zv∫−∞∞D[ψ^α]eSvS2=1Zvlimh→0∂∂h∫−∞∞D[ψ^α]eSv+hS2=1Zvlimh→0∂∂h∏α=β[det(Gαβ−1+hf−1)]−12∏α≠β[det(Gαβ−1)]−12=limh→0∂∂h∏α[det(I+hf−1Gαα)]−12=∑αn∂∂hlimh→0(1−h2Tr(f−1Gαα))=−∑αn12Tr(f−1Gαα)\begin{document}$$ \begin{aligned} \frac{1}{Z_v} \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} D[\hat{\psi}^\alpha] e^{S_v} S_2 &= \displaystyle \frac{1}{Z_v} \lim_{h \to 0} \frac{\partial}{\partial h} \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} D[\hat{\psi}^\alpha] e^{S_v + h S_2} \\ &= \displaystyle \frac{1}{Z_v} \lim_{h \to 0} \frac{\partial}{\partial h} \prod_{\alpha = \beta} \left[\det(G^{-1}_{\alpha \beta} + h f^{-1}) \right]^{-\frac{1}{2}} \prod_{\alpha \neq \beta} \left[\det(G^{-1}_{\alpha \beta}) \right]^{-\frac{1}{2}} \\ &= \displaystyle \lim_{h \to 0} \frac{\partial}{\partial h} \prod_{\alpha} \left[\det(I + h f^{-1} G_{\alpha \alpha}) \right]^{-\frac{1}{2}} \\ &= \displaystyle \sum_{\alpha}^{n} \frac{\partial}{\partial h} \lim_{h \to 0} \left(1 - \frac{h}{2} \text{Tr}(f^{-1} G_{\alpha \alpha}) \right) \\ &= \displaystyle - \sum_{\alpha}^{n} \frac{1}{2} \text{Tr}(f^{-1} G_{\alpha \alpha}) \end{aligned}$$\end{document}

Third, we calculate the second term 1Zv∫−∞+∞D[ψ^α]eSvNA\begin{document}$\frac{1}{Z_{v}}\int^{+\infty}_{-\infty}D[\hat{\psi}^{\alpha}]e^{S_{v}}NA$\end{document} in Equation S53, recall the term A\begin{document}$ A$\end{document} (Equation S31)A=∫−LLddx→V(z)−n2∫dσp(σ)exp⁡[12z∑α=1nψ^α(x→)2σ2]\begin{document}$$\displaystyle A=\int^{L}_{-L}\frac{\mathrm{d}^{d}\vec{x}}{V}(z)^{-\frac{n}{2}}\int\mathrm{d}\sigma p(\sigma)\exp\left[\frac{1}{2z}\sum\limits_{\alpha=1}^{n}\hat{\psi}^{\alpha}(\vec{x})^{2}\sigma^{2}\right]$$\end{document}(S56)1Zv∫−∞+∞D[ψ^α]eSvNA=N(z)−n2Zv∫dσp(σ)∫−∞+∞D[ψ^α]eSv∫−LLddx→Vexp⁡[12z∑α=1nψ^α(x→)2σ2]=N(z)−n2Zv∫dσp(σ)∫−LLddx→0V∫−∞+∞D[ψ^α]exp⁡[Sv+12z∑α=1nψ^α(x→)2σ2]=N(z)−n2Zv∫dσp(σ)∫−LLddx→0V∏α,β[det(Kαβ)]12=N(z)−n2∫dσp(σ)∫−LLddx→0V∏α,β[det(KαβGαβ−1)]12\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \begin{aligned} \displaystyle \frac{1}{Z_v}\int^{ +\infty}_{-\infty}&D[\hat{\psi}^{\alpha}]e^{S_v} N A\\=&\displaystyle \frac{N(z)^{-\frac{n}{2}}}{Z_v}\int \mathrm{d}\sigma p(\sigma)\int^{ +\infty}_{ -\infty}D[\hat{\psi}^{\alpha}]e^{S_v} \int^{L}_{-L}\frac{\mathrm{d}^d\vec{x}}{V}\exp\left[\frac{1}{2z}\sum\limits_{\alpha=1}^{n}\hat{\psi}^{\alpha}(\vec{x})^2\sigma^2\right]\\=& \displaystyle \frac{N(z)^{-\frac{n}{2}}}{Z_v}\int \mathrm{d}\sigma p(\sigma)\int^{L}_{-L}\frac{\mathrm{d}^d\vec{x}_0}{V}\int^{ +\infty}_{ -\infty}D[\hat{\psi}^{\alpha}] \exp\left[S_v+\frac{1}{2z}\sum\limits_{\alpha=1}^{n}\hat{\psi}^{\alpha}(\vec{x})^2\sigma^2\right]\\=& \displaystyle \frac{N(z)^{-\frac{n}{2}}}{Z_v}\int \mathrm{d}\sigma p(\sigma)\int^{L}_{-L}\frac{\mathrm{d}^d\vec{x}_0}{V}\prod_{\alpha, \beta} \left[\det(K_{\alpha\beta})\right]^{\frac{1}{2}}\\=& \displaystyle N(z)^{-\frac{n}{2}}\int \mathrm{d}\sigma p(\sigma)\int^{L}_{-L}\frac{\mathrm{d}^d\vec{x}_0}{V}\prod_{\alpha, \beta} \left[\det(K_{\alpha\beta}G^{-1}_{\alpha\beta})\right]^{\frac{1}{2}}\end{aligned}$$\end{document}

where(S57)Sv+12z∑α=1nψ^α(x→)2σ2=−12∑αβn∫−∞+∞dx→dx→′Gαβ−1(x→−x→′)ψ^α(x→)ψ^β(x→′)+12z∑α=1nψ^α(x→)2σ2=−12∑αβn∫−∞+∞dx→dx→′Kαβ−1(x→−x→′)ψ^α(x→)ψ^β(x→′)\begin{document}$$\begin{aligned} \displaystyle S_v + \frac{1}{2z}\sum\limits_{\alpha=1}^{n}\hat{\psi}^{\alpha}(\vec{x})^2\sigma^2&= \displaystyle -\frac{1}{2}\sum\limits_{\alpha\beta}^{n}\int^{ +\infty}_{ -\infty}\mathrm{d}\vec{x}\mathrm{d}\vec{x}'G^{-1}_{\alpha \beta}(\vec{x}-\vec{x}')\hat{\psi}^{\alpha}(\vec{x})\hat{\psi}^{\beta}(\vec{x}') + \frac{1}{2z}\sum\limits_{\alpha=1}^{n}\hat{\psi}^{\alpha}(\vec{x})^2\sigma^2\\&= -\frac{1}{2}\sum\limits_{\alpha\beta}^{n}\int^{ +\infty}_{ -\infty}\mathrm{d}\vec{x}\mathrm{d}\vec{x}'K_{\alpha \beta}^{-1}(\vec{x}-\vec{x}')\hat{\psi}^{\alpha}(\vec{x})\hat{\psi}^{\beta}(\vec{x}')\end{aligned}$$\end{document}Kαβ−1(x→,y→)=Gαβ−1(x→,y→)−σ2zδαβδ(x→−x→o)δ(y→−x→0)\begin{document}$$\displaystyle K^{-1}_{\alpha\beta}(\vec{x},\vec{y})=G^{-1}_{\alpha\beta}(\vec{x},\vec{y})-\frac{\sigma^{2}}{z}\delta_{\alpha\beta}\delta(\vec{x}-\vec{x}_{o})\delta(\vec{y}-\vec{x}_{0})$$\end{document}(S58)det(Kαβ−1Gαβ)=1−σ2zδαβG(x→0,x→0)\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \det(K_{\alpha\beta}^{-1}G_{\alpha\beta}) = 1-\frac{\sigma^2}{z}\delta_{\alpha\beta}G(\vec{x}_0,\vec{x}_0)$$\end{document}(S59)1Zv∫−∞+∞D[ψ^α]eSvNA=N(z)−n2∫dσp(σ)∫−LLddx→0V∏α,β[det(Kαβ−1Gαβ)]−12=N(z)−n2∫dσp(σ)∫−LLddx→0V∏α[det(Kαα−1Gαα)]−12=N(z)−n2∫dσp(σ)∫−LLddx→0V∏α(1−σ2zGαα(x→0,x→0))−12=N(z)−n2∫dσp(σ)∏α(1−σ2zGαα(0))−12=N(z)−n2∫dσp(σ)exp⁡(−12Trnln⁡(1−σ2z∫ddk→(2π)dG~(k→)))\begin{document}$$\begin{aligned} \frac{1}{Z_v}\int^{ +\infty}_{ -\infty}D[\hat{\psi}^{\alpha}]e^{S_v} NA &= \displaystyle N(z)^{-\frac{n}{2}}\int \mathrm{d}\sigma p(\sigma)\int^{L}_{-L}\frac{\mathrm{d}^d\vec{x}_0}{V}\prod_{\alpha, \beta} \left[\det(K_{\alpha\beta}^{-1}G_{\alpha\beta})\right]^{-\frac{1}{2}}\\ &= \displaystyle N(z)^{-\frac{n}{2}}\int \mathrm{d}\sigma p(\sigma)\int^{L}_{-L}\frac{\mathrm{d}^d\vec{x}_0}{V}\prod_{\alpha} \left[\det(K_{\alpha\alpha}^{-1}G_{\alpha\alpha})\right]^{-\frac{1}{2}}\\ &= \displaystyle N(z)^{-\frac{n}{2}}\int \mathrm{d}\sigma p(\sigma)\int^{L}_{-L}\frac{\mathrm{d}^d\vec{x}_0}{V}\prod_{\alpha}(1-\frac{\sigma^2}{z}G_{\alpha\alpha}(\vec{x}_0,\vec{x}_0))^{-\frac{1}{2}}\\ &= \displaystyle N(z)^{-\frac{n}{2}}\int \mathrm{d}\sigma p(\sigma)\prod_{\alpha}(1-\frac{\sigma^2}{z}G_{\alpha\alpha}(0))^{-\frac{1}{2}}\\ &= \displaystyle N(z)^{-\frac{n}{2}}\int \mathrm{d}\sigma p(\sigma)\exp(-\frac{1}{2}\mathrm{Tr}_n \ln(1-\frac{\sigma^2}{z}\int \frac{\mathrm{d}^d \vec{k}}{(2\pi)^d} \tilde G(\vec{k})))\end{aligned}$$\end{document}

In sum, the variational free energy Fv\begin{document}$ F_{v}$\end{document} is equal to(S60)Fv=∑α12Tr(f−1Gαα)−∑α,β12ln⁡(det(Gαβ))−N(z)−n2∫dσp(σ)exp⁡(−12Trnln⁡(1−σ2z∫ddk→(2π)dG~(k→)))=∑αV2∫ddk→(2π)dG~(k→)f~(k→)−V2∫ddk→(2π)d∑α,βln⁡(G~αβ(k→))−N(z)−n2∫dσp(σ)exp⁡(−12Trnln⁡(1−σ2z∫ddk→(2π)dG~(k→)))\begin{document}$$\begin{aligned} F_v = & \, \displaystyle \sum_{\alpha} \frac{1}{2}\mathrm{Tr}(f^{-1}G_{\alpha \alpha})- \sum_{\alpha,\beta} \frac{1}{2}\ln(\det(G_{\alpha \beta}))\\&- N(z)^{-\frac{n}{2}}\int \mathrm{d}\sigma p(\sigma)\exp(-\frac{1}{2}\mathrm{Tr}_n \ln(1-\frac{\sigma^2}{z}\int \frac{\mathrm{d}^d \vec{k}}{(2\pi)^d} \tilde G(\vec{k})))\\ = & \, \displaystyle \sum_{\alpha} \frac{V}{2}\int \frac{\mathrm{d}^d \vec{k}}{(2\pi)^d} \frac{\tilde G(\vec{k})}{\tilde f(\vec{k})}-\frac{V}{2} \int \frac{\mathrm{d}^d \vec{k}}{(2\pi)^d} \sum_{\alpha,\beta} \ln(\tilde G_{\alpha \beta}(\vec{k}))\\ & \displaystyle - N(z)^{-\frac{n}{2}}\int \mathrm{d}\sigma p(\sigma)\exp(-\frac{1}{2}\mathrm{Tr}_n \ln(1-\frac{\sigma^2}{z}\int \frac{\mathrm{d}^d \vec{k}}{(2\pi)^d} \tilde G(\vec{k})))\end{aligned}$$\end{document}

Now let us find the best quadratic action Sv\begin{document}$ S_{v}$\end{document} that minimizes the variational free energy Fv\begin{document}$ F_{v}$\end{document}(S61)δFvδG~αβ=0\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \frac{\delta F_v}{\delta \tilde G_{\alpha\beta}} = 0$$\end{document}

The solution of Equation S61 is given by(S62)G~αβ−1(k→)=δαβG~−1(k→)\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \tilde G_{\alpha\beta}^{-1} (\vec{k}) = \delta_{\alpha \beta} \tilde G^{-1} (\vec{k})$$\end{document}(S63)1f~(k→)−∫dσp(σ)ρσ2z−σ2∫Dk→G~(k→)−1G~(k→)=0\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \frac{1}{\tilde f(\vec{k})} - \int \mathrm{d}\sigma p(\sigma)\frac{\rho \sigma^2}{z-\sigma^2\int \textrm{D}\vec{k} \; \tilde G(\vec{k})}- \frac{1}{\tilde G(\vec{k})} = 0$$\end{document}

where ∫Dk→≡∫ddk→(2π)d\begin{document}$ \int\mathrm{D}\vec{k}\equiv\int\frac{\mathrm{d}^{d}\vec{k}}{(2\pi)^{d}}$\end{document}. By using Equation S117, we finally obtain(S64)g(z)=limn→02nN∂∂zF1≈limn→02nN∂∂zFv=∫dσp(σ)1z−σ2∫Dk→G~(k→)\begin{document}$$\displaystyle g(z) = \lim\limits_{n \to 0} \frac{2}{nN} \frac{\partial}{\partial z} F_1\approx\lim\limits_{n \to 0} \frac{2}{nN} \frac{\partial}{\partial z} F_v= \int \mathrm{d}\sigma p(\sigma)\frac{1}{z-\sigma^2 \int \textrm{D}\vec{k} \; \tilde G(\vec{k})}$$\end{document}

sec.title: Scale invariance of the covariance spectrum in the Gaussian variational Model
sec.p: In Result, we point to two factors that contribute to the scale invariance of eigenspectrum using the high-density theory. In this section, we show that the same conclusion can be drawn by using the Gaussian variational method. Furthermore, we examine how the heterogeneity of neural activity influences the eigendensity calculated by the Gaussian variational model. We show that ∂p(λ)∂ρ\begin{document}$ \frac{\partial p(\lambda)}{\partial\rho}$\end{document}, which characterizes the change of eigendensity due to sampling in the functional space, decreases with the heterogeneity of neural activity described by higher-order moment of neural activity variance, for example, E(σ4)\begin{document}$ \mathrm{E}(\sigma^{4})$\end{document}.

Let us rewrite Equation S63 as(S65)G=∫Dk→G~(k→)=∫Dk→f~(k→)1−M(z)f~(k→)M(z)=∫dσp(σ)ρσ2z−σ2G(z)\begin{document}$$ \begin{aligned} \displaystyle\mathcal{G} = \int \mathrm{D}\vec{k} \; \tilde G(\vec{k}) & = \displaystyle\int \mathrm{D}\vec{k} \;\frac{\tilde f(\vec{k})}{1-M(z)\tilde f(\vec{k})}\\ M(z) & = \displaystyle \int \mathrm{d}\sigma p(\sigma)\frac{\rho \sigma^2}{z-\sigma^2 \mathcal{G}(z)}\end{aligned}$$\end{document}

To present a formal expression for the eigendensity, let us define Re(G)≡gr\begin{document}$ \mathbf{Re}(\mathcal{G})\equiv g_{r}$\end{document}, Im(G)≡gi\begin{document}$ \mathbf{Im}(\mathcal{G})\equiv g_{i}$\end{document}. From Equations S6 and S64, we find(S66)p(λ,ρ)=1π⟨σ2gi(λ−σ2gr)2+σ4gi2⟩σ,\begin{document}$$\displaystyle p(\lambda,\rho) = \frac{1}{\pi}\left \langle \frac{\sigma^2 g_i}{(\lambda -\sigma^2 g_r)^2+\sigma^4 g_i^2} \right \rangle_{\sigma},$$\end{document}
where ⟨...⟩σ=∫...p(σ)dσ\begin{document}$ \langle...\rangle_{\sigma}=\int...p(\sigma)\mathrm{d}\sigma$\end{document}.

A direct computation of Equation S66, however, remains difficult: the complication arises from the complex function M(z)\begin{document}$ M(z)$\end{document} in Equation S65, which in turn is an integral function of G\begin{document}$ \mathcal{G}$\end{document}. To streamline the calculation, let us further define Re(M)≡ρa\begin{document}$ \mathbf{Re}(M)\equiv\rho a$\end{document}, Im(M)≡ρb\begin{document}$ \mathbf{Im}(M)\equiv\rho b$\end{document}. Writing it down explicitly, we have(S67)a=⟨σ2(λ−σ2gr)(λ−σ2gr)2+σ4gi2⟩σ\begin{document}$$\displaystyle a =\left \langle \frac{\sigma^2 (\lambda - \sigma^2g_r)}{(\lambda -\sigma^2g_r)^2+\sigma^4 g_i^2} \right\rangle_{\sigma}$$\end{document}(S68)b=⟨σ4gi(λ−σ2gr)2+σ4gi2⟩σ\begin{document}$$\displaystyle b =\left \langle \frac{\sigma^4 g_i}{(\lambda -\sigma^2g_r)^2+\sigma^4 g_i^2} \right\rangle_{\sigma}$$\end{document}

The real and imaginary part of G\begin{document}$\mathcal{G}$\end{document} can now be expressed as functions of a and b. Integrating Equation S65 in the spherical coordinates, we have(S69)gr(ρ)=Sd−1(2π)d∫π/Lπ/ϵdkkd−1f~(k)[1−ρaf~(k)][1−ρaf~(k)]2+ρ2b2f~2(k)gi(ρ)=Sd−1(2π)d∫π/Lπ/ϵdkkd−1ρbf~2(k)[1−ρaf~(k)]2+ρ2b2f~2(k)\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \begin{aligned} g_r(\rho) &= \displaystyle\frac{S_{d-1}}{(2\pi)^d}\int_{\pi/L}^{\pi/\epsilon}\textrm{d}k k^{d-1} \;\frac{\tilde f(k)[1-\rho a \tilde f(k)]}{[1-\rho a\tilde f(k)]^2+\rho^2b^2\tilde f^2(k)} \\ g_i(\rho) &= \displaystyle\frac{S_{d-1}}{(2\pi)^d}\int_{\pi/L}^{\pi/\epsilon}\textrm{d}kk^{d-1} \;\frac{ \rho b\tilde f^2(k)}{[1-\rho a\tilde f(k)]^2+\rho^2b^2\tilde f^2(k)}\end{aligned}$$\end{document}

where for clarity, we have abused the notation a bit by defining k=‖k→‖;Sd−1\begin{document}$ k=\|\vec{k}\|;S_{d-1}$\end{document} is the surface area of unit d\begin{document}$ d$\end{document}-ball in the momentum space. In order to evaluate the integrals analytically, we introduce an ultraviolet cutoff π/ϵ\begin{document}$ \pi/\epsilon$\end{document}. Numerically, whether integrating up to π/ϵ\begin{document}$ \pi/\epsilon$\end{document} or greater than this bound shows little difference.

sec.title: Numerical solution of the Gaussian variational method
sec.p: With Equations S66–S69, we numerically calculate the eigendensity iteratively from the following steps:

list-item.p: Step 1: set the initial values of a and b as a0=1\begin{document}$ a_{0}=1$\end{document}, b0=1\begin{document}$ b_{0}=1$\end{document}
Step 2: solve for a in Equation S67 with fixed b
Step 3: solve for b in Equation S68 with fixed a
Step 5: calculate p(λ)\begin{document}$ p(\lambda)$\end{document} using Equation S66

sec.p: Note that we plug Equation S69 into Equations S67 and S68 in step 2–3.

sec.title: Two contributing factors on the scale invariance
sec.p: We next derive an analytical expression for Equation S69 by considering the approximate power law kernel function f(x→)≈ϵμ‖x→‖−μ, μ>0\begin{document}$f(\vec{x})\approx\epsilon^{\mu}\|\vec{x}\|^{-\mu},\ \mu \gt 0$\end{document}, from which the high-density theory results on the scale invariance can be extended.

By a change of variable x=f~(k)∼ϵμk−(d−μ)\begin{document}$ x=\tilde{f}(k)\sim\epsilon^{\mu}k^{-(d-\mu)}$\end{document}, and let xϵ≡f~(πϵ)\begin{document}$ x_{\epsilon}\equiv\tilde{f}(\frac{\pi}{\epsilon})$\end{document}, xL≡f~(πL)\begin{document}$ x_{L}\equiv\tilde{f}(\frac{\pi}{L})$\end{document}, we have(S70)gi(ρ)∼ϵμdd−μd−μ∫xϵxLdxρbx−μd−μ[1−ρax]2+ρ2b2x2,\begin{document}$$\displaystyle g_i(\rho) \sim \frac{\epsilon^{\frac{\mu d}{d-\mu}}}{d-\mu}\int_{x_\epsilon}^{x_L}\mathrm{d}x\frac{\rho bx^{-\frac{\mu}{d-\mu}}}{[1-\rho ax]^2+\rho^2b^2x^2},$$\end{document}

where ∼ indicates that all constant numerical factors (e.g., π and Γ(d/2)\begin{document}$ \Gamma(d/2)$\end{document}) are ignored. To compute Equation S70, we perform a branch cut at [0,∞]\begin{document}$ [0,\infty]$\end{document}, and perform a contour integral on the complex plane following the path in , Appendix 2—figure 1A. When 0<β=1−μd−μ<2\begin{document}$ 0 \lt \beta=1-\frac{\mu}{d-\mu} \lt 2$\end{document}, the integral on the large circle ΓR\begin{document}$ \Gamma_{R}$\end{document} and the small circle Γϵ\begin{document}$ \Gamma_{\epsilon}$\end{document} goes to zero as xL→∞,xϵ→0\begin{document}$ x_{L}\rightarrow\infty,x_{\epsilon}\rightarrow 0$\end{document}, leaving only two simple poles (zeros of the function in the denominator) in the complex plane. By applying the residue theorem, we find an expression for gi\begin{document}$ g_{i}$\end{document} in the limit L→∞,ϵ→0\begin{document}$ L\rightarrow\infty,\epsilon\rightarrow 0$\end{document}(S71)cos⁡θ=−aa2+b2β=d−2μd−μgi∼−ϵμdd−μd−μsin⁡(β−1)θsin⁡θsin⁡πβπbρ1−β(a2+b2)β/2\begin{document}$$\begin{aligned} \cos\theta &= \displaystyle -\frac{a}{\sqrt{a^2+b^2}} \\ \beta &= \displaystyle \frac{d-2\mu}{d-\mu} \\ g_i &\sim \displaystyle -\frac{\epsilon^{\frac{\mu d}{d-\mu}}}{d-\mu}\frac{\sin (\beta -1)\theta}{\sin \theta \sin \pi\beta}\frac{\pi b \rho^{1-\beta} }{(a^2+b^2)^{\beta/2}}\end{aligned}$$\end{document}

The analytical expression for gr\begin{document}$ g_{r}$\end{document} is a bit more involving.(S72)gr(ρ)∼ϵμdd−μd−μ∫xϵxLdxx−dd−μ[1−ρax]2+ρ2b2x2−abgi\begin{document}$$\displaystyle g_r(\rho) \sim \frac{\epsilon^{\frac{\mu d}{d-\mu}}}{d-\mu}\int_{x_\epsilon}^{x_L}\mathrm{d}x\frac{x^{-\frac{d}{d-\mu}}}{[1-\rho ax]^2+\rho^2b^2x^2} - \frac{a}{b} g_i$$\end{document}

It has two terms, the second term is similar to Equation S70; the first term, however, diverges as xϵ→0\begin{document}$x_{\epsilon}\rightarrow 0$\end{document}. Thus, the radius of the small circle Γϵ\begin{document}$ \Gamma_{\epsilon}$\end{document} in Appendix 2—figure 1 cannot shrink to zero: this is precisely the requirement of an ultraviolet cutoff in the wave vector k→\begin{document}$ \vec{k}$\end{document}. The contour integral on the large circle ΓR\begin{document}$ \Gamma_{R}$\end{document}, on the other hand, goes to zero as xL→∞\begin{document}$ x_{L}\rightarrow\infty$\end{document}. Thus, the integral on Γϵ\begin{document}$ \Gamma_{\epsilon}$\end{document} contributes to the final result. By considering leading order term of xϵ\begin{document}$ x_{\epsilon}$\end{document} for finite but small xϵ\begin{document}$x_{\epsilon}$\end{document}, we find(S73)cos⁡θ=−aa2+b2γ=−μd−μgr∼−ϵμdd−μd−μxϵγγ−ϵμdd−μd−μsin⁡(γ−1)θsin⁡θsin⁡πγπρ−γ(a2+b2)γ/2−abgi\begin{document}$$\begin{aligned} \cos\theta &= \displaystyle -\frac{a}{\sqrt{a^2+b^2}} \\ \gamma &= \displaystyle \frac{-\mu}{d-\mu} \\g_r & \sim \displaystyle - \frac{\epsilon^{\frac{\mu d}{d-\mu}}}{d-\mu}\frac{x_\epsilon^\gamma}{\gamma} - \frac{\epsilon^{\frac{\mu d}{d-\mu}}}{d-\mu}\frac{\sin (\gamma -1)\theta}{\sin \theta \sin \pi\gamma}\frac{\pi \rho^{-\gamma} }{(a^2+b^2)^{\gamma/2}} - \frac{a}{b} g_i\end{aligned}$$\end{document}

Recall xϵ∼ϵμ(π/ϵ)d−μ\begin{document}$ x_{\epsilon}\sim\frac{\epsilon^{\mu}}{(\pi/\epsilon)^{d-\mu}}$\end{document}, and we find that the first term in gr\begin{document}$ g_{r}$\end{document} is proportional to πμ/μ\begin{document}$ \pi^{\mu}/\mu$\end{document}, independent of ε.

caption.title: Calculate gi\begin{document}$ g_{i}$\end{document} and gr\begin{document}$ g_{r}$\end{document}.
caption.p: (A) The path of the contour integral for gi\begin{document}$ g_{i}$\end{document}, gr\begin{document}$ g_{r}$\end{document} (Equation S70). The heatmap of gr\begin{document}$ g_{r}$\end{document} and gi\begin{document}$ g_{i}$\end{document} with respect to λ and ρ, gr\begin{document}$ g_{r}$\end{document} in (B, C) are calculated by the numerical method (Methods). The parameters are N=1024\begin{document}$ N=1024$\end{document}, ρ=10.24\begin{document}$ \rho=10.24$\end{document}, d=2\begin{document}$ d=2$\end{document}, L=10\begin{document}$ L=10$\end{document}, μ=0.5\begin{document}$ \mu=0.5$\end{document}, ϵ=0.03125\begin{document}$\epsilon=0.03125$\end{document} is i.i.d. sampled from a log-normal distribution with zero mean and a standard deviation of 0.5 in the natural logarithm of the σi2\begin{document}$ \sigma_{i}^{2}$\end{document} values; we also normalize E(σi2)=1\begin{document}$ \mathrm{E}(\sigma_{i}^{2})=1$\end{document}.

sec.p: According to Equation S71 and S73, one can immediately see that as μ/d→0\begin{document}$ \mu/d\rightarrow 0$\end{document}, the ρ-dependence relationship vanishes for gr\begin{document}$ g_{r}$\end{document} and gi\begin{document}$ g_{i}$\end{document}. We therefore conclude that a slower power-law decay in the kernel function and/or a higher dimension of the functional space are two contributing factors for the scale invariance of the covariance spectrum.

sec.title: Heterogeneity of neural activity across neurons enhances scale invariance
sec.p: Next, we take a more close look at how the eigendensity changes with ρ for finite but small μ/d\begin{document}$ \mu/d$\end{document} and when λ≫1\begin{document}$ \lambda\gg 1$\end{document}. Using Equation S66, we have(S74)∂p∂ρ=1π⟨∂gi∂ρσ2[(λ−σ2gr)2+σ4gi2]−2σ6gi2[(λ−σ2gr)2+σ4gi2]2+∂gr∂ρ2σ4gi(λ−σ2gr)[(λ−σ2gr)2+σ4gi2]2⟩σ\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \frac{\partial p}{\partial \rho} = \frac{1}{\pi} \left\langle \frac{\partial g_i}{\partial \rho} \frac{\sigma^2\left[(\lambda-\sigma^2 g_r)^2 +\sigma^4 g_i^2 \right] - 2\sigma^6 g_i^2}{\left[(\lambda - \sigma^2g_r)^2 + \sigma^4 g_i^2\right]^2} +\frac{\partial g_r}{\partial \rho}\frac{2\sigma^4g_i (\lambda-\sigma^2 g_r)}{\left[(\lambda - \sigma^2g_r)^2 + \sigma^4 g_i^2\right]^2}\right\rangle_{\sigma}$$\end{document}

From numerical calculation, we find that typically gr≫gi\begin{document}$ g_{r}\gg g_{i}$\end{document}, so one can use the approximation(S75)∂p∂ρ≈1π⟨∂gi∂ρσ2(λ−σ2gr)2+σ4gi2⟩σ+1π⟨∂gr∂ρ2σ4gi(λ−σ2gr)3⟩σ\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \frac{\partial p}{\partial \rho}\approx \frac{1}{\pi}\left\langle \frac{\partial g_i}{\partial \rho}\frac{\sigma^2}{(\lambda - \sigma^2g_r)^2+\sigma^4 g_i^2}\right\rangle_{\sigma} + \frac{1}{\pi}\left\langle\frac{\partial g_r}{\partial \rho}\frac{2\sigma^4g_i}{(\lambda - \sigma^2g_r)^3}\right\rangle_{\sigma} $$\end{document}

Recall Equation S66(S76)p(λ,ρ)=1π⟨σ2gi(λ−σ2gr)2+σ4gi2⟩σ,\begin{document}$$\displaystyle p(\lambda,\rho) = \frac{1}{\pi}\left \langle \frac{\sigma^2 g_i}{(\lambda -\sigma^2 g_r)^2+\sigma^4 g_i^2} \right \rangle_{\sigma},$$\end{document}

Since p(λ,ρ)\begin{document}$ p(\lambda,\rho)$\end{document} is very small for large λ, a more appropriate measure is to examine(S77)∂log⁡p∂ρ≡1p∂p∂ρ≈∂gi∂ρ1gi+2∂gr∂ρ⟨σ4(λ−σ2gr)3⟩σ⟨σ2(λ−σ2gr)2⟩σ\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \frac{\partial \log p}{\partial \rho} \equiv \frac{1}{p} \frac{\partial p}{\partial \rho} \approx \frac{\partial g_i}{\partial \rho}\frac{1}{g_i} + 2 \frac{\partial g_r}{\partial \rho} \frac{\left\langle\frac{\sigma^4}{(\lambda - \sigma^2g_r)^3}\right\rangle_{\sigma}}{\left \langle \frac{\sigma^2}{(\lambda -\sigma^2 g_r)^2} \right\rangle_{\sigma}}$$\end{document}

Considering the large eigenvalue case λ≫σ2gr\begin{document}$ \lambda\gg\sigma^{2}g_{r}$\end{document} (the numerical value of gr\begin{document}$ g_{r}$\end{document} is on the order of 1), we perform Taylor expansion and arrive at(S78)⟨σ2(λ−σ2gr)2⟩σ≈⟨σ2λ2+2σ4grλ3+3σ6gr2λ4⟩σ\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \left\langle\frac{\sigma^2}{(\lambda - \sigma^2g_r)^2}\right\rangle_{\sigma}\approx \left\langle\frac{\sigma^2}{\lambda^2} + \frac{2\sigma^4 g_r}{\lambda^3} + \frac{3\sigma^6 g_r^2}{\lambda^4}\right\rangle_{\sigma}$$\end{document}(S79)⟨σ4(λ−σ2gr)3⟩σ≈⟨σ4λ3+3σ6grλ4⟩σ\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \left\langle\frac{\sigma^4}{(\lambda - \sigma^2g_r)^3}\right\rangle_{\sigma}\approx \left\langle\frac{\sigma^4}{\lambda^3} + \frac{3\sigma^6 g_r}{\lambda^4}\right\rangle_{\sigma}$$\end{document}

Note ⟨σ2⟩σ≡E(σ2)\begin{document}$ \langle\sigma^{2}\rangle_{\sigma}\equiv\mathrm{E}(\sigma^{2})$\end{document} is normalized to 1.(S80)∂log⁡p∂ρ≈∂gi∂ρ1gi+2∂gr∂ρ⟨σ4(λ−σ2gr)3⟩σ⟨σ2(λ−σ2gr)2⟩σ≈∂gi∂ρ1gi+2∂gr∂ρ⟨σ4⟩σ+3grλ⟨σ6⟩σλ+2gr⟨σ4⟩σ+3gr2λ⟨σ6⟩σ\begin{document}$$\begin{aligned}\frac{\partial \log p}{\partial \rho} &\approx \displaystyle \frac{\partial g_i}{\partial \rho}\frac{1}{g_i} + 2 \frac{\partial g_r}{\partial \rho} \frac{\left\langle\frac{\sigma^4}{(\lambda - \sigma^2g_r)^3}\right\rangle_{\sigma}}{\left \langle \frac{\sigma^2}{(\lambda -\sigma^2 g_r)^2} \right\rangle_{\sigma}} \\ &\approx \displaystyle \frac{\partial g_i}{\partial \rho}\frac{1}{g_i} + 2 \frac{\partial g_r}{\partial \rho} \frac{\left\langle\sigma^4\right\rangle_{\sigma} + \frac{3 g_r}{\lambda} \left\langle\sigma^6\right\rangle_{\sigma}}{\lambda +2g_r\left\langle\sigma^4\right\rangle_{\sigma}+\frac{3 g_r^2}{\lambda} \left\langle\sigma^6\right\rangle_{\sigma}}\end{aligned}$$\end{document}

By examining Equations S71 and S73, we find that when λ≫gr\begin{document}$\lambda\gg g_{r}$\end{document}, a≫b\begin{document}$ a\gg b$\end{document}, θ≈π\begin{document}$\theta\approx\pi$\end{document}, gr\begin{document}$g_{r}$\end{document} decays weakly with ρ while gi\begin{document}$g_{i}$\end{document} increases weakly with ρ (also confirmed by numerical calculation, Figure 1B, C)∂gr∂ρ<0, ∂gi∂ρ>0.\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \frac{\partial g_{r}}{\partial\rho} \lt 0,\ \frac{\partial g_{i}}{\partial\rho} \gt 0.$$\end{document}

It is therefore straightforward to see from 80 that the higher-order moment (e.g., E(σ4)\begin{document}$ \mathrm{E}(\sigma^{4})$\end{document}) in the activity variance contributes to reducing the ρ\begin{document}$\rho$\end{document}-dependence in the eigendensity function.

sec.title: The relationship between CI and eigendensity
sec.p: In this section, we show how the CI introduced in Methods is related to Equation S80, namely how the eigendensity changes with the neuronal density in the functional space. Recall the definition of CI in Equation S13:CI:=1log⁡(q0/q1)∫log⁡q1log⁡q0|∂log⁡λ(q)∂log⁡ρ|dlog⁡q\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \mathrm{CI}:=\frac{1}{\log(q_{0}/q_{1})}\int_{\log q_{1}}^{\log q_{0}}\left|\frac{\partial\log\lambda(q)}{\partial\log\rho}\right|\mathrm{d}\log q$$\end{document}
whereq(λ)=∫λ∞p(λ)dλ\begin{document}$$\displaystyle q(\lambda)=\int_{\lambda}^{\infty}p(\lambda)\mathrm{d}\lambda$$\end{document}

we used implicit differentiation to compute ∂log⁡λ(q)∂log⁡ρ\begin{document}$\frac{\partial\log\lambda(q)}{\partial\log\rho}$\end{document}. For clarity, we write the function q(λ,ρ)\begin{document}$ q(\lambda,\rho)$\end{document} explicitly involving λ and ρ as Q(λ,ρ)\begin{document}$ Q(\lambda,\rho)$\end{document} in Equations S81–S83.(S81)F(λ(q,ρ),q,ρ)=Q(λ(q,ρ),ρ)−q≡0\begin{document}$$\displaystyle F(\lambda(q,\rho),q,\rho) = Q(\lambda(q,\rho),\rho) - q \equiv 0$$\end{document}(S82)dF(λ(q,ρ),q,ρ)dρ=∂F(λ(q,ρ),q,ρ)∂ρ+∂F(λ(q,ρ),q,ρ)∂λ∂λ(q,ρ)∂ρ=0\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \frac{\mathrm{d} F(\lambda(q,\rho),q,\rho)}{\mathrm{d} \rho} = \frac{\partial F(\lambda(q,\rho),q,\rho)}{\partial \rho} + \frac{\partial F(\lambda(q,\rho),q,\rho)}{\partial \lambda} \frac{\partial \lambda(q,\rho)}{\partial \rho} = 0$$\end{document}(S83)∂λ(q,ρ)∂ρ=−∂F(λ(q,ρ),q,ρ)∂ρ∂F(λ(q,ρ),q,ρ)∂λ=−∂Q(λ(q,ρ),ρ)∂ρ∂Q(λ(q,ρ),ρ)∂λ\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \frac{\partial \lambda(q,\rho)}{\partial \rho} = - \frac{\frac{\partial F(\lambda(q,\rho),q,\rho)}{\partial \rho}}{\frac{\partial F(\lambda(q,\rho),q,\rho)}{\partial \lambda} } = - \frac{\frac{\partial Q(\lambda(q,\rho),\rho)}{\partial \rho}}{\frac{\partial Q(\lambda(q,\rho),\rho)}{\partial \lambda} }$$\end{document}

Now we can write CI as(S84)∂log⁡λ(q,ρ)∂log⁡ρ=ρλ(q,ρ)∂λ(q,ρ)∂ρ=−ρλ(q,ρ)∂q(ρ,λ)∂ρ∂q(ρ,λ)∂λ\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \frac{\partial \log \lambda(q, \rho)}{\partial\log \rho} = \frac{\rho}{\lambda(q, \rho)} \frac{\partial \lambda(q, \rho)}{\partial \rho} = - \frac{\rho}{\lambda(q, \rho)} \frac{\frac{\partial q(\rho,\lambda)}{\partial \rho} }{\frac{\partial q(\rho,\lambda)}{\partial \lambda}} $$\end{document}

from which we arrive at Equation S15 in Methods:(S85)CI=1log⁡(q0/q1)∫log⁡q1log⁡q0|∂log⁡λ(q,ρ)∂log⁡ρ|dlog⁡q=1log⁡(q0/q1)∫q1q0|−ρqλ∂q∂ρ∂q∂λ|dq=1log⁡(q0/q1)∫λ(q1)λ(q0)|−ρqλ∂q∂ρ∂q∂λ|∂q∂λdλ=1log⁡(q0/q1)∫λ(q0)λ(q1)|ρqλ∂q∂ρ|dλ\begin{document}$$\begin{aligned} \mathrm{CI} &= \displaystyle \frac{1}{\log (q_0/q_1)}\int_{\log q_1}^{\log q_0} \left| \frac{\partial \log \lambda(q,\rho)}{\partial\log \rho}\right| \mathrm{d} \log q = \frac{1}{\log (q_0/q_1)}\int_{q_1}^{q_0} \left| - \frac{\rho}{q \lambda} \frac{\frac{\partial q}{\partial \rho} }{\frac{\partial q}{\partial \lambda}} \right| \mathrm{d} q \\ &= \displaystyle \frac{1}{\log (q_0/q_1)}\int_{\lambda(q_1)}^{\lambda(q_0)} \left| - \frac{\rho}{q \lambda} \frac{\frac{\partial q}{\partial \rho} }{\frac{\partial q}{\partial \lambda}} \right|\frac{\partial q}{\partial \lambda} \mathrm{d} \lambda = \frac{1}{\log (q_0/q_1)}\int_{\lambda(q_0)}^{\lambda(q_1)} \left| \frac{\rho}{q \lambda} \frac{\partial q}{\partial \rho} \right| \mathrm{d} \lambda\end{aligned}$$\end{document}

Finally, we can rewrite CI as a function of ∂p∂ρ\begin{document}$ \frac{\partial p}{\partial\rho}$\end{document} using a double integral:(S86)CI=1log⁡(q0/q1)∫λ(q0)λ(q1)|ρqλ∂q∂ρ|dλ=1log⁡(q0/q1)∫λ(q0)λ(q1)dλ1|ρqλ1∫λ1∞dλ2∂p(λ2)∂ρ|=1log⁡(q0/q1)∫λ(q0)λ(q1)1λ1dλ1|∫λ1∞dλ2p(λ2)∂ln⁡p(λ2)∂ln⁡ρ∫λ1∞dλ2p(λ2)|\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \begin{aligned} \mathrm{CI} &= \displaystyle \frac{1}{\log (q_0/q_1)}\int_{\lambda(q_0)}^{\lambda(q_1)} \left| \frac{\rho}{q \lambda} \frac{\partial q}{\partial \rho} \right| \mathrm{d} \lambda = \frac{1}{\log (q_0/q_1)}\int_{\lambda(q_0)}^{\lambda(q_1)} \mathrm{d} \lambda_1 \left| \frac{\rho}{q \lambda_1} \int_{\lambda_1}^\infty \mathrm{d} \lambda_2 \frac{\partial p(\lambda_2)}{\partial \rho} \right| \\ &= \displaystyle \frac{1}{\log (q_0/q_1)}\int_{\lambda(q_0)}^{\lambda(q_1)} \frac{1}{\lambda_1} \mathrm{d} \lambda_1 \left| \frac{\int_{\lambda_1}^\infty \mathrm{d} \lambda_2 p(\lambda_2)\frac{\partial \ln p(\lambda_2)}{\partial \ln \rho}}{\int_{\lambda_1}^\infty \mathrm{d} \lambda_2 p(\lambda_2)} \right|\end{aligned}$$\end{document}

sec.title: Compare high-density theory and Gaussian variational method
sec.p: This section aims to determine the conditions under which the high-density approximation aligns with the simulation results. To this end, we begin by comparing the kernel operator G~h(k→)\begin{document}$\tilde{G}_{h}(\vec{k})$\end{document} in the high-density quadratic action and G~v(k→)\begin{document}$ \tilde{G}_{v}(\vec{k})$\end{document} in the variational approximation. We identify the condition when high-density theory would agree with the variational method as well as the numerical simulation, namely z≫∫ddk→(2π)dG~v(k→)\begin{document}$ z\gg\int\frac{\mathrm{d}^{d}\vec{k}}{(2\pi)^{d}}\tilde{G}_{v}(\vec{k})$\end{document}. Secondly, we give a precise re-derivation of the high-density result by incorporating this condition into the variational approximation. Finally, we substitute ∫ddk→(2π)dG~v(k→)\begin{document}$ \int\frac{\mathrm{d}^{d}\vec{k}}{(2\pi)^{d}}\tilde{G}_{v}(\vec{k})$\end{document} with ∫ddk→(2π)dG~h(k→)\begin{document}$ \int\frac{\mathrm{d}^{d}\vec{k}}{(2\pi)^{d}}\tilde{G}_{h}(\vec{k})$\end{document} and estimate the parameter regime where the high-density theory would agree with numerical simulation. This analysis yields a deeper understanding of the relationship between high-density theory and variational method, and how they relate to simulation results.

sec.title: A simple comparison of the two methods
sec.p: For the sake of simplicity, we consider the correlation matrix with p(σ)=δ(σ−1)\begin{document}$ p(\sigma)=\delta(\sigma-1)$\end{document} in this section. Returning to the explicit result Equation S29–S31 ,(S87)⟨Ξn(z)⟩=(detf)−n/2(z)−Nn2∫−∞+∞D[ψ^α]eS1\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \left \langle \Xi^n(z) \right \rangle =(\det f)^{-n/2}(z)^{-\frac{Nn}{2}}\int^{ +\infty}_{ -\infty}D[\hat{\psi}^{\alpha}]e^{S_1}$$\end{document}

In the high-density approximation (Equation S35)(S88)Sh=∫−LLddx→VN2z∑α=1nψ^α(x→)2−12∑α=1n∫−∞+∞dx→dx→′f−1(x→−x→′)ψ^α(x→)ψ^α(x→′)=−12∑α=1n∫−∞+∞dx→dx→′Gh−1(x→−x→′)ψ^α(x→)ψ^α(x→′)\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \begin{aligned} S_h &= \displaystyle \int^{L}_{-L}\frac{\mathrm{d}^d\vec{x}}{V}\frac{N}{2z}\sum\limits_{\alpha=1}^{n}\hat{\psi}^{\alpha}(\vec{x})^2 - \frac{1}{2}\sum\limits_{\alpha=1}^{n}\int^{ +\infty}_{ -\infty}\mathrm{d}\vec{x}\mathrm{d}\vec{x}'f^{-1}(\vec{x}-\vec{x}')\hat{\psi}^{\alpha}(\vec{x})\hat{\psi}^{\alpha}(\vec{x}')\\ &= \displaystyle -\frac{1}{2}\sum\limits_{\alpha=1}^{n}\int^{ +\infty}_{ -\infty}\mathrm{d}\vec{x}\mathrm{d}\vec{x}'G_h^{-1}(\vec{x}-\vec{x}')\hat{\psi}^{\alpha}(\vec{x})\hat{\psi}^{\alpha}(\vec{x}')\end{aligned}$$\end{document}

Here, we introduce Gh\begin{document}$ G_{h}$\end{document} as the kernel operator in the high-density quadratic action.(S89)Gh−1(x→−y→)=f−1(x→−y→)−NVzδ(x→−y→)\begin{document}$$\displaystyle G_h^{-1}(\vec{x}-\vec{y}) = f^{-1}(\vec{x}-\vec{y})-\frac{N}{Vz}\delta(\vec{x}-\vec{y}) $$\end{document}

Fourier transform of Gh\begin{document}$ G_{h}$\end{document} leads to(S90)G~h(k→)=f~(k→)1−ρzf~(k→)\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \tilde G_h(\vec{k}) = \frac{\tilde f(\vec{k})}{1 - \frac{\rho}{z} \tilde f(\vec{k})}$$\end{document}

In the variational method Equation S63, we have(S91)G~v(k→)=f~(k→)1−Cf~(k→),C=ρz−∫ddk→(2π)dG~v(k→),\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \tilde G_v(\vec{k}) = \frac{\tilde f(\vec{k})}{1 - C \tilde f(\vec{k})} \hspace{1em}, \hspace{1em}C = \frac{\rho}{z - \int \frac{\mathrm{d}^d \vec{k}}{(2\pi)^d} \tilde G_v(\vec{k})},$$\end{document}

where we introduce Gv\begin{document}$ G_{v}$\end{document} as the kernel operator in the variational quadratic action. Clearly, the condition that G~v(k→)\begin{document}$ \tilde{G}_{v}(\vec{k})$\end{document} approaches G~h(k→)\begin{document}$ \tilde{G}_{h}(\vec{k})$\end{document} is given byC→ρz,z≫∫ddk→(2π)dG~v(k→)\begin{document}$$\displaystyle C\to\frac{\rho}{z}\hskip 10.0pt,\hskip 10.0ptz\gg\int\frac{\mathrm{d}^{d}\vec{k}}{(2\pi)^{d}}\tilde{G}_{v}(\vec{k})$$\end{document}

The function ratiov(z)\begin{document}$ratio_{v}(z)$\end{document} is defined as:ratiov(z)=1z∫ddk→(2π)dG~v(k→)\begin{document}$$\displaystyle ratio_{v}(z)=\frac{1}{z}\int\frac{\mathrm{d}^{d}\vec{k}}{(2\pi)^{d}}\tilde{G}_{v}(\vec{k})$$\end{document}

As ratiov(z)\begin{document}$ ratio_{v}(z)$\end{document} approaches 0, G~v(k→)\begin{document}$ \tilde{G}_{v}(\vec{k})$\end{document} becomes identical to G~h(k→)\begin{document}$ \tilde{G}_{h}(\vec{k})$\end{document}. Note that G~v(k→)\begin{document}$ \tilde{G}_{v}(\vec{k})$\end{document} is difficult to compute; instead, we can compute and analyze ∫ddk→(2π)dG~h(k→)\begin{document}$\int\frac{\mathrm{d}^{d}\vec{k}}{(2\pi)^{d}}\tilde{G}_{h}(\vec{k})$\end{document} (see Appendix 2)(S92)ratioh(z)=1z∫ddk→(2π)dG~h(k→)\begin{document}$$\displaystyle ratio_h(z) = \frac{1}{z} \int \frac{\mathrm{d}^d \vec{k}}{(2\pi)^d} \tilde G_h(\vec{k})$$\end{document}

sec.title: A re-derivation of the high-density result using the grand canonical ensemble
sec.p: In this section, we re-derive the high-density result from the grand canonical ensemble and the variational method. The derivation also allows us to reproduce the approximation condition discussed in the previous section.

Let us recall the calculation of the free energy Fv\begin{document}$ F_{v}$\end{document} (Equation S60) in the variational approximation with p(σ)=δ(σ−1)\begin{document}$ p(\sigma)=\delta(\sigma-1)$\end{document}(S93)Fv=V2Trn∫ddk→(2π)dG~(k→)f~(k→)−N(z)−n2exp⁡(−12Trnlog⁡(1−1z∫ddk→(2π)dG~(k→)))−V2∫ddk→(2π)d∑α,βlog⁡(G~αβ(k→))=Vn2∫ddk→(2π)dG~(k→)f~(k→)−N(z)−n2[1−1z∫ddk→(2π)dG~(k→)]−n2−Vn2∫ddk→(2π)dlog⁡G~(k→)\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \begin{aligned} F_v &= \, \displaystyle \frac{V}{2}\mathrm{Tr}_n\int \frac{\mathrm{d}^d \vec{k}}{(2\pi)^d} \frac{\tilde G(\vec{k})}{\tilde f(\vec{k})}- N(z)^{-\frac{n}{2}}\exp(-\frac{1}{2}\mathrm{Tr}_n \log(1-\frac{1}{z}\int \frac{\mathrm{d}^d \vec{k}}{(2\pi)^d} \tilde G(\vec{k})))\\ & \displaystyle -\frac{V}{2} \int \frac{\mathrm{d}^d \vec{k}}{(2\pi)^d} \sum_{\alpha,\beta} \log(\tilde G_{\alpha \beta}(\vec{k}))\\ = & \, \displaystyle \frac{Vn}{2}\int \frac{\mathrm{d}^d \vec{k}}{(2\pi)^d} \frac{\tilde G(\vec{k})}{\tilde f(\vec{k})}- N(z)^{-\frac{n}{2}}\left[1-\frac{1}{z}\int \frac{\mathrm{d}^d \vec{k}}{(2\pi)^d} \tilde G(\vec{k})\right]^{-\frac{n}{2}}-\frac{Vn}{2} \int \frac{\mathrm{d}^d \vec{k}}{(2\pi)^d} \log\tilde G(\vec{k})\end{aligned}$$\end{document}(S94)limn→0Fv=Vn2∫ddk→(2π)dG~(k→)f~(k→)+Nn2log⁡[z−∫ddk→(2π)dG~(k→)]−Vn2∫ddk→(2π)dlog⁡G~(k→)+N\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \lim\limits_{n \to 0} F_v =\frac{Vn}{2}\int \frac{\mathrm{d}^d \vec{k}}{(2\pi)^d} \frac{\tilde G(\vec{k})}{\tilde f(\vec{k})}+ \frac{Nn}{2}\log \left[z-\int \frac{\mathrm{d}^d \vec{k}}{(2\pi)^d} \tilde G(\vec{k})\right]-\frac{Vn}{2} \int \frac{\mathrm{d}^d \vec{k}}{(2\pi)^d} \log\tilde G(\vec{k}) +N$$\end{document}

Following Equations S61 and S63:(S95)δFvδG~=0\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \frac{\delta F_v }{\delta \tilde G} = 0 $$\end{document}(S96)1f~(k→)−ρz−∫ddk→(2π)dG~(k→)−1G~(k→)=0\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \frac{1}{\tilde f(\vec{k})} - \frac{\rho}{z-\int \frac{\mathrm{d}^d \vec{k}}{(2\pi)^d} \tilde G(\vec{k})} -\frac{1}{\tilde G(\vec{k})} = 0$$\end{document}(S97)g(z)=limn→02nNddzF1≈limn→02nNddzFv=limn→02nN(∂∂zFv+∫ddk→(2π)d∂G~(k→)∂z∂∂G~(k→)Fv)=limn→02nN∂∂zFv=1z−∫ddk→(2π)dG~(k→)\begin{document}$$\begin{aligned} g(z) &= \displaystyle \lim\limits_{n \to 0} \frac{2}{nN} \frac{d}{d z} F_1\approx\lim\limits_{n \to 0} \frac{2}{nN} \frac{d}{d z} F_v=\lim\limits_{n \to 0} \frac{2}{nN} (\frac{\partial}{\partial z} F_v + \int \frac{\mathrm{d}^d \vec{k}}{(2\pi)^d} \frac{\partial \tilde G(\vec{k})}{\partial z}\frac{\partial}{\partial \tilde G(\vec{k})} F_v) \\ &= \displaystyle \lim\limits_{n \to 0} \frac{2}{nN} \frac{\partial}{\partial z} F_v= \frac{1}{z-\int \frac{\mathrm{d}^d \vec{k}}{(2\pi)^d} \tilde G(\vec{k})}\end{aligned}$$\end{document}

We can perform the same calculation in the high-density theory by considering the limit ratiov(z)=1z∫ddk→(2π)dG~v(k→)→0\begin{document}$ratio_{v}(z)=\frac{1}{z}\int\frac{\mathrm{d}^{d}\vec{k}}{(2\pi)^{d}}\tilde{G}_ {v}(\vec{k})\to 0$\end{document}:(S98)limn→0limratiov(z)→0Fv=Vn2∫ddk→(2π)dG~(k→)f~(k→)+Nn2log⁡[z−∫ddk→(2π)dG~(k→)]−Vn2∫ddk→(2π)dlog⁡G~(k→)+N=Vn2∫ddk→(2π)dG~(k→)f~(k→)+Nn2log⁡(z)−Nn21z∫ddk→(2π)dG~(k→)−Vn2∫ddk→(2π)dlog⁡G~(k→)+N\begin{document}$$\begin{aligned} \lim\limits_{n \to 0} \lim\limits_{ratio_v(z) \to 0} F_v=& \, \displaystyle \frac{Vn}{2}\int \frac{\mathrm{d}^d \vec{k}}{(2\pi)^d} \frac{\tilde G(\vec{k})}{\tilde f(\vec{k})}+ \frac{Nn}{2}\log \left[z-\int \frac{\mathrm{d}^d \vec{k}}{(2\pi)^d} \tilde G(\vec{k})\right]\\& \displaystyle -\frac{Vn}{2} \int \frac{\mathrm{d}^d \vec{k}}{(2\pi)^d} \log\tilde G(\vec{k}) +N \\ = & \, \displaystyle \frac{Vn}{2}\int \frac{\mathrm{d}^d \vec{k}}{(2\pi)^d} \frac{\tilde G(\vec{k})}{\tilde f(\vec{k})}+ \frac{Nn}{2} \log(z)- \frac{Nn}{2} \frac{1}{z}\int \frac{\mathrm{d}^d \vec{k}}{(2\pi)^d} \tilde G(\vec{k})\\& \displaystyle -\frac{Vn}{2} \int \frac{\mathrm{d}^d \vec{k}}{(2\pi)^d} \log\tilde G(\vec{k}) +N\end{aligned}$$\end{document}

Therefore, we can define the free energy Fh\begin{document}$ F_{h}$\end{document} in the high-density theory as(S99)Fh=Vn2∫ddk→(2π)dG~(k→)f~(k→)+Nn2log⁡(z)−Nn21z∫ddk→(2π)dG~(k→)−Vn2∫ddk→(2π)dlog⁡G~(k→)+N\begin{document}$$\displaystyle F_h = \frac{Vn}{2}\int \frac{\mathrm{d}^d \vec{k}}{(2\pi)^d} \frac{\tilde G(\vec{k})}{\tilde f(\vec{k})}+ \frac{Nn}{2} \log(z)- \frac{Nn}{2}\frac{1}{z}\int \frac{\mathrm{d}^d \vec{k}}{(2\pi)^d} \tilde G(\vec{k})-\frac{Vn}{2} \int \frac{\mathrm{d}^d \vec{k}}{(2\pi)^d} \log\tilde G(\vec{k}) +N$$\end{document}

then(S100)δFhδG~=0\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \frac{\delta F_h }{\delta \tilde G} = 0 $$\end{document}(S101)1f~(k→)−ρz−1G~(k→)=0\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \frac{1}{\tilde f(\vec{k})} - \frac{\rho}{z} -\frac{1}{\tilde G(\vec{k})} = 0$$\end{document}

This is precisely Equation S90 derived in the previous section.(S102)g(z)≈limn→02nN∂∂zFh=1z+1z2∫ddk→(2π)dG~(k→)=1z+1z2∫ddk→(2π)df~(k→)1−ρzf~(k→)=1z[1+∫ddk→(2π)df~(k→)z−ρf~(k→)]=1z[1ρ∫ddk→(2π)dz−ρf~(k→)z−ρf~(k→)+∫ddk→(2π)df~(k→)z−ρf~(k→)]=1ρ∫ddk→(2π)d1z−ρf~(k→)\begin{document}$$\begin{aligned} g(z) & \approx \displaystyle \lim\limits_{n \to 0} \frac{2}{nN} \frac{\partial}{\partial z} F_h= \frac{1}{z} + \frac{1}{z^2}\int \frac{\mathrm{d}^d \vec{k}}{(2\pi)^d} \tilde G(\vec{k})\\ &= \displaystyle \frac{1}{z} + \frac{1}{z^2}\int \frac{\mathrm{d}^d \vec{k}}{(2\pi)^d} \frac{\tilde f(\vec{k})}{1 - \frac{\rho}{z} \tilde f(\vec{k})}\\ &= \displaystyle \frac{1}{z} \left[1+ \int \frac{\mathrm{d}^d \vec{k}}{(2\pi)^d} \frac{\tilde f(\vec{k})}{z - \rho \tilde f(\vec{k})}\right]\\ &= \displaystyle \frac{1}{z} \left[\frac{1}{\rho}\int \frac{\mathrm{d}^d \vec{k}}{(2\pi)^d} \frac{z - \rho \tilde f(\vec{k})}{z - \rho \tilde f(\vec{k})}+ \int \frac{\mathrm{d}^d \vec{k}}{(2\pi)^d} \frac{\tilde f(\vec{k})}{z - \rho \tilde f(\vec{k})}\right]\\ &= \displaystyle \frac{1}{\rho}\int \frac{\mathrm{d}^d \vec{k}}{(2\pi)^d} \frac{1}{z - \rho \tilde f(\vec{k})}\end{aligned}$$\end{document}
which is the resolvent of high-density approximation (Equation S37).

sec.title: Explicit expression for the integral
